projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Fragmenta Aurea.
A Collection of all THE Incomparable Peeces,
WRITTEN By Sir JOHN SVCKLING.
And publihed by a Friend to perpetuate his memory.
Printed by his owne Copies.
LONDON, Printed for Humphrey Moeley, and are to be old at his hop, at the Signe of the Princes Armes in St Pauls Churchyard MDCXLVI.

lg.l: SUCKLIN whose numbers could invite
Alike to wonder and delight
And with new spirit did inspire
The Thespian Scene and Delphick Lyre;
Is thus exprest in either part
Above the humble reach of art;
Drawne by the Pencill here yow find
His Forme by his owne Pen his mind.

div.head: To the READER.
div.p:
WHile Sucklins name is in the forehead of this Booke, thee Poems can want no preparation: It had been a prejudice to Poterity they hould have lept longer, and an injury to his own ahes. They that convers'd with him alive, and truly, (under which notion I comprehend only knowing Gentlemen, his oule being trancendent, and incommunicable to others, but by reflection) will honour thee pothume
Idaea's of their friend: And if any have liv'd in o much darknee, as not to have knowne o great an Ornament of our Age, by looking upon thee Remaines with Civility and Vndertanding, they may timely yet repent, and be forgiven.

In this Age of Paper-protitutions, a man may buy the reputation of ome Authors into the price of their Volume; but know, the Name that leadeth into this Elyium, is acred to Art and Honour, and no man that is not excellent in both, is qualified a Competent Judge: For when Knowledg is allowed, yet Education in the Cenure of a Gentleman, requires as many decents, as goes to make one; And he that is bold upon his unequall Stock, to traduce this Name, or Learning, will deerve to be condemned againe
into Ignorance his Originall inne, and dye in it.

But I keep backe the Ingenuous Reader, by my unworthy Preface: The gate is open, and thy oulé invited to a Garden of ravihing variety, admire his wit, that created thee for thy delight, while I withdraw into a hade, and contemplate who mut follow.
POEMS, &c.
Written by Sir JOHN SUCKLING.
Printed by his owne Copy.
The Lyrick Poems were et in Muick by Mr. Henry Lawes, Gent. of the Kings Chappel, and one of His Majeties Private Muick.
LONDON, Printed by Ruth Raworth for Humphrey Moely, and are to be old at his hop at the igne of the Princes Arms in S. Pauls Church-yard. 1646.

div.head: On New-years day 1640. To the KING.

lg.l: AWake (great Sir) the Sun hines heer,
Gives all Your Subjects a New-yeer,
Onely we tay till you appear,
For thus by us Your Power is undertood,
He may make fair days, You mut make them good.
Awake, awake,
and take
Such Preents as poor men can make,
They can adde little unto blie
who cannot wih.
May no ill vapour cloud the skie,
Bold torms invade the Soveraigntie,
But gales of joy, o freh, o high;
That You may think Heav'n ent to try this year
What ayl, or burthen, a Kings mind could bear.
Awake, awake, &c.
May all the dicords in Your State
(Like thoe in Muick we create)
Be govern'd at o wie a rate,
That what would of it elf ound harh, or fright,
May be o temper'd that it may delight.
Awake, awake, &c.
What Conquerors from battels find,
Or Lovers when their Doves are kind,
Take up henceforth our Maters mind,
Make uch trange Rapes upon the place, 't may be
No longer joy there, but an extaie.
Awake, awake, &c.
May every pleaure and delight
That has or does your ence invite
Double this year, ave thoe o'th night:
For uch a Marriage-bed mut know no more
Then repetition of what was before.
Awake, awake,
and take
Such Preents as poor men can make,
They can add little unto blie
who cannot wih.
THere never yet was honet man
That ever drove the trade of love;
It is impoible, nor can
Integrity our ends promove:
• or Kings and Lovers are alike in this
That their chief art in reigne diembling is.
Here we are lov'd, and there we love,
Good nature now and paion trive
Which of the two hould be above,
And laws unto the other give.
o we fale fire with art ometimes dicover,
• nd the true fire with the ame art do cover.
What Rack can Fancy find o high?
Here we mut Court, and here ingage,
Though in the other place we die.
Oh! 'tis torture all, and cozenage;
And which the harder is I cannot tell,
To hide true love, or make fale love look well.
Since it is thus, God of deire,
Give me my honety again,
And take thy brands back, and thy fire;
I'me weary of the State I'me in:
Since (if the very bet hould now befal)
Loves Triumph, mut be Honours Funeral.
IF when Don Cupids dart
Doth wound a heart,
we hide our grief
and hun relief;
The mart increaeth on that core;
For wounds unearcht but ranckle more.
Then if we whine, look pale,
And tell our tale,
men are in pain
for us again;
So, neither peaking doth become
The Lovers tate, nor being dumb.
When this I do decry,
Then thus think I,
love is the fart
of every heart.
It pains a man when 't is kept cloe,
And others doth offend, when 't is let looe.
A Seion was held the other day
And Apollo himelf was at it (they ay)
The Laurel that had been o long reerv'd,
Was now to be given to him bet deerv'd.
And
Therefore the wits of the Town came thither,
T was trange to ee how they flocked together,
Each trongly confident of his own way,
Thought to gain the Laurel away that day.
There Selden, and he ate hard by the chair;
Weniman not far off, which was very fair;
Sands with Townend, for they kept no order;
Digby and Shillingworth a little further:
And
There was Lucans Tranlator too, and he
That makes God peak o bigge in's Poetry;
Selwin and Walter, and Bartlets both the brothers;
Jack Vaughan and Porter, and divers others.
The firt that broke ilence was good old Ben,
Prepar'd before with Canary wine,
And he told them plainly he deerv'd the Bayes,
For his were calld Works, where others were but Plaies.
And
Bid them remember how he had purg'd the Stage
Of errors, that had lated many an Age,
And he hopes they did not think the ilent Woman,
The Fox, and the Alchymit out done by no man.

l.U: topt him there, and bade him not go on,

lg.l: 'Twas merit, he aid, and not preumption
Mut carry't; at which Ben turned about,
And in great choler offer'd to go out:
But
Thoe that were there thought it not fit
To dicontent o ancient a wit;
And therefore Apollo call'd him back agen,
And made him mine hot of his own new Inne.
Tom Carew was next, but he had a fault
That would not well tand with a Laureat;
His Mue was hard bound, and th'iue of's brain
Was eldom brought forth but with trouble and pain.
And
All that were preent there did agree,
A Laureat Mue hould be eaie and free,
Yet ure 'twas not that, but 'twas thought that his Grace
Conider'd he was well he had a Cup-bearers place.
Will. Davenant aham'd of a foolih michance
That he had got lately travelling in France,
Modetly hoped the handomnee of's Mue
Might any deformity about him excue.
And
Surely the Company would have been content,
If they could have found any Preident;
But in all their Records either in Vere or Proe,
There was not one Laureat without a noe.
To Will Bartlet ure all the wits meant well,
But firt they would ee how his now would ell:

l.U: mil'd and wore in their judgements they went lee,

lg.l: That concluded of merit upon uccee.
Suddenly taking his place agen,
He gave way to Selwin, who treight tept in;
But alas! he had been o lately a wit,
That Apollo hardly knew him yet.
Toby Mathews (pox on him) how came he there?
Was whipering nothing in ome-bodies ear:
When he had the honour to be nam'd in Court,
But Sir, you may thank my Lady Carleil for't:
For had not her care furniht you out
With omething of handome, without all doubt
You and your orry Lady Mue had been
In the number of thoe that were not let in.
In hate from the Court two or three came in,
And they brought letters (forooth) from the Queen,
'Twas dicreetly done too, for if th'had come
Without them, th'had carce been let into the room.
Suckling next was call'd, but did not appear,
But trait one whiperd Apollo i'th 'ear,
That of all men living he cared not for't,
He loved not the Mues o well as his port;
And prized black eyes, or a lucky hit
At bowls, above all the Trophies of wit;
But Apollo was angry, and publiquely aid
'Twere fit that a fine were et upon's head.
Wat Montague now tood forth to his tryal,
And did not o much as upect a denial;
But witty Apollo asked him firt of all
If he undertood his own Patoral.
For if he could do it, 't would plainly appear
He undertood more than any man there,
And did merit the Bayes above all the ret,
But the Mounier was modet, and ilence confet.
During thee troubles in the Court was hid
One that Apollo oon mit, little Cid;
And having pied him, call'd him out of the throng,
And advis'd him in his ear not to write o trong.
Murrey was ummon'd, but 't was urg'd that he
Was Chief already of another Company.

l.U: et by himelf mot gravely did mile

lg.l: To ee them about nothing keep uch a coil;
Apollo had pied him, but knowing his mind
Pat by, and call'd Faulkland that ate jut behind:
But
He was of late o gone with Divinity,
That he had almot forgot his Poetry,
Though to ay the truth (and Apollo did know it)
He might have been both his Priet and his Poet.
At length who but an Alderman did appear,
At which Will. Davenant began to wear;
But wier Apollo bade him draw nigher,
And when he was mounted a little higher
Openly declared that the bet igne
Of good tore of wit 's to have good tore of coyn,
And without a Syllable more or lee aid,
He put the Laurel on the Aldermans head.
At this all the wits were in uch a maze
That for a good while they did nothing but gaze
One upon another, not a man in the place
But had dicontent writ in great in his face.
Onely the mall Poets clear'd up again,
Out of hope as 't was thought of borrowing,
But ure they were out for he forfeits his Crown
When he lends any Poets about the Town.
IN each mans heart that doth begin
To love, there's ever fram'd within
A little world, for o I found,
When firt my paion reaon drown'd.
Earth, Intead of Earth unto this frame,
I had a faith was till the ame,
For to be right it doth behoove
It be as that, fixt and not move;
Yet as the Earth may ometime hake
(For winds hut up will caue a quake)
So, often jealouie, and fear,
Sunne, Stolne into mine, caue tremblings there.
My Flora was my Sun, for as
One Sun, o but one Flora was:
All other faces borrowed hence
Their light and grace, as tars do thence.
Moon My hopes I call my Moon; for they
Incontant till, were at no tay;
But as my Sun inclin'd to me,
Or more or lee were ure to be:
Sometimes it would be full, and then
Oh! too too oon decreae agen;
Eclip't ometimes, that 't would o fall
There would appear no hope at all.
Starres, My thoughts 'caue infinite they be
Mut be thoe many Stars we ee;
Fixed Planets. Of which ome wandred at their will,
But mot on her were fixed till.
Element of fire. My burning flame and hot deire
Mut be the Element of fire,
Which hath as yet o ecret been
That it as that was never een:
No Kitching fire, nor eating flame,
But innocent, hot but in name;
A fire that's tarv'd when fed, and gone
When too much fewel is laid on.
But as it plainly doth appear,
That fire ubits by being near
The Moons bright Orbe, o I beleeve
Ours doth, for hope keeps love alive.
Ayre. My fancy was the Ayre, mot free
And full of mutability,
Big with Chimera's, vapours here
Innumerable hatcht as there.
Sea. The Sea's my mind, which calm would be
Were it from winds (my paions) free;
But out alas! no Sea I find
Is troubled like a Lovers mind.
Within it Rocks and Shallows be,
Depair and fond credulity.
But in this World it were good reaon
We did ditinguih Time and Seaon;
Her preence then did make the Day,
And Night hall come when hee's away.
Winter. Long abence in far ditant place
Creates the Winter, and the pace
She tarryed with me; well I might
Summer. Call it my Summer of delight.
Diverity of weather came
From what he did, and thence had name;
Somtimes h'would mile, that made it fair;
And when he laught, the Sun hin'd clear.
Sometimes h'would frown, and ometimes weep,
So Clouds and Rain their turns do keep;
Sometimes again h'would be all ice,
Extreamly cold, extreamly nice.
But oft my Mue, the world is wide,
And all at once was not decride:
It may fall out ome honet Lover
The ret hereafter will dicover.
WHy o pale and wan fond Lover?
prethee why o pale?
Will, when looking wel can't move her
looking ill prevail?
prethee why o pale?
Why o dull and mute young inner?
prethee why o mute?
Will when peaking well can't win her,
prethee why o mute?
Quit, quit for hame, this will not move,
this cannot take her;
If of her elf he will not love,
nothing can make her:
the divel take her.
DO't ee how unregarded now
that piece of beauty paes?
There was a time when I did vow
to that alone;
but mark the fate of faces;
That red and white works now no more on me
Then if it could not charm or I not ee.
And yet the face continues good,
and I have till deires,
Am till the elf ame fleh and blood,
as apt to melt
and uffer from thoe fires;
Oh! ome kind power unriddle where it lies,
Whether my heart be faulty, or her eyes?
She every day her Man does kill,
and I as often die;
Neither her power then, nor my will
can quetion'd be,
what is the mytery?
Sure Beauties Empires, like to greater States
Have certain periods et, and hidden fates.
OF thee (kind boy) I ask no red and white
to make up my delight,
no odd becomming graces,
Black eyes, or little know-not-whats, in faces;
Make me but mad enough, give me good tore
Of Love, for her I Court,
I ask no more,
Tis love in love that makes the port.
There's no uch thing as that we beauty call,
it is meer couenage all;
for though ome long ago
Like't certain colours mingled o and o,
That doth not tie me now from chuing new,
If I a fancy take
To black and blue,
That fancy doth it beauty make.
Tis not the meat, but 'tis the appetite
makes eating a delight,
and if I like one dih
More then another, that a Pheaant is;
What in our watches, that in us is found,
So to the height and nick
We up be wound,
No matter by what hand or trick.
OH! for ome honet Lovers ghot,
Some kind unbodied pot
Sent from the hades below.
I trangely long to know
Whether the nobler Chaplets wear,
Thoe that their mitree corn did bear,
Or thoe that were us'd kindly.
For what-o-e're they tell us here
To make thoe ufferings dear,
'Twill there I fear be found,
That to the being crown'd,
T'have lov'd alone will not uffice,
Unlee we alo have been wie,
And have our Loves enjoy'd.
What poture can we think him in,
That here unlov'd agen
Departs, and's thither gone
Where each its by his own?
Or how can that Elizium be
Where I my Mitree till mut ee
Circled in others Armes?
For there the Judges all are jut,
And Sophonisba mut
Be his whom he held dear;
Not his who lov'd her here:
The weet Philoclea ince he dy'de
Lies by her Pirocles his ide,
Not by Amphialus.
Some Bayes (perchance) or Myrtle bough
For difference crowns the brow
Of thoe kind ouls that were
The noble Martyrs here;
And if that be the onely odds
(As who can tell) ye kinder Gods,
Give me the Woman here.

div.head: To his much honoured, the Lord Lepinton, upon his Tranlation of Malvezzi his Romulus and Tarquin.

lg.l: IT is o rare and new a thing to ee
Ought that belongs to young Nobility
In print (but their own clothes) that we mut praie
You as we would do thoe firt hew the waies
To Arts or to new Worlds: You have begun;
Taught travel'd youth what'tis it hould have done:
For't has indeed too trong a cutome bin
To carry out more wit then we bring in.
You have done otherwie, brought home (my Lord)
The choiet things fam'd Countries do afford
Malvezzi by your means is Englih grown,
And peaks our tongue as well now as his own.
Malvezzi, he: whom 'tis as hard to praie
To merit, as to imitate his waies.
He does not hew us Rome great uddenly,
As if the Empire were a Tympany,
But gives it natural growth, tells how, and why
The little body grew o large and high.
Decribes each thing o lively, that we are
Concern'd our elves before we are aware:
And at the wars they and their neighbours wag'd,
Each man is preent till, and till engag'd.
Like a good Propective he trangely brings
Things ditant to us: and in thee two Kings
We ee what made greatnee. And what 't has been
Made that greatnee contemptible again.
And all this not tediouly deriv'd,
But like to Worlds in little Maps contriv'd.
'Tis he that doth the Roman Dame retore,
Makes Lucrece chater for her being whore;
Gives her a kind Revenge for Tarquins in;
For ravih't firt, he raviheth again.
She ays uch fine things after't, that we mut
In pite of vertue thank foul Rape and Lut,
Since't was the caue no woman would have had,
Though he's of Lucrece ide, Tarquin lee bad.
But tay; like one that thinks to bring his friend
A mile or two, and ees the journeys end,
I traggle on too far: long graces do
But keep good tomacks off that would fall too.
STay here fond youth and ask no more, be wie,
Knowing too much long ince lot Paradie;
The vertuous joyes thou hat, thou would't hould till
Lat in their pride; and would't not take it ill
If rudely from weet dreams (and for a toy)
Tho'wert wak't? he wakes himelf that does enjoy.
Fruition adds no new wealth, but detroyes,
And while it pleaeth much the palate, cloyes;
Who thinks he hall be happyer for that,
As reaonably might hope he might grow fat
By eating to a Surfet, this once pat,
What relihes? even kies looe their tat.
Urge not 'tis neceary, alas! we know
The homeliet thing which mankind does is o;
The World is of a vat extent we ee,
And mut be peopled; Children there mut be;
So mut bread too; but ince there are enough
Born to the drudgery, what need we plough?
Women enjoy'd (what e're before t'have been)
Are like Romances read, or ights once een:
Fruition's dull, and poils the Play much more
Than if one read or knew the plot before;
'Tis expectation makes a bleing dear,
Heaven were not heaven, if we knew what it were.
And as in Propects we are there pleas'd mot
Where omthing keeps the eye from being lot,
And leaves us room to guee, o here retraint
Holds up delight, that with excee would faint.
They who know all the wealth they have, are poor,
Hee's onely rich that cannot tell his tore.
THere never yet was woman made,
nor hall, but to be curt;
And oh that I (fond I) hould firt
of any Lover
This truth at my own charge to other fools dicover.
You that have promis'd to your elves
propriety in love,
Know womens hearts like traws do move,
and what we call
Their ympathy, is but love to jett in general,
All mankind are alike to them;
and though we iron find
That never with a Loadtone joyn'd,
'tis not the irons fault,
It is becaue the loadtone yet was never brought.
If where a gentle Bee hath fall'n
and laboured to his power,
A new ucceeds not to that Flower,
but paes by;
'Tis to be thought, the gallant ele-where loads his thigh.
For till the flowers ready tand,
one buzzes round about,
One lights, one tats, gets in, gets out
all, all waies ue them,
Till all their weets are gone, and all again refue them.
NO, no, fair Heretick, it needs mut be
But an ill love in me,
And wore for thee;
For were it in my power,
To love thee now this hower
More then I did the lat;
I would then o fall
I might not love at all;
Love that can flow, and can admit increae,
Admits as well an ebbe, and may grow lee.
True Love is till the ame; the Torrid Zones,
And thoe more frigid ones
It mut not know:
For love grown cold or hot,
Is lut, or friendhip, not
The thing we have.
For that's a flame would dye
Held down, or up too high:
Then think I love more then I can expree,
And would love more could I but love thee lee.

div.head: To my Friend Will. Davenant; upon his Poem of Madagacar.

lg.l: WHat mighty Princes Poets are? thoe things
The great ones tick at, and our very Kings
Lay down, they venter on; and with great eae,
Dicover, conquer, what, and where they pleae.
Some Flegmatick Sea-Captain, would have taid
For money now, or victuals; not have waid
Anchor without 'em; Thou (Will) do't not tay
So much as for a wind, but go't away,
Land't, view't the Country; fight't, put't all to rout,
Before another could be putting out!
And now the news in Town is; Dav'nant's come
From Madagacar, Fraught with Laurel home;
And welcom (Will) for the firt time, but prithee
In thy next Voyage, bring the gold too with thee.

div.head: To my Friend Will. Davenant on his other Poems.

lg.l: THou hat redeem'd us, Wil. and future Times
Shall not account unto the Age's crimes
Dearth of pure wit: ince the great Lord of it
(Donne) parted hence, no Man has ever writ
So neer him, in's own way: I would commend
Particulars, but then, how hould I end
Without a Volume? Ev'ry line of thine
Would ask (to praie it right) twenty of mine.
LOve, Reaon, Hate, did once bepeak
Three mates to play at barley-break;
Love, Folly took; and Reaon, Fancy;
And Hate conorts with Pride; o dance they:
Love coupled lat, and o it fell
That Love and Folly were in hell.
They break, and Love would Reaon meet,
But Hate was nimbler on her feet;
Fancy looks for Pride, and thither
Hyes, and they two hugge together:
Yet this new coupling till doth tell
That Love and Folly were in hell.
The ret do break again, and Pride
Hath now got Reaon on her ide;
Hate and Fancy meet, and tand
Untoucht by Love in Folly's hand;
Folly was dull, but Love ran well,
So Love and Folly were in hell.
I Prethee pare me, gentle Boy,
Pree me no more for that light toy,
That foolih trifle of an heart,
I wear it will not do its part,
Though thou dot thine, employ't thy power and art.
For through long cutom it has known
The little ecrets, and is grown
Sullen and wie, will have its will,
And like old Hawks purues that till
That makes leat port, flies onely where 't can kill.
Some youth that has not made his tory,
Will think perchance the pain's the glory;
And mannerly it out Loves Feat;
I hall be carving of the bet,
Rudely call for the lat coure 'fore the ret.
And oh! when once that coure is pat,
How hort a time the Feat doth lat;
Men rie away, and carce ay grace,
Or civilly once thank the face
That did invite; but eek another place.

div.head: pon my Lady Carliles walking in Hampton-Court garden.

lg.l: DIdt thou not find the place inpir'd,
And flow'rs as if they had deir'd
No other Sun, tart from their beds,
And for a ight teal out their heads?
Heardt thou not muick when he talk't?
And didt not find that as he walkt
She threw rare perfumes all about
Such as beanblooms newly out,
Or chafed pices give?—
I mut confee thoe perfumes (Tom)
I did not mell; nor found that from
Her paing by, ought prung up new,
The flow'rs had all their birth from you;
For I pas't o're the elf ame walk,
And did not find one ingle talk
Of any thing that was to bring
This unknown after after pring.
Dull and inenible, could't ee
A thing o near a Deity
Move up and down, and feel no change?
None, and o great, were alike trange,
I had my Thoughts, but not your way,
All are not born (Sir) to the Bay;
Alas! Tom, I am fleh and blood,
And was conulting how I could
In pite of masks and hoods decry
The parts deni'd unto the eye;
I was undoing all he wore,
And had he walkt but one turn more,
Eve in her firt tate had not been
More naked, or more plainly een.
'T was well for thee he left the place,
There is great danger in that face;
But had't thou view'd her legg and thigh,
And upon that dicovery
Search't after parts that are more dear
(As Fancy eldom tops o near)
No time or age had ever een
So lot a thing as thou hadt been.
WOnder not if I tay not here,
Hurt Lovers (like to wounded Deer)
Mut hift the place for tanding till
Leaves too much time to know our ill:
Where there is a Traytor eye
That lets in from th'enemy
All that may upplant an heart,
'Tis time the Chief hould ue ome Art;
Who parts the object from the ence,
Wiely cuts off intelligence.
O how quickly men mut die,
Should they tand all Loves Battery;
Perindaes eyes great michief do,
So do we know the Canon too;
But men are afe at ditance till,
Where they reach not, they cannot kill.
Love is a fit, and oon is pat,
Ill dyet onely makes it lat;
Who is till looking, gazing ever,
Drinks wine i'th' very height o'th' Fever.
MY whining Lover, what needs all
Thee vows of life Monatical?
Depairs, retirements, jealouies,
Aud ubtile ealing up of eyes?
Come, come, be wie; return again,
A finger burnt's as great a pain;
And the ame Phyick, elf ame art
Cures that, would cure a flaming heart:
Would't thou whilt yet the fire is in
But hold it to the fire again.
If you (Dear Sir) the plague have got,
What matter is't whether or not
They let you in the ame houe lie,
Or carry you abroad to die?
He whom the plague, or Love once takes,
Every Room a Pet-Houe makes.
Abence were good if't were but ence
That onely holds th'Intelligence:
Pure love alone no hurt would do,
But love is love, and magick too;
Brings a mitree a thouand miles,
And the leight of looks beguiles,
Makes her entertain thee there,
And the ame time your Rival here;
And (oh! the divel) that he hould
Say finer things now then he would;
So nobly Fancy doth upply
What the dull ence lets fall and die.
Beauty like mans old enemy's known
To tempt him mot when hee's alone:
The ayre of ome wild o'regrown wood,
Or pathlee Grove is the Boyes food.
Return then back, and feed thine eye,
Feed all thy ences, and feat high.
Spare dyet is the caue Love lats,
For Surfets ooner kill than Fats.

div.head: A Supplement of an imperfect Copy of Veres of Mr. Wil. Shakepears, By the Author.

lg.l: ONe of her hands, one of her cheeks lay under,
Cozening the pillow of a lawful kie,
Which therefore wel'd, and eem'd to part aunder,
As angry to be rob'd of uch a blie:
The one lookt pale, and for revenge did long,
While t'other bluht, caue it had done the wrong.
Out of the bed the other fair hand was
On a green attin quilt, whoe perfect white
Lookt like a Dazie in a field of grae,
Thus far Shakepear. *And hew'd like unmelt now unto the ight,
There lay this pretty perdue, afe to keep
The ret oth' body that lay fat aleep.
Her eyes (and therefore it was night) cloe laid,
Strove to imprion beauty till the morn,
But yet the doors were of uch fine tuffe made,
That it broke through, and hew'd it elf in corn.
Throwing a kind of light about the place,
which turnd to miles til as't came near her face.
Her beams (which ome dul men call'd hair) divided
Part with her cheeks, part with her lips did port,
But thee, as rude, her breath put by till; ome
Wielyer downwards ought, but falling hort,
Curl'd back in rings, and eem'd to turn agen
To bite the part o unkindly held them in.
THat none beguiled be by times quick flowing,
Lovers have in their hearts a clock till going;
For though Time be nimble, his motions are quicker
and thicker
where Love hath his notions:
Hope is the main pring on which moves deire,
And thee do the lee wheels, fear, joy, inpire;
the ballance is thought, evermore clicking
and triking,
and ne're giving ore
Occaions the hand which till's moving round,
Till by it the Critical hour may be found,
And when that falls out, it will trike kies,
and what you bet like.
TIs now ince I ate down before
That foolih Fort, a heart;
(Time trangely pent) a Year, and more,
And till I did my part:
Made my approaches, from her hand
Unto her lip did rie,
And did already undertand
The language of her eyes.
Proceeded on with no lee Art,
My Tongue was Engineer;
I thought to undermine the heart
By whipering in the ear.
When this did nothing, I brought down
Great Canon-oaths, and hot
A thouand thouand to the Town,
And till it yeelded not.
I then reolv'd to tarve the place
By cutting off all kies,
Praying and gazing on her face,
And all uch little blies.
To draw her out, and from her trength,
I drew all batteries in:
And brought my elf to lie at length
As if no iege had been.
When I had done what man could do,
And thought the place mine owne,
The Enemy lay quiet too,
And mil'd at all was done.
I ent to know from whence, and where,
Thee hopes, and this relief?
A Spie inform'd, Honour was there,
And did command in chief.
March, march (quoth I) the word traight give,
Lets loe no time, but leave her:
That Giant upon ayre will live,
And hold it out for ever.
To uch a place our Camp remove
As will no iege abide;
I hate a fool that tarves her Love
Onely to feed her pride.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: IN bed dull man?
When Love and Hymens Revels are begun,
And the Chnrch Ceremonis pat and done.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: Why who's gone mad to day?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Dull Heretick, thou wouldt ay,
He that is gone to Heaven's gone atray;
Brohall our gallant friend
Is gone to Church as Martyrs to the fire:
Who marry differ but i'th'end,
Since both do take
The hardet way to what they mot deire:
Nor taid he till the formal Priet had done,
But ere that part was finiht, his begun:
Which did reveal
The hat and eagernee men have to eal
That long to tell the money.
A prigg of Willow in his hat he wore,
(The looers badge and liv'ry heretofore)
But now o ordered that it might be taken
By lookers on, foraking as foraken.
And now and then
A careles mile broke forth, which poke his mind,
And eem'd to ay he might have been more kind.
When this (dear Jack) I aw
Thought I
How weak is Lovers Law?
The bonds made there (like gypies knots) with eae
Are fat and looe, as they that hold them pleae.
But was the fair Nymphs praie or power lee
That led him captive now to happinee?
'Caue he did not a forreign aid depie,
But enterr'd breaches made by others eyes:
The Gods forbid,
There mut be ome to hoot and batter down,
Others to force and to take in the Town.
To Hawkes (good Jack) and hearts
There may
Be ev'ral waies and Arts;
One watches them perchance, and makes them tame:
Another, when they're ready, hews them game.

lg.l: WHether thee lines do find you out,
Putting or clearing of a doubt;
(Whether Predetination,
Or reconciling three in one,
Or the unriddling how men die,
And live at once eternally,
Now take you up) know 'tis decreed
You traight betride the Colledge Steed:
Leave Socinus and the Schoolmen,
(Which Jack Bond wears do but fool men)
And come to Town; 'tis fit you how
Your elf abroad, that men may know
(What e're ome learned men have guet)
That Oracles are not yet ceas't:
There you hall find the wit, and wine
Flowing alike, and both divine:
Dihes, with names not known in books,
And lee amongt the Colledge-Cooks,
With auce o pregnant that you need
Not tay till hunger bids you feed.
The weat of learned Johnons brain,
And gentle Shakepear's eas'er train,
A hackney-coach conveys you to,
In pite of all that rain can do:
And for your eighteen pence you it
The Lord and Judge of all freh wit.
News in one day as much w'have here
As erves all Windor for a year,
And which the Carrier brings to you,
After 't has here been found not true.
Then think what Company's deign'd
To meet you here, men o refin'd,
Their very common talk at boord,
Makes wie, or mad a young Court-Lord,
And makes him capable to be
Umpire in's Fathers Company.
Where no diputes nor forc't defence
Of a mans peron for his ence
Take up the time; all trive to be
Maters of truth, as victory:
And where you come, I'de boldly wear
A Synod might as eas'ly erre.
FYe upon hearts that burn with mutual fire;
I hate two minds that breath but one deire:
Were I to cure th'unhallow'd ort of men,
I'de wih them to love, and be lov'd agen.
Love's a Camelion, that lives on meer ayre;
And urfets when it comes to groer fare:
'Tis petty Jealouies, and little fears,
Hopes joyn'd with doubts, and joyes with April tears,
That crowns our Love with pleaures: thee are gone
When once we come to full Fruition.
Like waking in a morning, when all night
Our fancy hath been fed with true delight.
Oh! what a troke't would be! Sure I hould die,
Should I but hear my mitree once ay, I.
That monter expectation feeds too high
For any Woman e're to atifie:
And no brave Spirit ever car'd for that
Which in Down-beds with eae he could come at.
Shee's but an honet whore that yeelds, although
She be as cold as ice, as pure as now:
He that enjoys her hath no more to ay
But keep us Fating if you'l have us pray.
Then fairet Mitree, hold the power you have,
By till denying what we till do crave:
In keeping us in hopes trange things to ee
That never were, nor are, nor e're hall be.
I Tell thee Dick where I have been,
Where I the raret things have een;
Oh things without compare!
Such ights again cannot be found
In any place on Englih ground,
Be it at Wake, or Fair.
At Charing-Croe, hard by the way
Where we (thou know't) do ell our Hay,
There is a houe with tairs;
And there did I ee comming down
Such folk as are not in our Town,
Vorty at leat, in Pairs.
Amongt the ret, one Pet'lent fine,
(His beard no bigger though then thine)
Walkt on before the ret:
Our Landlord looks like nothing to him:
The King (God blee him) 'twould undo him,
Should he go till o dret.
At Coure-a-Park, without all doubt,
He hould have firt been taken out
By all the Maids i'th' Town:
Though luty Roger there had been,
Or little George upon the Green,
Or Vincent of the Crown.
But wot you what? the youth was going
To make an end of all his woing;
The Paron for him taid:
Yet by his leave (for all his hate)
He did not o much wih all pat,
(Perchance) as did the maid.
The maid (and thereby hangs a tale)
For uch a maid no Whiton-ale
Could ever yet produce:
No Grape that's kindly ripe, could be
So round, o plump, o oft as he,
Nor half o full of Juyce.
Her finger was o mall, the Ring
Would not tay on which they did bring,
It was too wide a Peck:
And to ay truth (for out it mut)
It lookt like the great Collar (jut)
About our young Colts neck.
Her feet beneath her Petticoat,
Like little mice tole in and out,
As if they fear'd the light:
But oh! he dances uch a way!
No Sun upon an Eater day
Is half o fine a ight.
He would have kit her once or twice,
But he would not, he was nice,
She would not do't in ight,
And then he lookt as who hould ay
I will do what I lit to day;
And you hall do't at night.
Her Cheeks o rare a white was on,
No Dazy makes comparion,
(Who ees them is undone)
For treaks of red were mingled there,
Such as are on a Katherne Pear,
(The ide that's next the Sun.)
Her lips were red, and one was thin,
Compar'd to that was next her chin;
(Some Bee had tung it newly.)
But (Dick) her eyes o guard her face;
I durt no more upon them gaze,
Then on the Sun in July.
Her mouth o mall when he does peak,
Thou'dt wear her teeth her words did break,
That they might paage get,
But he o handled till the matter,
They came as good as ours, or better,
And are not pent a whit.
If wihing hould be any in,
The Paron himelf had guilty bin;
(She lookt that day o purely,)
And did the youth o oft the feat
At night, as ome did in conceit,
It would have poil'd him, urely.
Jut in the nick the Cook knockt thrice,
And all the waiters in a trice
His ummons did obey,
Each erving man with dih in hand,
Marcht boldly up, like our Train'd Band,
Preented, and away.
When all the meat was on the Table
What man of knife, or teeth, was able
To tay to be intreated?
And this the very reaon was,
Before the Paron could ay Grace,
The Company was eated.
The bus'nee of the Kitchin's great,
For it is fit that men hould eat;
Nor was it there deni'd:
Paion oh me! how I run on!
There's that that would be thought upon,
(I trow) beides the Bride.
Now hatts fly off, and youths carroue;
Healths firt go round, and then the houe,
The Brides came thick and thick:
And when 'twas nam'd anothers health,
Perhaps he made it hers by tealth.
(And who could help it? Dick)
O'th' odain up they rie and dance;
Then it again and igh, and glance:
Then dance again and kie:
Thus ev'ral waies the time did pae,
Till ev'ry Woman wiht her place,
And ev'ry Man wiht his.
By this time all were toln aide
To counel and undree the Bride;
But that he mut not know:
But yet 'twas thought he ghet her mind,
And did not mean to tay behind
Above an hour or o.
When in he came (Dick) there he lay
Like new-faln now melting away,
('Twas time I trow to part)
Kies were now the onely tay,
Which oon he gave, as who would ay,
Good Boy! with all my heart.
But jut as heav'ns would have to croe it,
In came the Bridemaids with the Poet:
The Bridegroom eat in pight;
For had he left the Women to't
It would have cot two hours to do't,
Which were too much that night.
At length the candles out and out,
All that they had not done, they do't:
What that is, who can tell?
But I beleeve it was no more
Then thou and I have done before
With Bridget, and with Nell.
MY dearet Rival, leat our Love
Should with excentrique motion move,
Before it learn to go atray,
Wee'l teach and et it in a way,
And uch directions give unto't,
That it hall never wander foot.
Know firt then, we will erve as true
For one poor mile, as we would do
If we had what our higher flame,
Or our vainer wih could frame.
Impoible hall be our hope;
And Love hall onely have his cope
To joyn with Fancy now and then,
And think what reaon would condemn:
And on thee grounds wee'l love as true,
As if they were mot ure t'enue:
And chatly for thee things wee'l tay,
As if to morrow were the day.
Mean time we two will teach our hearts
In Loves burdens bear their parts:
Thou firt hall igh, and ay hee's fair;
And I'le till anwer, pat compare.
Thou halt et out each part o'th face,
While I extol each little grace;
Thou halt be raviht at her wit;
And I, that he o governs it:
Thou halt like well that hand, that eye,
That lip, that look, that majety;
And in good language them adore:
While I want words, and do it more.
Yea we will it and igh a while,
And with oft thoughts ome time beguil;
But traight again break out and praie
All we had done before new-waies.
Thus will we do till paler death
Come with a warrant for our breath,
And then whoe fate hall be to die
Firt of us two, by Legacy
Shall all his tore bequeath, and give
His love to him that hall urvive;
For no one tock can ever erve
To love o much as hee'l deerve.
HOnet Lover whooever,
If in all thy love there ever
Was one wav'ring thought, if thy flame
Were not till even, till the ame:
Know this,
Thou lov't amie,
And to love true,
Thou mut begin again, and love anew.
If when he appears i'th' room,
Thou dot not quake, and art truck dumb,
And in triving this to cover
Dot not peak thy words twice over,
Know this,
Thou lov't amie,
And to love true,
Thou mut begin again, and love anew.
If fondly thou dot not mitake,
And all defects for graces take
Perwad't thy elf that jeats are broken,
When he hath little or nothing poken,
Know this,
Thou lov't amie,
And to love true,
Thou mut begin again, and love anew.
If when thou appear't to be within,
Thou lett't not men ask and ask agen,
And when thou anwer't, if it be
To what was askt thee properly,
Know this,
Thou lov't amie,
And to love true
Thou mut begin again, and love anew.
If when thy tomack calls to eat,
Thou cutt't not fingers 'teed of meat,
And with much gazing on her face
Dot not rie hungry from the place,
Know this,
Thou lov't amie,
And to love true,
Thou mut begin again, and love anew.
If by this thou dot dicover
That thou art no perfect Lover,
And deiring to love true
Thou dot begin to love anew:
Know this,
Thou lov't amie,
And to love true,
Thou mut begin again, and love anew.
BEleev't yong Man, I can as eas'ly tell
How many yards and inches 'tis to hell;
Unriddle all predetination,
Or the nice points we now dipute upon,
Had the three Goddees been jut as fair,
It had not been o eaily decided
And ure the apple mut have been divided:
It mut, it mut; hee's impudent, dares ay
Which is the handomer till one's away.
And it was neceary it hould be o;
Wie Nature did foreee it, and did know
When he had fram'd the Eldet, that each heart
Mut at the firt ight feel the blind-god's dart:
And ure as can be, had he made but one,
No plague had been more ure detruction;
For we had lik't, lov'd, burnt to ahes too,
In half the time that we are chuing now:
Variety, and equal objects make
The buie eye till doubtful which to take;
This lip, this hand, this foot, this eye, this face,
The others body, geture, or her grace:
And whilt we thus dipute which of the two,
We unreolv'd go out, and nothing do.
He ure is happy't that has hopes of either,
Next him is he that ees them both together.
NOw we have taught our Love to know
That it mut creep where't cannot go
And be for once content to live,
Since here it cannot have to thrive;
It will not be amie t'enquire
What fuel hould maintain this fire:
For fires do either flame too high,
Or where they cannot flame, they die.
Firt then (my half but better heart)
Know this mut wholy be her part;
(For thou and I, like Clocks, are wound
Up to the height, and mut move round)
She then by till denying what
We fondly crave, hall uch a rate
Set on each trifle, that a kie
Shall come to be the utmot blie.
Where parks and fire do meet with tinder,
Thoe parks meer fire will till engender:
To make this good, no debt hall be
From ervice or fidelity;
For he hall ever pay that core,
By onely bidding us do more:
So (though he till a niggard be)
In graceing, where none's due, hee's free:
The favors he hall cat on us,
(Leat we hould grow preumptuous)
Shall not with too much love be hown,
Nor yet the common way till done;
But ev'ry mile and little glance
Shall look half lent, and half by chance:
The Ribbon, Fan, or Muffe that he
Would hould be kept by thee or me,
Should not be giv'n before to many,
But neither thrown to's when there's any;
So that her elf hould doubtful be
Whether 'twere fortune flung't, or he.
She hall not like the thing we do
Sometimes, and yet hall like it too;
Nor any notice take at all
Of what, we gone, he would extol:
Love he hall feed, but fear to nourih,
For where fear is, love cannot flourih;
Yet live it mut, nay mut and hall,
While Dedemona is at all:
But when hee's gone, then Love hall die,
And in her grave buried lie.
WEll hadow'd Landskip, fare-ye-well:
How I have lov'd you, none can tell,
At leat o well
As he that now hates more
Then e're he lov'd before.
But my dear nothings, take your leave,
No longer mut you me deceive,
Since I perceive
All the deceit, and know
Whence the mitake did grow.
As he whoe quicker eye doth trace
A fale tar hot to a mark't place,
Do's run apace,
And thinking it to catch,
A gelly up do's natch.
So our dull ouls tating delight
Far off, by ence, and appetite,
Think that is right
And real good; when yet
'Tis but the Counterfeit.
Oh! how I glory now that I
Have made this new dicovery!
Each wanton eye
Enflam'd before: no more
Will I encreae that core.
If I gaze, now, 'tis but to ee
What manner of deaths-head 'twill be,
When it is free
From that freh upper skin;
The gazers Joy, and in.
The Gun and glit'ning which with art
And tudi'd method, in each part
Hangs down the heart,
Looks (jut) as if, that day
Snails there had crawl'd the Hay.
The Locks, that curl'd o're each eare be,
Hang like two Mater-worms to me,
That (as we ee)
Have tated to the ret
Two holes, where they lik't bet.
A quick coare me-thinks I py
In ev'ry woman; and mine eye,
At paing by,
Check, and is troubled, jut
As if it roe from Dut.
They mortifie, not heighten me:
Thee of my ins the Glaes be:
And here I ee
How I have lov'd before.
And o I love no more.

div.p: LETTERS To divers Eminent PERSONAGES: Written on everal Occaions,
By Sir JOHN SUCKLING.
Printed by his owne Copy.
LONDON, Printed by Ruth Raworth for Humphrey Moeley, and are to be old at his hop at the igne of the Princes Arms in S. Pauls Church-yard. 1646.

FOrtune and Love have ever been o incompatible, that it is no wonder (Madam) if having had o much of the one for you, I have ever found o little of the other for my elf; Comming to Town (and having rid as if I had brought intelligence of a new-landed Enemy to the State) I find you gone the day before, and with you (Madam) all that is coniderable upon the place; for though you have left behind you, faces whoe beauties might well excue perjury in others, yet in me they cannot, ince to the making that no in, Loves Cauits have mot rationally reolved, that he for whom we forake, ought to be handomer then the foraken, which would be here impoible: So that now a gallerie hung with Titians or Vandikes hand, and a chamber filled with living Excellence, are the ame things to me; and the ue that I hall make of that Sex now, will be no other then that which the wier ort of Catholiques do of Pictures; at the highet, they but erve to raie my devotion to you: Should a great Beauty now reolve to take me in (as that is all they think belongs to it) with the Artillery of her eyes, it would be as vain, as for a
Thief to et upon a new robd paenger; You Madam) have my heart already, nor can you ue it unkindly but with ome injutice, ince (beides that it left a good ervice to wait on you) it was never known to tay o long, or o willingly before with any; After all, the wages will not be high; for it hath been brought up under Platonicks, and knows no other way of being paid for ervice, then by being commanded more; which truth when you doubt, you have but to end to its mater and

div.head: A diwaion from Love.
div.p: THough your dieae be in the number of thoe that are better cured with time then precept, yet ince it is lawful for every man to practie upon them that are foraken and given over (which I take to be your tate) I will adventure to precribe to you; and of the innocence of the Phyick you hall not need to doubt, ince I can aure you I take it daily my elf.

To begin Methodically, I hould enjoyn you Travel; for Abence doth in a kind remove the caue (removing the object) and anwers the Phyitians firt Recipez, vomiting and purging; but this would be too harh, and indeed not agreeing
to my way. I therefore advie you to ee her as often as you can, for (beides that the rarity of viits endears them) this may bring you to urprie her, and to dicover little defects, which though they cure not abolutely, yet they qualifie the fury of the Feaver: As neer as you can let it be uneaonably, when he is in icknes, and diorder; for that will let you know he is mortal, and a Woman, and the lat would be enough to a wie man: If you could draw her to dicoure of things he undertands not, it would not be amie.

Contrive your elf often into the Company of the cryedup Beauties; for if you read but one book, it will be no wonder if you peak or write that tile; variety will breed ditraction, and that will be a kind of diverting the humour.

I would not have you deny your elf the little things (for thee Agues are eaier cured with Surfets than abtinence) rather (if you can) tat all: for that (as an old Author aith) will let you ee
That the thing for which we wooe,
Is not worth o much ado.
But ince that here would be impoible, you mut be content to take it where you can get it. And this for your comfort I mut tell you (Jack) that Mitree and Woman differ no otherwie then Frontiniack and ordinary Grapes: which though a man loves never o well, yet if he urfet of the lat, he will care but little for the firt.

I would have you leave that foolih humour
(Jack) of aying you are not in love with her, and pretending you care not for her; for mothered fires are dangerous, and malicious humors are bet and afet vented and breathed out. Continue your affection to your Rival till, that will ecure you from one way of loving, which is in pite; and preerve your friendhip with her woman; for who knows but he may help you to the remedy.

A jolly glae and right Company would much conduce to the cure; for though in the Scripture (by the way it is but Apocrypha) Woman is reolved tronger than Wine, yet whether it will be o or not, when wit is joyned to it, may prove a freh quetion.

Marrying (as our friend the late Ambaador hath wittily oberved) would certainly cure it; but that is a kind of live Pigeons laid to the oals of the feet, a lat remedy, and (to ay truth) wore than the dieae.

But (Jack) I remember I promied you a letter, not a Treaty; I now expect you hould be jut, and as I have hewed you how to get out of love, o you (according to our bargain) hould teach me how to get into it. I know you have but one way, and will precribe me now to look upon Mitris Howard; but for that I mut tell you aforehand, that it is love as in Antipathy; The Capers which will make my Lord of Doret go from the Table, another man will eat up. And (Jack) if you would make a viit to Bedlam, you hall find,
that there are rarely two there mad for the ame thing.

THough (Madam) I have ever hitherto beleeved play to be a thing in it elf as meerly indifferent as Religion to a State-man, or love made in a privie-chamber; yet hearing you have reolved it otherwie for me, my faith hall alter without becomming more learned upon it, or once knowing why it hould do o; o great and jut a Soveraignty is that your reaon hath above all others, that mine mut be a Rebel to it elf, hould it not obey thus eaily; and indeed all the infallibility of judgement we poor Protetants have, is at this time wholy in your hands.

The loe of a Mitris (which kills men onely in Romances, and is till digeted with the firt meat we eat after it) had yet in me raied up o much paion, and o jut a quarrel (as I thought) to Fortune for it, that I could not but tempt her to do me right upon the firt occaion: yet (Maddame) has it not made me o deperate but that I can it down a loer both of that time and money too, when there hall be the leat fear of loing you

And now, ince I know your Ladyhip is too wie to uppoe to your elf impoibilities, and therefore cannot think of uch a thing, as of making me abolutely good; it will not be without
ome impatience that I hall attend to know what in you will be pleaed to aigne me in the room of this: omething that has lee danger about it (I conceive it would be) and therefore if you pleae (Madam) let it not be Women: for to ay truth, it is a dyet I cannot yet rellih, otherwie then men do that on which they urfetted lat.

BEfore this intant I did not beleeve Warwickhire the other world, or that Milcot walks had been the bleed hades. At my arrival here I am aluted by all as rien from the dead, and have had joy given me as prepoterouly and as impertinently as they give it to men who marry where they do not love. If I hould now die in earnet, my friends have nothing to pay me, for they have dicharged the Rites of Funeral orrow before hand. Nor do I take it ill, that report which made Richard the econd alive o often after he was dead, hould kill me as often when I am alive; The advantage is on my ide: The onely quarrel I have, is that they have made ue of the whole Book of Martyrs upon me; and without all quetion the firt Chritians under the great perecutions uffered not in 500. years, o many everal waies as I have done in ix daies in this lewd Town. This (Madam) may eem trange unto you
now, who know the Company I was in; and certainly if at that time I had departed this tranitory World, it had been a way they had never thought on; and this Epitaph of the Spaniards (changing the names) would better have become my Grave-tone, then any other my friends the Poets would have found out for me:

lg.head: Epitaph.
lg.l: Here lies Don Alonzo,
Slain by a wound received under
His left Pappe,
The Orifice of which was o
Small, no Chirurgion could
Dicover it.
Reader,
If thou wouldst avoid o trange
A Death,
Look not upon Lucinda'es eyes.

div.p:
Now all this dicoure of dying (Madam) is but to let you know how dangerous a thing it is to be long from London, epecially in a place which is concluded out of the World. If you are not to be frighted hither, I hope you are to be perwaded; and if good Sermons, or good Playes, new Braveries, or freh Wit, Revells (Madam) Masks that are to be, have any Rhetorique about them, here they are I aure you in perfection; without asking leave of the Provinces beyond Seas, or the aent of—I write not this that you hould think I value thee pleaures above thoe of Milcot: for I mut here protet, I
preferre the ingle Tabor and Pipe in the great Hall, far above them: and were there no more belonging to a journey then riding o many miles (would my affairs conpire with my deires) your Ladyhip hould find there not at the bottom of a Letter

I Thank Heaven we live in an Age in which the Widdows wear Coulers, and in a Country where the Women that loe their Husbands may be truted with poion, knives, and all the burning coals in Europe, notwithtanding the preident of Sophonisba and Portia: Conidering the etate you are in now, I hould reaonably imagine meaner Phyitians then Seneca or Cicero might adminiter comfort. It is o far from me to imagine this accident hould urprize you, that in my opinion it hould not make you wonder; it being not trange at all that a man who hath lived ill all his time in a houe, hould break a Window, or teal away in the night through an unuual Potern: you are now free, and what matter is it to a Prioner whether the fetters be taken off the ordinary way or not? If inteed of putting off handomly the chain of Matrimony, he hath rudely broke it, 'tis at his owne charge, nor hould it cot you a tear; Nothing (Madam) has wore Mine
than counterfet orrow, and you mut have the height of Womans Art to make yours appear other, epecially when the pectators hall conider all the tory.

The word that is placed betwixt a contracted Princee and an Ambaador, was as much a Huband, and the onely difference was, that that word laid in the bed, allowed one to upply its place; this Huband denied all, like a fale Crow et up in a Garden, which keeps others from the fruit it cannot tate it elf: I would not have you o much as enquire whether it were with his garters or his Cloak-bag trings, nor ingage your elf to freh ighs by hearing new relations.

The Spanih Princee Leonina (whom Balzac delivers the Ornament of the lat Age) was wie; who hearing a Pot was ent to tell her her Huband was dead, and knowing the Secretary was in the way for that purpoe, ent to tay the Pot till the arrival of the Secretary, that he might not be obliged to hed tears twice. Of ill things the lee we know, the better. Curioity would here be as vain, as if a Cuckold hould enquire whether it were upon the Couch or a Bed, and whether the Cavalier pulld off his Spurrs firt or not.

I mut confee it is a jut ubject for our orrow to hear of any that does quit his tation without his leave that placed him there; and yet as ill a Mine as this Act has: 't was a-la-Romanci, as you may ee by a line of Mr. Shakepears, who bringing in Titinius after a lot battel, peaking to
his word, and bidding it find out his heart, adds
By your leave Gods, this a Romanes part.

'Tis true, I think Cloak-bag trings were not then o much in fahion; but to thoe that are not Sword-men, the way is not o depicable; and for my owne part, I aure you Chritianity highly governs me in the minute in which I do not wih with all my heart that all the dicontents in his Majeties three Kingdoms would find out this very way of atisfying themelves and the world.

SInce the etling of your Family would certainly much conduce to the etling of your mind (the care of the one being the trouble of the other) I cannot but reckon it in the number of my misfortunes, that my affairs deny me the content I hould take to erve you in it.

It would be too late now for me (I uppoe) to advance or confirm you in thoe good reolutions I left you in, being confident your own reaon hath been o jut to you, as long before this to have repreented a neceity of redeeming time and fame, and of taking an handome revenge upon your elf for the injuries you would have done your elf.

Change I confee (to them that think all at once) mut needs be trange, and to you hateful, whom firt your owne nature, and then cutome
another nature, have brought to delight in thoe narrow and uncouth waies we found you in. You mut therefore conider that you have entred into one of thoe neer conjunctions of which death is the onely honourable divorce; and that you have now to pleae another as well as your elf; who though he be a Woman, and by the patent he hath from nature, hath liberty to do imply; yet can he never be o trongly bribed againt her elf, as to betray at once all her hopes and ends, and for your ake reolve to live mierably. Examples of uch loving folly our times afford but few; and in thoe there are, you hall find the tock of Love to have been greater, and their trengths richer to maintain it, than is to be feared yours can be.

Woman (beides the trouble) has ever been thought a Rent-charge, and though through the vain curioity of man it has often been incloed, yet has it eldom been brought to improve or become profitable; It faring with marryed men for the mot part, as with thoe that at great charges wall in grounds and plant, who cheaper might have eaten Mellons elewhere then in their owne Gardens Cucumbers. The ruines that either time, icknee, or the melancholy you hall give her, hall bring; mut all be made up at your cot: for that thing a huband is but Tenant for life in what he holds, and is bound to leave the place Tenantable to the next that hall take it. To conclude, a young Woman is a Hawk upon
her wings; and if he be handome, he is the more ubject to go out at check; Faulkners that can but eldom pring right game, hould till have omething about them to take them down with. The Lure to which all toop in this world, is either garniht with profit or pleaure, and when you cannot throw her the one, you mut be content to hew out the other. This I peak not out of a deire to increae your fears which are already but too many, but out of a hope that when you know the wort, you will at once leap into the River, and wim through handomly, and not (weather-beaten with the divers blats of irreolution) tand hivering upon the brink.

Doubts and fears are of all the harpet paions, and are till turning ditempers to dieaes; through thee fale Opticks 'tis, all that you ee is like evening haddows, diproportionable to the truth, and trangely longer then the true ubtance: Thee (when a handome way of living and expence utable to your Fortune is repreented to you) makes you in their tead ee want and beggery: thruting upon your judgement impoibilities for likelyhoods, which they with eae may do (ince as Solomon aith) they betray the uccors that reaon offers.

'Tis true, that all here below is but diverified folly, and that the little things we laugh at Children for, we do but act our elves in great; yet is there difference of Lunacy, and of the two, I had much rather be mad with him, that (when he had
nothing) thought all the Ships that came into the Haven his; Than with you, who (when you have o much comming in) think you have nothing; This fear of loing all in you, is the ill iue of a wore Parent, deire of getting in you; So that if you would not be paion-rent, you mut ceae to be covetous: Money in your hand is like the Conjurers Divel, which, while you think you have, that has you.

The rich Talent that God hath given, or rather lent you, you have hid up in a napkin, and Man knows no difference betwixt that and Treaures kept by ill Spirits, but that yours is the harder to come by. To the guarding of thee golden Apples, of neceity mut be kept thoe never leeping Dragons, Fear, Jealouie, Ditrut, and the like; o that you are come to moralize AEop, and his fables of beats are become prophecies of you; for while you have catcht at the hadow, uncertain riches; you have loft the ubtance, true content.

The deire I have ye hould be yet your elf, and that your friends hould have occaion to blee the providence of mifortune, has made me take the boldnes to give you your own Character; and to hew you your elf out of your own glae: And though all this tells you but where you are, yet it is ome part of a cure to have earcht the wound. And for this time we mut be content to do like Travellers, who firt find out the place, and then the neeret way.

YOur humble Servant had the honour to receive from your hand a Letter, and had the grace upon the ight of it to bluh. I but then found my owne negligence, and but now could have the opportunity to ask pardon for it. We have ever ince been upon a March, and the places we are come to, have afforded rather blood than Inke: and of all things, Sheets have been the hardet to come by, pecially thoe of Paper. If thee few lines hall have the happines to kie your hand, they can aure, that he that ent them knows none to whom he owes more obligation then to your Lordhip, and to whom he would more willingly pay it: and that it mut be no lee than neceity it elf that can hinder him from often preenting it. Germany hath no whit altered me, I am till the humble ervant of my Lord [] that I was, and when I ceae to be o, I mut ceae to be

SInce you can breath no one deire that was not mine before it was yours,—or full as oon, (for hearts united never knew divided wihes) I mut chide you (dear Princee) not thank you, for your Preent: and (if at leat I knew how) be angry with you for ending him a bluh, who needs mut bluh becaue you ent him one. If you are concious of much, what am I then? who
guilty am of all you can pretend to, and omthing more—unworthinee. But why hould you at all (Heart of my heart) diturb the happines you have o newly given me? or make love feed on doubts, that never yet could thrive on uch a diet? If I have granted your requet—Oh!—Why will you ever ay that you have tudied me, and give o great an intance to the contrary? that wretched If—peaks as if I would refue what you deire, or could: both which are equally impoible. My dear Princee, There needs no new Approaches where the Breach is made already; nor mut you ever ask any where, but of your fair elf, for any thing that hall concern
BUt that I know I love you more then ever any did any, and that yet I hate my elf becaue I can love you no more, I hould now mot unatified dipatch away this meenger.

The little that I can write to what I would, makes me think writing a dull commerce, and then—how can I chue but wih my elf with you—to ay the ret. My Dear Dear, think what merit, vertue, beauty, what and how far Aglaura with all her charmes can oblige, and o far and omething more I am

div.head: A Letter to a Friend to diwade him from marrying a Widow which he formerly had been in Love with, and quitted.
div.p: AT this time when no hot Planet fires the blood, and when the Lunaticks of Bedlam themelves are truted abroad; that you hould run mad, is (Sir) not o much a ubject for your friends pitty, as their wonder. 'Tis true, Love is a natural ditemper, a kind of Small Pocks: Every one either hath had it, or is to expect it, & the ooner the better.

Thus far you are excued: But having been well cured of a Fever, to court a Relape, to make Love the econd time in the ame Place, is (not to flatter you) neither better nor wore then to fall into a Quagmire by chance, and ride into it
afterwards on purpoe. 'Tis not love (Tom) that that doth the michief, but contancy, for Love is of the nature of a burning-glae, which kept till in one place, fireth: changed often, it doth nothing: a kind of glowing-Coal, which with hifting from hand to hand a man eaily endures. But then to marry! (Tom) Why thou hadt better to live honet. Love thou knowt is blind, what will he do when he hath Fetters on thinket thou?

Dot thou know what marriage is? 'Tis curing of Love the dearet way, or waking a looing Gameter out of a winning dream: and after a long expectation of a trange banquet, a preentation of a homely meal. Alas! (Tom) Love-eeds when it runs up to Matrimony, and is good for nothing. Like
ome Fruit-trees, it mut be tranplanted if thou wouldt have it active, and bring forth any thing.

Thou now perchance hat vowed all that can be vowed to any one face, and thinkt thou hat left nothing unaid to it: do but make love to another, and if thou art not uddenly furniht with new-language, and freh oathes, I will conclude Cupid hath ued thee wore then ever he did any of his train.

After all this, to marry Widow, a kind of chew'dmeat! What a fantatical tomack hat thou, that cant not eat of a dih til another man hath cut of it? who would wah after another, when he might have freh water enough for asking?

Life is ometimes a long-journey: to be
tyed to ride upon one beat till, and that halftyr'd to thy hand too! Think upon that (Tom.)

Well; If thou mut needs marry (as who can tell to what height thou hat inned? Let it be a Maid, and no Widow: (for as a modern Author hath wittily reolved in this cae) 'tis better (if a man mut be in Prion) to lie in a private room then in the hole.

div.head: An Anwer to the Letter.
div.p: CEae to wonder (honet Jack) and give me leave to pitty thee, who labouret to condemn that which thou confeet natural, and the ooner had, the better.

Thus far there needs no excue, unlee it be on thy behalf, who tilet econd thoughts (which are by all allowed the Bet) a relape, and talket of a quagmire where no man ever tuck fat, and accuet contancy of michief in what is natural, and adviedly undertaken.

'Tis confet that Love changed often doth nothing; nay 'tis nothing: for Love and change are incompatible: but where it is kept fixt to its firt object, though it burn not, yet it warms
and cheriheth, o as it needs no tranplantation, or change of oyl to make it fruitful: and certainly if Love be natural, to marry is the bet Recipe for living honet.

Yes, I know what mariage is, and know you know it not, by terming it the dearet way of curing Love: for certainly there goes more charge to the keeping of a Stable full of hores, then one onely Steed: and much of vanity is therein beides: when, be the errand what it will, this one Steed hall erve your turn as well as twenty more. Oh! if you could erve your Steed o!
Marriage turns pleaing Dreams to ravihing Realities which out doe what Fancy or expectation can frame unto themelves.

That Love doth eed when it runs into Matrimony,
is undoubted truth; how ele hould it increae and multiply, which is its greatet blesing.
'Tis not the want of Love, nor Cupids fault, if every day afford not new-language, and new-waies of expreing affection: it rather may be caued through an excee of joy, which oftentimes trikes dumb.

Thee things conidered I will marry, nay, and to prove the econd Paradox fale, I'le marry a Widow, who is rather the chewer, then thing chewed. How trangely fantatical is he who will be an hour in plucking on a trait-boot, when he may be forthwith furniht with enough that will come on eaily, and do him as much credit, and better ervice? Wine when firt-broacht, drinks not half o well as after a while drawing. Would
you not think him a mad man who whilt he might fair & eaily ride on the beaten-road-way, hould trouble himelf with breaking up of gaps? a well wayed hore will afely convay thee to thy journeys end, when an unbackt Filly may by chance give thee a fall: 'Tis Prince-like to marry a Widow, for 'tis to have a Tater.
Tis true, life may prove a longjourney; and o believe me it mut do, A very long one too, before the Beat you talke of prove tyr'd. Think you upon that (Jack.)

Thus, Jack, thou eet my wel-tane reolution of marrying, and that a Widow, not a maid; to which I am much induced out of what Pythagoras aith (in his 2da Sect. cu • iculorum) that it is better lying in the hole, then itting in the Stocks.

VVHen I receive your lines (my Dear Princee) and find there expreions of a Paion; though reaon and my own immerit tell me, it mut not be for me; yet is the Cozenage o pleaing to me, that I (bribed by my own deires) beleeve them till before the other. Then do I glory that my Virgin-Love has taid for uch an object to fixe upon, and think how good the Stars were to me that kept me from quenching thoe flames (Youth or wild Love furnihed me withall) in common and ordinary Waters, and reerved me a Sacrifice for your eyes;—While thought thus miles and olaces himelf within me, cruel Remembrance breaks in upon our retirements, and tells o ad a Story, that (trut me) I forget all that pleaed Fancy aid before, and turnes my thoughts to where I left you. Then I conider that tormes neither know Courthip, nor Pittie, and that thoe rude blats will often make you a Prioner this Winter, if they doe no wore.

While I here enjoy freh diverion, you make the ufferings more, by having leiure to conider them; nor have I now any way left me to make mine equal with them, but by often conidering that they are not o: for the thought that I cannot be with you to bear my hare, is more intolerable to me, then if I had borne
more—but I was onely born to number houres, and not enjoy them—yet can I never think my elfe unfortunate, while I can write my elfe

VVHen I conider (my Dear Princee that I have no other pretence to your favours, then that which all men have to the Original of Beauty, Light: which we enjoy not that it is the inheritance of our eyes, but becaue things mot excellent cannot retrain themelves, but are ours, as they are diffuively good; Then doe I find the jutnee of your quarrel, and cannot but bluh to think what I doe owe, but much more to thinke what I doe pay, Since I have made the Principal o great, by ending in o little Interet—When you have received this humble confeion, you will not I hope, conceive me one that would (though upon your bidding) enjoy my elfe, while there is uch a thing in the world, as—

SO much (Dear—) was I ever yours ince I had firt the honour to know you, and conequently o little my elf ince I had the unhappines to part with you, that you your elf (Dear) without what I would ay, cannot but have been o jut as to have imagined the welcom of your own letters; though indeed they have but removed me from one Rack, to et me on another; from fears and doubts I had about me of your welfare, to an unquietnee within my elf, till I have deerv'd this Intelligence.

How pleaingly troubleome thought and remembrance have been to me ince I left you, I am no more able now to expree, then another to have them o. You onely could make every place you came in worth the thinking of, and I do think thoe places worthy my thought onely, becaue you made them o. But I am to leave them, and I hall do't the willinger, becaue the Gameter till is o much in me, as that I love not to be told too often of my loes: Yet every place will be alike, ince every good object will do the ame. Variety of Beauty and of Faces (quick underminers of Contancy to others) to me will be but pillars to upport it; Since when they pleae me mot, I mot hall think of you.
In pite of all Philoophy, it will be hottet in my Climate, when my Sun is farthet off; and in pite of all reaon, I proclaim, that I am not my elf but when I am

THough deire in thoe that love be till like too much ail in a torm, and man cannot o eaily trike, or take all in when he pleaes: Yet (Dearet Princee) be it never o hard, when you hall think it dangerous, I hall not make it difficult, though—Well; Love is love, and Aire is Aire; and (though you are a Miracle your elf) yet do not I believe that you can work any; without it I am confident you can never make thee two thus different in themelves, one and the elf ame thing; when you hall, it will be ome mall furtherance towards it, that you have

postscript.p: Who o truly loves the fair Aglaura, that he will never know deire, at leat not entertain it, that brings not letters of recommendation from her, or firt a fair Paport.

div.p:
THink I have kit your Letter to nothing, and now know not what to anwer. Or that now I am anwering, I am kiing you to nothing, and know not how to go on! For you mut pardon, I mut hate all I end you here, becaue it exprees nothing in repect of what it leaves behind with me. And oh! Why hould I write then? Why hould I not come my elf? Thoe Tyrants, buinee, honour, and neceity, what have they to do with you and I? Why hould we not do Loves
commands before theirs whoe Soveraignty is but uurped upon us? Shall we not mell to Roes 'caue others do look on? or gather them, 'caue there are prickles, and omething that would hinder us? Dear—I fain would—and know no hindrance—but what mut come from you—and—why hould any come? ince 'tis not I, but you mut be enible how much time we loe, It being long ince I was not my elf, but

FInding the date of your Letter o young, and having an aurance from [ ] who at the ame time heard from Mr. [ ] that all our Letters have been delivered at [B] I cannot but imagine ome ill mitake, and that you have not received any at all. Faith I have none in Welch, man; and though Fear and Supition look often o far that they overee the right, yet when Love holds the Candle, they eldom do mitake o much. My Dearet Princee, I hall long, next hearing you are well, to hear that they are afe: for though I can never be ahamed to be found an Idolater to uch a hrine as yours, yet ince the world is ful of profane eyes, the bet way, ure, is to keep all myteries from them, and to let privacy be (what indeed it is) the bet part of devotion. So thinks
SInce the inferiour Orbes move but by the firt, without all quetion deires and hopes in me are to be govern'd till by you, as they by it. What mean thee fears then? Dear Princee.
Though Planets wander, yet is the Sphere that carries them the ame till; and though wihes in me may be extravagant, yet he in whom they make their motion is, you know, my dear Princee,

closer.signed: Yours, and wholy to be dipoed of by you.

postscript.p: And till we hear from you, though (according to the form of concluding a Letter) we hould now ret, we cannot.

div.p: IF parting be a in (as ure it is) what then to part from you? if to extenuate an ill be to increae it, what then now to excue it by a letter? That which we would alledge to leen it, with you perchance has added to the guilt already, which is our odain leaving you. Abruptnee is an eloquence in parting, when Spinning out of time, is but the weaving of new orrow. And thus we thought yet not being able to ditinguih of our owne Acts, the fear we may have inn'd farther then we think of, has made us end to you, to know whether it be Mortal or not.

div.head: For the Two Excellent Siters.
div.p:
THough I conceive you (Ladies) o much at leiure that you may read any thing, yet
ince the tories of the Town are meerly amorous, and ound nothing but Love, I cannot without betraying my owne judgement make them news for Wales. Nor can it be lee improper to tranport them to you, then for the King to end my Lord of C. over Ambaador this winter into Green-land.

It would want faith in o cold a Countrey as Angleey, to ay that your Cozen Dutchee, for the quenching of ome foolih flames about her, has endured quietly the loe of much of the Kings favour, of many of her houes, and of mot of her friends.

Whether the disfigurement that Travel or icknes has betowed upon B W. be thought o great by the Lady of the Ile, as 'tis by others, and whether the alteration of his face has bred a change in her mind—it never troubles you—Ladies. What old Loves are decay'd, or what newones are prung up in their room; Whether this Lady be too dicreet, or that Cavalier not ecret enough; are things that concern the inhabitants of Angleey not at all. A fair day is better welcom and more news, then all that can be aid in this kind. And for all that I know now, the Divels Chimney is on fire, or his pot eething over, and all North-Wales not able to tay the fury of it. Perchance while I write this, a great black cloud is ayling from Mitris Thomaes bleak Mountains over to Baron-hill, there to digorge it elf with what the Sea or wore places fed it with before.

It may be the honet banks about you turn bankrupt too, and break; and the Sea like an angry Creditor eizes upon all, and hath no pitty, becaue he has been put off o long from time to time. For variety (and it is not impoible) ome boyterous wind flings up the hangings; and thinking to do as much to your cloths, finds a reitance, and o departs, but firt breaks all the windows about the houe for it in revenge.
Thee things now we that live in London cannot help, and they are as great news to men that it in Boxes at Black-Fryars, as the affairs of Love to Flannel-Weavers.

For my own part, I think I have made a great complement, when I have wiht my elf with you, and more then I dare make good in Winter: and yet there is none would venture farther for uch a happines then

div.head: The Wine-drinkers to the Water-drinkers, greeting.
div.p:
