WHereas by your Ambaador two daies ince ent unto us, we undertand that you have lately had a plot to urprize (or to peak more properly) to take the waters; and in it have not onely a little micarryed, but alo met with uch difficulties, that unlee you be peedily relieved, you are like to uffer in the adventure; We as well out of pitty to you, as out of care to our State and Common-Wealth (knowing that Women have ever been held neceary, and that
nothing reliheth o well after Wine) have o far taken it into our conideration, that we have neglected no means ince we heard of it firt, that might be for your contents, or the good of the caue; and therefore to that purpoe we have had divers meetings at the Bear at the Bridge-foot and now at length have reolv'd to dipatch to you one of our Cabinet-Councel, Colonel Young, with ome light Forces of Canary, and ome few of Sherry, which no doubt will tand you in good teed, if they do not mutiny and grow too headtrong for their Commander; him Captain Puffe of Barton hall follow with all expedition, with two or three Regiments of Claret; Monieur de Granville, commonly called Lieutenant Strutt, hall lead up the Reer of Rhenih and White. Thee uccors thus timely ent, we are confident will be ufficient to hold the Enemy in Play; and till we hear from you again, we hall not think of a freh upply: For the Waters (though perchance they have driven you into ome extremities, and divers times forc't their paages through ome of your bet guarded places) yet have they, if our intelligence fail us not, hitherto had the wort of it till, and evermore at length plainly run away from you.

closer.dateline: Given under our hands at the Bear, this fourth of July.

div.p:
SInce Joy (the thing we all o Court) is but our hopes tript of our fears, pardon me if I be till
preing at it, and like thoe that are curious to know their fortunes aforehand deire to be atified, though it dipleaes me afterward. To this Gentleman (who has as much in-ight as the t'other wanted Ey-ight) I have committed the particulars, which would too much well a Letter: if they hall not pleae you, 'tis but freh ubject till for Repentance; nor ever did that make me quarrel with any thing but my owne tarres. To wear new oaths from this place, were but to weaken the credit of thoe I have worn in another: if heaven be to forgive you now for not beleeving of them then, (as ure as it was a in) heaven forgive me now for wearing of them then (for that was double in.) More then I am I cannot be, nor lit,

postscript.p: I am not o ill a Protetant as to beleeve in merit, yet if you pleae to give anwer under your owne hand, uch as I hall for ever rely upon: if I have not deerv'd it already, it is not impoible but I may.

div.head: To a Coin (who till loved young Girles, and when they came to be mariageable, quitted them, and fell in love with freh) at his fathers requet, who deired he might be perwaded out of the humour, and marry.
div.p:
VVEre there not fooles enow before in the Common-Wealth of Lovers, but that
thou mut bring up a new Sect? Why delighted with the firt knots of roes, and when they come to blow (can atisfie the ence, and do the end of their Creation) dot not care for them? Is there nothing in this foolih tranitory world that thou cant find out to et thy heart upon, but that which has newly left off making of dirt-pyes, and is but preparing it elf for loam, and a greenicknes? Seriouly (Charles) and without ceremony, 'tis very foolih, and to love widdows is as tolerable an humour, and as jutifiable as thine—for beats that have been ridd of their legges are as much for a mans ue, as Colts that are un-way'd, and will not go at all:—Why the divel uch yong things? before thee undertand what thou wouldt have, others would have granted. Thou dot not marry them neither, nor any thing ele. 'Sfoot it is the tory of the Jack-an-apes and the Partridges; thou taret after a beauty till it is lot to thee, & then let't out another, and taret after that till it is gone too. Never conidering that it is here as in the Thames, and that while it runs up in the middle, it runnes down on the ides; while thou contemplat't the comming-in-tide and flow of Beauty, that it ebbes with thee, and that thy youth goes out at the ame time: After all this too, She thou now art cat upon will have much ado to avoid being ugly. Pox on't, Men will ay thou wert benighted, and wert glad of any Inne. Well! (Charles) there is another way if you could find it out. Women are like Melons: too green,
or too ripe, are worth nothing; you mut try till you find a right one. Tat all, but hark you—(Charles) you hall not need to eat of all, for one is ufficient for a urfet: Your most humble ervant.

I hould have perwaded you to marriage, but to deal ingeniouly, I am a little out of arguments that way at this preent: 'Tis honourable, there's no quetion on't; but what more, in good faith I cannot readily tell.

TO tell you that neither my misfortunes nor my ins did draw from me ever o many ighs as my departure from you has done, and that there are yet tears in mine eyes left undryed for it; or that melancholy has o deeply eized me, that colds and dieaes hereafter hall not need above half their force to detroy me, would be I know uperfluous and vain, ince o great a goodnee as yours, cannot but have out-beleeved already what I can write.

He never knew you that will not think the loe of your Company, greater then the Imperialits can all this time the loe of all their Companies; and he hall never know you that can think it greater then I, who though I never had neither widom nor wit enough to admire you to your worth, yet had my Judgement ever o much right in it, as to admire you above all. And thus he aies that dares wear he is

THe ditrut I have had of not being able to write to you any thing which might pay the charge of reading, has perwaded me to forbear kiing your hands at this ditance: So, like Women that grow proud, becaue they are chate; I thought I might be negligent, becaue I was not troubleom. And, were I not afe in your goodnes, I hould be (Madam) in your judgement; which is too jut to value little obervances, or think them neceary to the right honouring my Lady.

Your Ladyhip I make no doubt, will take into conideration, that upertition hath ever been fuller of Ceremony then the true worhip. When it hall concern any part of your real ervice, and I not throw by all repects whatoever to manifet my devotion, take what revenge you pleae. Undo me Madam: Reume my bet Place and Title; and let me be no longer.

BY the ame reaon the Ancients made no acrifice to death, hould your Ladyhip end me no Letters; ince there has been no return on my ide. But the truth is, the place affords nothing: all our dayes are (as the Women here) alike: and the difference of Fair, does rarely hew it elfe; Such great State do Beauty and the Sun keep in
thee parts. I keep company with my own Hores (Madam) to avoid that of the men; and by this you may guee how great an enemy to my living contentedly my Lady is, whoe converation has brought me to o fine a diet, that, whereoever I go, I mut tarve: all daies are tedious, companies troubleom, and Books themelves (Feats heretofore) no relih in them. Finding you to be the caue of all this, Excue me (Madam) if I reent: and continue peremptory in the reolution I have taken to be

BUt that I know your goodnes is not mercinary, and that you receive thanks, either with as much trouble as men ill news, or with as much wonder as Virgins unexpected Love, this letter hould be full of them. A trange proud return you may think I make you (Madam) when I tell you, it is not from every body I would be thus obliged; and that if I thought you did me not thee favours becaue you love me; I hould not love you becaue you do me thee favours. This is not language for one in Affliction, I confee, and upon whom it may be at this preent, a cloud is breaking; but finding not within my elf I have deerv'd that torm; I will not make it greater by apprehending it.

After all, leat (Madam) you hould think I take your favours as Tribute; to my great grief, I here
declare, that the ervices I hall be able to render you, will be no longer Preents, but payments of Debts; ince I can do nothing for you hereafter, which I was not obliged to do before.

closer.signed: Your mot humble and faithful ervant.

div.p: THat you have overcome the danger of the Land and of the Sea, is news mot welcom to us, and with no lee joy receiv'd amongt us than if the King of Sweden had the econd time overcome Tilley, and again pat the Meine and the Rhine. Nor do we in this look more upon our elves and private interets, then on the publike, ince in your afety both were compried. And though you had not had about you the affairs and ecrets of State, yet to have left your own peron upon the way, had been half to undoe our poor Iland, and the loe mut have been lamented with the tears of a whole Kingdom.

But you are now beyoud all our fears, and have nothing to take heed on your elf, but fair Ladies. A pretty point of ecurity; and uch a one as all Germany cannot afford. We here convere with Northern Beauties, that had never heat enough to kindle a park in any mans breat, where heaven had been firt o merciful, as to put in a reaonable oul.

There is nothing either fair or good in this part of the world; and I cannot name the thing can
give me any content, but the thought that you enjoy enough otherwhere: I having ever been ince I had the firt honour to know you,

TO perwade one that has newly hip-wrackt upon a Coat to imbarque odainly for the ame place again, or your Lordhip to eek that content you now enjoy in the innocence of a olitude, among the diorders and troubles of a Court, were I think a thing the King himelf (and Majety is no ill Orator) would find ome difficulty to do. And yet when I conider that great oul of yours, like a Spider, working all inwards, and ending forth nothing, but like the Cloiter'd Schoolmens Divinity, threads fine and unprofitable: if I thought you would not upect my being erious all this while, for what I hould now ay, I would tell you that I cannot but be as bold with you as your Ague is, and for a little time, whether you will or not entertain you curvily.

When I conider you look (to me) like—I cannot but think it as odd a thing, as if I hould ee Van Dike with all his fine colours and Penills about him, his Frame, and right Light, and every thing in order, and yet his hands tyed behind him: and your Lordhip mut excue me if upon it I be as bold.

The wiet men, and greatet States have made no cruple to make ue of brave men whom they
had laid by with ome digrace nor have thoe brave men o laid by, made cruple, or thought it a digrace to erve again, when they were called to it afterwards.

Thee general motives of the State and Common good, I will not o much as once offer up to your Lordhips conideration, though (as 'tis fit) they have till the upper end: yet, like great Oleoes, they rather make a hew then provoke Appetite. There are two things which I hall not be ahamed to propound to you, as ends; ince the greater part of the wie men of the world have not been ahamed to make them theirs: and if any has been found to contemn them, it hath been trongly to be upected that either they could not eaily attain to them, or ele that the readiet way to attain to them was to contemn them. Thee two are Honour and Wealth: and though you tand poet of both of them, yet is the firt in your hands like a word, which, if not through negligence, by michance hath taken rut, and needs a little clearing; and it would be much handomer a preent to poterity, if you your elf in your life time wipe it off.

For your Etate (which it may be had been more had it not been too much) though it is true that it is o far from being contemptible, that it is Nobly competent, yet mut it be content to undergo the ame fate greater tates (Common-wealths themelves) have been & are ubject to: which is, when it comes to be divided in it elf, not to be coniderable.
Both Honour and Etate are too fair and weet Flowers, to be without Prickles, or to be gathered without ome cratches.
And now (my Lord) I know you have nothing to urge but a kind of incapability in your elf to the ervice of this State; when indeed you have made the onely bar you have, by imagining you have one

I confee (though) had vice o large an Empire in the Court, as heretofore it has had, or were the times o dangerous that to the living well there, wie conduct were more neceary then vertue it elf; Your Lordhip would have reaon (with AEops countrey-moue) to undervalue all change of condition; ince a quiet-mediocrity is till to be preferred before a troubled uperfluity: but thee things are now no more: and if at any time they have threatned that Horizon, like great clouds, either they are fallen of themelves to the ground, or ele, upon the appearing of the Sunne (uch a Prince as ours is) they have vanihed, and left behind them clear and fair daies. To decend to parts, envie is o leen'd, that it is almot lot into vertuous emulation, every man truting the Kings judgement o far, that he knows no better meaure of his own merit, then his reward. The little word behind the back, and undoing whiper, which, like pulling of a heat-rope at Sea, lackens the ail, and makes the gallantet hip tand till; that that heretofore made the faulty and the innocent alike guilty, is a thing, I beleeve, now o
forgot; or at leat o unpractiz'd, that thoe that are the wort, have leiure to grow good, before any will take notice they have been otherwie, or at leat divulge it.

'Tis true, Faction there is, but 'tis as true, that it is as winds are, to clear, and keep places free from corruption; the oppoitions being as harmlee, as that of the meeting-tides under the bridge, whoe encounter makes it but more eaie for him that is to pae. To be a little pleaant in my intances; The very women have uffered reformation, and wear through the whole Court their faces as little diguied now, as an honet mans actions hould be, and if there be any have uffer'd themelves to be gained by their ervants, their ignorance of what they granted may well excue them from the hame of what they did. So that it is more then poible to be great and good: and we may afely conclude, if there be ome that are not o exact, as much as they fall hort of it, jut o much they have gone from the great Original, God; and from the bet Copies of him on earth, the King and the Queen.

To conclude, If thoe accidents or diaters which make men grow lee in the world (as ome uch, my Lord, have happened to you) were inevitable as death, or, when they were once entered upon us, there were no cure for them; examples of others would atisfie me for yours; but ince there have been that have delivered themelves from their ills, either by their good Fortune,
or Vertue, 'twould trouble me that my friends hould not be found in that number, as much as if one hould bring me a Catalogue of thoe that truly honoured my Lord of—and I hould not find among the firt,

div.head: To Mr. Henry German, in the beginning of PARLIAMENT, 1640.
div.p:
THat it is fit for the King to do omething extraordinary at this preent, is not onely the opinion of the wie, but the expectation. Men oberve him more now then at other times: for Majetie in an Eclipe, like the Sun, draws eyes that would not o much as have looked towards it, if it had hined out, and appeared like it elf. To lie till now, would, at the bet, hew but a calmnee of mind, not a magnanimity; ince in matter of government, to think well (at any time, much lee in a very active) is little better then to dream well. Nor mut he tay to act till his people deire, becaue 'tis thought nothing relihes ele: for therefore hath nothing reliht with them, becaue the King hath for the mot part tayed till they have deired; done nothing but what they have or were petitioning for. But, that the King hould do, will not be o much the quetion, as what he hould do. And certainly, for a King to have right counel given him, is at all times trange, and at this
preent impoible. His party for the mot part (I would that were modetly aid, and it were not all) have o much to do for their own preervation, that they cannot (without breaking a law in nature) intend anothers. Thoe that have courage have not perchance innocence, and o dare not hew themelves in the Kings buines; and if they have innocence, they want parts to make themelves coniderable; o conequently the things they undertake. Then, in Court, they give much counel, as they beleeve the King inclin'd, determine his good by his deires: which is a kind of etting the Sun by the Dial, Interet which cannot er • e, by paions which may.

In going about to hew the King a Cure, now a man hould firt plainly hew him the dieae. But to Kings, as to ome kind of Patients, it is not alwaies proper to tell how ill they be: and it is too like a Countrey clown not to hew the way, unles he know from whence, and dicoure of things before.

Kings may be mitaken, and Councellors corrupted; but true interet alone (aith Monieur de Rohan) cannot erre. It were not amie then to find out the Interet: for etting down right principles before concluions, is weighing the cales before we deal out the commodity.

Certainly the great interet of the King is, A union with his People, and whooever hath told him otherwie (as the Scripture aith of the divel) was a educer from the firt. If there ever had been any
one Prince in the whole world that made a felicity in this life, and left fair Fame after death, without the love of his Subjects, there were ome colour to depie it.

There was not among all our Princes a greater Courtier of the People then Richard the third, not o much out of fear, as out of wiedom. And, hall the wort of our Kings have triven for that? and hall not the bet? (it being an Angelical thing to gain love.)
There are 2. things in which the people expect to be atisfied; Religion, and Justice: nor can this be done by any little acts, but by Royal and Kingly reolutions.

If any hall think that by dividing the factions (a good rule at other times) he hall mater the ret now, he will be trangely deceived: for in the beginning of things That would do much, but not when whole Kingdoms are reolv'd. Of thoe now that lead thee parties, if you could take off the major number, the leer would govern, and do the ame things till: nay, if you could take off all, they would et up one, and follow him.

And of how great conequence it is for the King to reume this right, and be the author himelf, let any body judge: ince as Cumneus aid, thoe that have the art to pleae the People, have commonly the power to raie them.

To do things o that there hall remain no jealouie, is very neceary, and is no more then really
reforming, that is, pleaing them. For to do things that hall grieve hereafter, and yet pretend love (amongt lovers themelves, where there is eaiet faith) will not be accepted. It will not be enough for the King to do what they deire, but he mut do omthing more: I mean (by doing more) doing omthing of his owne, as throwing away things they call not for, or giving things they expected not. And when they ee the King doing the ame things with them, it will take away all thought and apprehenion that he thinks the things they have done already ill.

Now if the King ends the differences, and takes away upect for the future, the cae will fall out to be no wore then when two duellits enter the Field, where the worted party (the other having no ill opinion of him) hath his word given him again (without further hurt after he is in the others power.) But otherwie it is not afe to imagine what may follow: for the people are naturally not valiant, and not much Cavalier. Now it is the nature of Cowards to hurt where they can receive none. They will not be content (while they fear and have the upper hand) to fetter only Royalty, but perchance (as timorous pirits ue) will not think themelves afe while that is at all. And poibly, this is the preent tate of things.

In this great work (at leat to make it appear perfect and lating to the Kingdom) it is neceary the Queen really joyn; for if he tand aloof, there will till be upicions: it being a received opinion
in the world, that he hath a great interet in the Kings favor and power. And to invite her, he is to conider with her elf, whether uch great vertues and eminent excellencies (though they be highly admired & valued by thoe that know her) ought to ret atisfied with o narrow a payment as the etimation of a few? And whether it be not more proper for a great Queen to arrive at univeral honour, and love, then private eteem and value.
Then, how becomming a work, for the weetnes and oftnes of her Sex, is compoing of differences, and uniting hearts? and how proper for a Queen, reconciling King and People?

There is but one thing remains, which whiper'd abroad, buies the Kings mind much (if not diturbs it) in the midt of thee great Reolutions, and that is, The preervation of ome ervants, whom he thinks omwhat hardly torn from him of late: which is of o tender a nature; I hal rather propound omething about it, then reolve it.

The firt Quaere will be, Whether as things now tand (Kingdoms in the ballance) the King is not to follow nature, where the conervation of the more general till commands and governs the lee. As Iron by particular ympathy ticks to the loadtone, but yet if it be joyned with a great body of Iron, it quits thoe particular affections to the loadtone, and moves with the other, to the greater, the common Countrey.

The econd will be, Whether, if he could preerve
thoe miniters, they can be of any ue to him hereafter? ince no man is erved with a greater prejudice, then he that employs upected intruments, or not beloved, though able and deerving in themelves.

The third is, Whether, to preerve them, there be any other way then for the King to be firt right with his people? ince the rule in Philoophy mut ever hold good, nihil dat quod non habet. Before the King have power to ave, he mut have power.

Latly, Whether the way to preerve this power be not to give it away? For the people of England have ever been like wantons, which pull and tugg as long as the princes have pull'd w • th them, as you may ee in Hen. 3. King John, Edw. 2. and indeed, all the troubleom and unfortunate reigns; but when they have let it go, they come and put it into their hands again, that they may play on: as you may ee in Queen Elizabeth.

I will conclude with a prayer (not that I think it needs at this preent: Prayers are to keep us from what may be, as well as to preerve us from what is) That the King be neither too inenible of what is without him, nor too reolved from what is within him. To be ick of a dangerous icknes, and find no pain, cannot but be with loe of undertanding (Tis an Aphorime of Hippocrates) and on the other ide, Opiniatrie is a ullen Porter, and (as it was wittily aid of Contancy) hutts out often-times, Better things then it lets in.
AN ACCOVNT OF RELIGION BY REASON. A Dicoure upon Occaion preented to the Earl of Doret.
By Sir JOHN SUCKLING.
Printed by his owne Copy.

q.l: Tentat enim dubiam mentem rationis egetas.

div.p: LONDON, Printed by Ruth Raworth for Humphrey Moeley, and are to be old at his hop at the igne of the Princes Arms in S. Pauls Church-yard. 1646.

div.head: The Epitle.
div.p:
I Send you here (my Lord) that Dicoure enlarged, which frighted the Lady into a cold weat, and which had like to have made me an Atheit at Court, and your Lordhip no very good Chritian. I am not ignorant that the fear of Socinianime at this time, renders every man that offers to give an account of Religion by Reaon, upected to have none at all: yet I have made no cruple to run that hazard, not knowing why a man hould not ue the best Weapon his Creator hath given him for his defence. That Faith was by the Apostles both highly exalted, and everely enjoyned, is known to every man, and
this upon excellent grounds; for it was both the eaiest and bet way of converting: the other being tedious, and almot uelee: for but few among thouands are capable of it, and thoe few not capable at all times of their life, Judgement being required. Yet the bet ervant our Saviour ever had upon Earth, was o far from neglecting or contemning Reaon, that his Epistles were admired, even by thoe that embraced not the Truthes he delivered. And indeed, had the Fathers of the Church only bid men beleeve, and not told them why, they had lept now un-Sainted in their Graves, and as much benighted with Oblivion, as the ordinary Parih-Priets of their owne Age.

That man is deceivable, is true; but what part within him is not likelyer then his Reaon? For as Manilius aid,
Nam neque decipitur ratio nec decipit unquam.

And how unlikely is it that that which gives us the Prerogative above other Creatures, and wholy entitles us to future happinee,
hould be laid aide, and not ued to the acquiring of it.

But by this time (my Lord) you finde how apt thoe which have nothing to do themelves, are to give others trouble. I hall onely therefore let you know that your Commands to my Lord of Middleex are performed; and that when you have freh ones, you cannot place them where they will be more willingly received, then by

div.head: A Dicoure by Sir John Suckling, Knight.
div.p: AMong the truths (my Lord) which we receive, none more reaonably commands our belief, then thoe which by all men, at all times have been aented to. In this number and highet I place this great one, that there is a Deity; which the whole world hath been o eager to embrace, that rather then it would have none at all, it hath too often been contented with a very mean one.

That there hould be a great Dipoer and Orderer of things, a wie Rewarder and Puniher of good and evil, hath appeared o equitable to men that by intinct they have concluded it neceary; Nature (which doth nothing in vain) having o far imprinted it in us all, that hould the envie of Predeceors deny the ecret to Succeders, they yet would find it out. Of all thoe little ladders with which we eale heaven, and climb up to our Maker, that eems to me not the wort, of which man is the firt tep. For but by examining how I, that could contribute nothing to mine owne being, hould be here, I come to ask the ame quetion for my Father, and o am led in a direct line to a lat Producer, that mut be more then man. For if man
made man, Why died not I when my Father died? ince according to that Maxime of the Philoophers, the caue taken away, the effect does not remain. Or if the firt man gave himelf being, why hath he it not till? Since it were unreaonable to imagine any thing could have power to give it elf life, that had no power to continue it. That there is then a God, will not be o much the dipute, as what this God is, or how to be worhipped, is that which hath troubled poor mortals from the firt, nor are they yet in quiet. So great has been the diverity, that ome have almot thought God was no lee delighted with variety in his ervice, then he was pleaed with it in his works. It would not be amie to take a urvey of the world from its cradle; and with Varro, divide it into three Ages: the Unknown, the Fabulous, and the Hitorical.

The firt was a black night, and dicovered nothing: the econd was a weak and glimmering light, repreenting things imperfectly and fally: the lat (more clear) left handom monuments to poterity. The unknown I place in the age before the Flood, for that Deluge wept away things as well as men, and left not o much as footteps to trace them by. The fabulous began after the Flood; in this time Godheads were cheap, & men not knowing where to chooe better, made Deities one of another. Where this ended, the hitorical took beginning: for men began to ingrave in pillars, and to commit to Letters, as it were by joynt conent: for the three great Epoches or Termes of Accompt were
all etablihed within the pace of 30. yeers: The Grecians reckoning from their Olympiades: The Romans from the building of their City: and the Babilonians from their King Salmonaar. To bring into the cale with Chritian Religion any thing out of the firt Age, we cannot; becaue we know nothing of it.

And the econd was o fabulous, that thoe which took it up afterwards, mil'd at it as ridiculous and fale (which though was eaier for them to do then to hew a true.) In the hitorical, it improved, and grew more refined: but here the Fathers entred the field, and o cleerly gained the victory, that I hould ay nothing in it, did I not know it till to be the opinion of good wits, that the particular Religion of Chritians has added little to the general Religion of the World. Let us take it then in its perfecter etate, and look upon it in that age which was made glorious by the bringing forth of o many admirable pirits, and this was about the 80. Olympiad, in the year of the world 3480. for in the pace of an 100. yeers, flourihed almot all that Greece could boat of, Socrates, Plato, Aritotle, Architas, Iocrates, Pythagoras, Epicurus, Heraclitus, Xenophon, Zeno, Anaxagoras, Democritus, Demothenes, Parmenides, Zenocrates, Theophrates, Empedocles, Tymaeus, with divers others, Orators and Poets. Or rather (for they had their Religion one from another, and not much different) let us take a view of it in that Century in which Nature (as it were to oppoe the Grecian inolence) brought forth that happy birth of Roman
wits: Varro, Cicero, Caear, Livie, Salut, Virgil, Horace, Vitruvius, Ovid, Pliny, Cato, Marcus Brutus, and this was from Quintus Servilius his Conulhip to that of Augutus, 270. yeers after the other. And to ay truth, a great part of our Religion, either directly or indirectly hath been profeed by Heathens; which I conceive not o much an exprobation to it, as a confirmation; it being no derogating from truth, to be warranted by common conent.

Firt then, the Creation of the world is delivered almot the ame in the Phoenician tories with that in Moes; from this the Grecians had their Chaos, and Ovid the beginning of his Metamorphois. That All things were made by God, was held by Plato, and others; that darknes was before light, by Thales; that the Stars were made by God, by Aratus; that life was infued into things by the breath of God, Virgil; that Man was made of dut, Heied, and Homer; that the firt life of man was in implicity and nakednes, the AEgyptians taught: and from thence the Poets had their Golden Age. That in the firt times mens lives lated a thouand yeers, Berous, and others: that omthing divine was een amongt men, till that the greatnes of our ins gave them caue to remove, Ca • u •• us: and this he that writes the tory of Columbus, reports from the Indians of a great Deluge, almot all. But to the main, they hold one God, and though multiplicity hath been laid to their charge, yet certainly the clearer pirits undertood thee petty Gods as things, not as Deities; econd caues, and everal vertues of the great power: by Neptune, water; Juno, aire; by Dipater, earth; by Vulcan, fire;
and ometimes one God ignified many things, as Jupiter the whole world, the whole heaven; and ometimes many gods, one thing, as Ceres, Juno mag • a, the earth. They concluded thoe to be vices which we do; nor was there much difference in their vertues; onely Chritians have made ready beleef the highet, which they would hardly allow to be any. They held rewards for the good, and punihments for the ill; had their Elizium, and their hell; and that they thought the pains eternal there, is evident, in that they beleev'd from thence was no return. They proportion'd ufferings hereafter, to offences here; as in Tantalus, Siyphus, and others, among which that of Concience) the worm that never dies) was one, as in the Vultures gnawing of Promotheus heart, and Virgils ugliet of Furies thundring in Pirithous ear, was not obcurely hown; and yet neerer us, they held the number of the Elect to be but mall, and that there hould be a lat day in which the World hould perih by fire. Latly they had their Priets, Temples, Altars.

We have een now the Parallel, let us enquire whether thoe things they eem to have in common with us, we have not in a more excellent manner, and whether the ret in which we differ from all the world, we take not up with reaon. To begin then with their Jupiter (for all before were but little tealthes from Moes workes) how much more like a Deity are the actions our tories declare our God to have done, then what the Ethnick Authors deliver of theirs? How excellently
elevated are our decriptions of him? Theirs looking as if they knew that power onely by their fears, as their Statues erected to him declare: for when he was Capitolinus, he appeard with thunder; when Latiaris, bemear'd with blood; when Feretrius, yet more terrible: We may ghee what their conceptions were, by the worhip they gave him: How full of cruelty were their acrifices? it being received almot through the whole world, that gods were pleaed with the blood of men: and this cutom neither the Grecian Widom, nor Roman Civility abolihed, as appears by acrifices to Bacchus.

Then the ceremonies of Liber Pater, and Ceres, how obcene? and thoe daies which were et a part for the honour of the gods, celebrated with uch hews as Cato himelf was ahamed to be preent at. On the contrary, our ervices are uch as not only Cato, but God himelf may be there: we worhip him that is the puret Spirit, in purity of pirit; and did we not beleeve what the Scriptures deliver from himfelf, yet would our reaon perwade us that uch an Eence could not be pleaed with the blood of beats, or delighted with the team of fat: and in this particular, Chritians have gone beyond all others except the Mahometans; beides whom there has been no Nation that had not acrifice, and was not guilty of this pious cruelty.

That we have the ame vertues with them is very true; but who can deny that thoe vertues have received additions from Chritianity, conducing to mens better living together? revenge of injuries
Moes both took himelf, and allowed by the Law to others; Cicero and Aritotle placed it in vertues quarter: We extol patient bearing of injuries; and what quiet the one, what trouble the other would give the world, let the indifferent judge. Their jutice only took care that men hould not do wrong: ours that they hould not think it, the very coveting everely forbidden: and this holds too in chatity, deire of a woman unlawfully being as much a breach of the commandement, as their enjoying, which hew'd not only the Chritians care, but widom to prevent ill, who provided to detroy it where it was weaket in the Cradle, and declared, He was no lee then a God which gave them thee Laws; for had he been but man, he never would have provided or taken care for what he could not look into, the hearts of Men, and what he could not punih, their thoughts. What Charity can be produced anwerable to that of Chritians? Look upon the Primitive times, and you hall find that (as if the whole World had been but a private Family) they ent from Province to Province, and from Places farre ditant, to Releeve them they never aw nor knew.

Now for the happinee which they propoed: if they take it as the Heathens undertood it, it was an Elizium, a place of bleed hades, at bet but a handom retirement from the troubles of this World: if according to the duller Jewes, Featings and Banquettings; (for it is evident
that the Sadduces, who were great oberver • of the Moaical Law, had but faint thoughts of any thing to come) there being in Moes books no promies but of Temporal bleings, and (if any) an obcure mention of eternity. The Mahometans are no lee enual, making the renewing of youth, high Feats, a woman with great eyes, and dret up with a little more fancie, the lat and bet good.

Then the hell; How gentle with the Heathens? but the rowling of a tone, filling of a ieve with water, itting before Banquets, and not daring to touch them, exerciing the trade and buinees they had on earth; with the Mahometans, but a Purgatory acted in the grave, ome pains inflicted by a bad Angel, and thoe qualified and mitigated too, by an aiting good one. Now for the Jewes, as they had no hopes, o they had no fears; o that if we conider it rightly, neither their punihments were great enough to deter them from doing ill, nor their rewards high enough to invite men to trictnes of life; for ince every man is able to make as good a heaven of his own, it were unreaonable to perwade him to quit that certain happines for an uncertainty: whereas Chritians with as much more noble conideration both in their heaven and hell took care not onely for the body but the oul, and for both above mans apprehenion.

The tranget, though mot Epidemical dieae of all Religions, has been an imagination men have had, that the impoing painful and difficult things
upon themelves, was the bet way to appeae the Deity, groly thinking the chief ervice and delight of the Creator to conit in the tortures and ufferings of the Creature. How laden with chargeable and unneceary Ceremonies the Jews were, their feats, circumciions, acrifices, great Sabbaths, and little Sabbaths, fats, burials, indeed almot all their worhip, ufficiently declare: and that the Mahometans are much more infected, appeares by the cutting of the Praepuces, wearing iron rings in the skin of their Fore parts, launcing themelves with knives, putting out their eyes upon the ight of their Prophets Tombe, and the like. Of thee lat we can hew no patterns amongt us: for though there be uch a thing as whipping of the body, yet it is but in ome parts of Chritendom, and there perchance too, more mil'd at then practis'd. Our Religion teacheth us to bear afflictions patiently when they fall upon us, but not to force them upon our elves: for we beleeve the God we erve, wie enough to chue his owne ervice, and therefore preume not to adde to his commands. With the Jews it is true we have omthing in common, but rather the names then thinges: Our Fats being more the medicines of the body, then the punihments of it, piritual, as our Sabbaths; both good mens delight, not their trouble.

But leat this dicoure hould well into a greatnee, uch as would make it look rather like a defence which I had labour'd to get, then an accompt which I alwaies carry about me; I will now briefly
examine, whether we beleeve not with reaon thoe things we have different from the ret of the world. Firt then, for the perwaion of the truth of them in general: let us conider what they were that conveigh'd them to us: men (of all the world) the mot unlikely to plot the cozenage of others, being themelves but imple people, without ends, without deignes, eeking neither honour, riches, nor pleaure, but uffering (under the contrary) ignominy, poverty, and miery; enduring death it elf, nay courting it: all which are things ditateful to nature, and uch as none, but men trangely aured, would have undergone. Had they feigned a tory, certainly they would not in it have regitred their owne faults, nor deliver'd him whom they propounded as a God, ignominiouly crucified: add to this the progree their doctrine made abroad, miraculous above all other either before or ince: other Religions were brought in with the word, power, forcing a cutom, which by degrees uurp'd the place of truth: this even power it elf oppoing. For the Romans (contrary to their cutome which entertained all Religions kindly) perecuted this: which by its owne trength o poeed the hearts of men, that no age, ex, or condition, refued to lay down life for it. A thing o rare in other Religions, that among the Heathens, Socrates was the ole martyr: and the Jews (unlee of fome few under Manaes and Antiochus) have not to boat of any. If we cat our eyes upon the healing of the blind, curing the lame, redeeming from the grave,
and but with a touch or word, we mut conclude them done by more then humane power, and if by any other, by no ill; Thee buie not themelves o much about the good of man: and this Religion not only forbids by precept the worhip of wicked pirits, but in fact detroys it whereoever it comes. Now as it is clear by Authors impartial (as being no Chritians) that trange things were done, o it is plain they were done without impoture. Deluions hun the light; Thee were all acted openly, the very enemies both of the mater and diciples daily looking on. But let us decend to thoe more principal particulars, which o much trouble the curious wits: thee I take to be the Incarnation, Pasion, Reurrection, and Trinity.

For the firt, That man hould be made without man, why hould we wonder more at it in that time of the world, then in the beginning? much eaier, certainly, it was here, becaue neerer the natural way; Woman being a more prepared matter then earth. Thoe great truths, and myteries of alvation would never have been received without miracles; and where could they more opportunely be hown, then at his entrance into the world, where they might give credit to his following actions and doctrine? So far it is from being againt my reaon to think him thus borne, that it would be againt it to beleeve him otherwie; it being not fit that the Son of God hould be produced like the race of men. That humane nature may be aumed by a Deity, the enemy of Chritians,
Julian, confirms; and intances (himelf) in AEculapius, whom he will have decend from heaven in mortal hape, to teach us here below the Art of Phyick. Latly, That God has liv'd with men, has been the general fancy of all Nations: every particular having this tradition; that the Deity at ome time or other convered amongt men. Nor is it contrary to reaon to beleeve him reiding in glory above, and yet incarnate here: So in man himelf, the oul is in heaven when it remains in the fleh, for it reacheth with its eye the Sun; why may not God then being in heaven, be at the ame time with us in the fleh? ince the oul without the body would be able to do much more then with it, and God much more then the oul, being the oul of the oul. But it may be urged as more abtrue, how all in heaven, and all in earth? Oberve man peaking (as you have done eeing) Is not the ame peech, at the intant it is uttered, all in every place? Receives not each particular ear alike, the whole? and hall not God be much more Ubiquitary then the voice of man? For the Pasion (to let alone the neceity of atisfying divine Jutice this way, which, whooever reads more particularly our Divines, hall find rationally enforced) we find: the Heathen had omething neer to this (though, as in the ret, imperfect) for they acrificed ingle men for the ins of the whole City or Countrey. Porphyrius having laid this foundation: That the upreme happines of the oul is to ee God, and that it cannot ee him unpurified, concludes, That there mut
be a way for the cleaning of Mankind; and proceeding to find it out, he tells that Arts and Sciences erve but to et our wits right in the knowledge of things, and cleane us not enough to come to God: the like judgment he gives of purging by Theurgie, and by the myteries of the Sun; becaue thoe things extend but to ome few, whereas this cleaning ought to be univeral for the benefit of all mankind: in the end reolves that this cannot be done, but by one of the three In-beings, which is the word they ue to expree the Trinity by. Let us ee what the divinet of the Heathens (and his Mater Plato) delivers, to admiration, and as it were Prophetically, to this purpoe. That a truly jut man be hewn (aith he) it is neceary that he be poil'd of his Ornaments, o that he mut be accounted by others a wicked man, be coffed at, put in prion, beaten, nay be crucified: and certainly for him that was to appear the highet example of patience, it was neceary to undergo the highet tryal of it, which was an undeerved death.

Concerning the Reurrection, I conceive the difficulty to lie not o much upon our Lord, as us; it being with eaie Reaon imagined, that he which can make a body, can lay it down, and take it up again. There is omthing more that urges and prees us: for in our etate we promie our elves hereafter, there will be no need of Food, Copulation, or Excrement, to what purpoe hould we have a mouth, belly, or lee comely parts? it being trange to imagine God to have created man, for a moment
of time, a body coniting of particulars, which hould be uelee to all eternity. Beides, Why hould we deire to carry that along with us which we are ahamed of here, and which we find o great a trouble, that very wie men (were it not forbidden) would throw it off before it were worn out? To this I hould anwer, that as the body is partner in well or ill doing, o it is but jut it hould hare in the rewards or punihments hereafter: and though by reaon of in we bluh at it here, yet when that hall ceae to be, why we hould be more ahamed then our firt Parents were, or ome in the lat dicover'd parts of the World are now, I cannot undertand. Who knowes but thee unightly parts hall remain for good ue, and that putting us in mind of our imperfect etate here, they hall erve to increae our content and happines there? What kind of thing a glorified body hall be, how chang'd, how refin'd, who knowes? Nor is it the meanet invitement to me now, to think that my etate there, is above my capacity here. There remaines that which does not onely quarrel with the likelyhood of a Reurrection, but with the poibility; alleadging, that man corrupted into dut, is cattered almot into infinite, or devoured by an irrational creature, goes into aliment, and grows part of it; then that creature perchance is made like food to another: And truly did we doubt of Gods power, or not think him omnipotent, this were a Labyrinth we hould be lot in: but it were hard, when we ee every petty Chymick
in his little hop bring into one body things of the ame kind, though catter'd and diorder'd; that we hould not allow the great Maker of all things to do the ame in his owne Univere.
There remains onely the mitery of the Trinity; to the difficulty of which, the poverty and narrownee of words have made no mall addition.

St. Autin plainly aies the word Peron was taken up by the Church for want of a better; Nature, Subtance, Eence, Hypotais, Suppoitum, and Perona, have caued harp diputes amongt the Doctors: at length they are contented to let the three firt and three lat ignifie the ame thing. By all of them is undertood omthing Compleat, Perfect, and Singular: in this onely they differ, that Nature, Subtance, Eence are communicable ad quid, and ut quo (as they call it) The other are not at all: but enough of this; Thoe that were the immediate Conveighers of it to us, wrapt it not up in any of thee terms. We then hold God to be one, and but one, it being groe to imagine two omnipotents, for then neither would be o; yet ince this good is perfectly good, and perfect goodnes cannot be without perfect love, nor perfect love without communication, nor to an unequal or created, for then it mut be inordinate; We conclude a Second Coeternal though Begotten: nor are thee contrary (though they eem to be o) even in created ubtances, that one thing may come from another, and yet that from whence it comes, not be before that which comes from it; as in the Sun and Light. But
in thee high myteries, imilitudes may be the bet Arguments. In Metaphyicks they tell us, that to the contituting of every being, there is a Poe ui ee, from whence there is a Sapientia ui ee, and from thee two proceedeth an Amor ui ee: and though thee three be ditinct, yet they make up one perfect being. Again, and more familiarly; There is a hidden Original of waters in the earth, from this a pring flows up, and of thee proceeds a tream: this is but one eence, which knows neither a before, nor an after, but in order, and (that too) according to our conidering of it: the Head of a Spring is not a Head, but in repect of the Spring; for if omthing flow'd not from it, it were no Original, Nor the Spring a Spring if it did not flow from omthing, nor the Stream a Stream but in repect of both: Now all thee three are but one Water, and though one is not the other, yet they can hardly be conidered one without the other. Now, though I know this is o far from a demontration, that it is but an imperfect intance (perfect being impoible of infinite by finite things) yet there is a reemblance great enough to let us ee the poibility. And here the eye of Reaon needed no more the pectacles of Faith, then for thee things of which we make ympathy the caue, as in the Load-tone, or antipathy, of which every man almot gives intance from his owne nature: nor is it here o great a wonder that we hould be ignorant; for this is ditant and removed from ence; thee neer and ubject to it; and
it were tranger for me to conclude that God did not work ad extra, thus one and ditinct within himelf, becaue I cannot conceive how begotten, how proceeding; then if a Clown hould ay the hand of a Watch did not move, becaue he could not give an account of the wheels within. So far is it from being unreaonable, becaue I do not undertand it, that it would be unreaonable I hould: For why hould a created ubtance comprehend an uncreated, A circumcribed and limited, an uncircumcrib'd and unlimited? And this I oberve in thoe great Lovers and Lords of Reaon, quoted by the Fathers, Zoroastres, Trimegitus, Plato, Numenius, Plotinus, Proclus, Amelius, and Avicen, that when they poke of this mytery of the Trinity, of which all writ omething, and ome almot as plainly as Chritians themelves, that they dicued it not as they did other things, but delivered them as Oracles which they had received themelves, without dipute.

Thus much of Chritian Profeion compared with others: I hould now hew which (compar'd within it elf) ought to be preferred: but this is the work of every pen, perhaps to the prejudice of Religion it elf. This excue (though) it has, that (like the chief Empire) having nothing to conquer, no other Religion to oppoe or dipute againt, it hath been forced to admit of Civil wars, and uffer under its owne excellency.
AGLAURA. PRESENTED At the Private Houe in Black-Fryers, by his Majeties Servants.
Written by Sir JOHN SVCKLING.
LONDON, Printed for Tho. Walkley, and are to be old by Humphrey Moeley, at his hop, at the igne of the Princes armes in St. Pauls Church-yard, 1646.

lg.l: I'Ve thought upon't; and cannot tell which way
Ought I can ay now, hould advance the Play.
For Playes are either good, or bad; the good,
(If they doe beg) beg to be undertood.
And in good faith, that has as bold a ound,
As if a Beggar hould aske twenty pound.
—Men have it not about them:
Then (Gentlemen) if rightly undertood,
The bad do need lee Prologue than the good:
For if it chance the Plot be lame, or blinde,
Ill cloath'd, deform'd throughout, it needs mut finde
Compaion,—It is a beggar without Art:—
But it falls out in penny-worths of Wit,
As in all bargaines ele. Men ever get
All they can in; will have London meaure,
A handfull over in their very pleaure.
And now yee have't; hee could not well deny'ee,
And I dare weare hee's carce a aver by yee.
THoe common paions, hopes, and feares, that till,
The Poets firt, and then the Prologues fill
In this our age, hee that writ this, by mee,
Protets againt as modet foolerie.
Hee thinks it an odde thing to be in paine,
For nothing ele, but to be well againe.
Who writes to feare is o; had hee not writ,
You ne're had been the Iudges of his wit;
And when hee had, did he but then intend
To pleae himelfe, he ure might have his end
Without th' expence of hope, and that he had
That made this Play, although the Play be bad.
Then Gentlemen be thriftie, ave your doomes
For the next man, or the next Play that comes;
For miles are nothing, where men doe not care,
And frownes as little, where they need not feare.
THis (Sir) to them, but unto Majetie.
All hee has aid before, hee does denie.
Yet not to Majetie: that were to bring
His feares to be, but for the Queen and King,
Not for your elves; and that hee dares not ay:
Y'are his Soveraignes another way:
Your oules are Princes, and you have as good
A title that way, as yee have by blood
To governe, and here your power's more great
And abolute, than in the royall Seat.
There men dipute, and but by Law obey,
Here is no Law at all, but what yee ay.

div.p: Scena Peria.

list.item: Therames, Prince, in love with Aglaura.
Orbella, Queen, at firt Mitree to Ziriff: in love with Ariapes.
Ziriff, Otherwayes Sorannez diguied, Captaine of the Guard, in love with Orbella, brother to Aglaura.
Iolas, A Lord of the Councell, eeming friend to the Prince, but a Traytour, in love with Semanthe.
Aglaura, In love with the Prince, but nam'd Mitree to the King.
Orames, A young Lord antiplatonique; friend to the Prince.
Semanthe, In love with Ziriff; platonique.

div.head: ACTUS I. SCENA I.

sp.speaker: Jolas,
sp.l: MArried? and in Diana's Grove!

sp.speaker: Jolin.
sp.l: So was th'appointment, or my Sene deceiv'd me.

sp.speaker: Jolas,
sp.l: Married!
Now by thoe Powers that tye thoe pretty knots,
'Tis very fine, good faith 'tis wondrous fine:

sp.speaker: Jolin.
sp.l: What is, Brother?

sp.speaker: Jolas,
sp.l: Why? to marrie Siter—
T'injoy 'twixt lawfull and unlawfull thus
A happinee, teale as 'twere ones owne;
Diana's Grove ayet thou?—Scratcheth his head.

sp.speaker: Jolin.
sp.l: That's the place; the hunt once up, and all
Ingag'd in the port, they meane to leave
The company, and teale unto thoe thickets,
Where, there's a Priet attends them;

sp.speaker: Jolas,
sp.l: And will they lye together think't thou?

sp.speaker: Jolin.
sp.l: Is there ditinction of ex thinke you?
Or fleh and bloud?

sp.speaker: Jolas,
sp.l: True; but the King, Siter!

sp.speaker: Jolin.
sp.l: But love, Brother!

sp.speaker: Jolas,
sp.l: Thou ayet well;
'Tis fine 'tis wondrous fine:
Diana's Grove—

sp.speaker: Jolin.
sp.l: Yes, Diana's grove,
But Brother if you hould peake of this now,—(o fat:

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Why thou know't a drowning man holds not a thing Semanthe! he huns me too: (Enter Semanthe he ees

sp.speaker: Jolin.
sp.l: The wound fetred ure!
The hurt the boy gave her, when firt
Shee look'd abroad into the world, is not yet cur'd.

sp.speaker: Iolas,
sp.l: What hurt?

sp.speaker: Iolin.
sp.l: Why, know you not
Shee was in love long ince with young Zorannes,
(Aglaura's brother,) and the now Queens betroth'd?

sp.speaker: Iolas,
sp.l: Some uch light Tale I'ave heard.

sp.speaker: Iolin.
sp.l: Slight? he yet does weep, when he but hears him nam'd,
And tels the prettiet, and the addet tories
Of all thoe civill wars, and thoe Amours,
That, trut me both my Lady and my elfe
Turne weeping Statues till.

sp.speaker: Iolas,
sp.l: Pih, 'tis not that.
'Tis Ziriff and his freh glories her •
Have rob'd me of her.
Since he thus appear'd in Court,
My love has languih'd wore than Plants in drought.
But time's a good Phyician: come, lets in:
The King & Queen by this time are come forth. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: 1 Serv.
sp.l: Yonder's a crowd without, as if ome trange
Sight were to be een to day here.

sp.speaker: 2 Serv.
sp.p: Two or three with Carbonadoes afore in tead of faces mitook the doore for a breach, & at the opening of it, are triving till which hould enter firt.

sp.speaker: 3 Serv.
sp.l: Is my Lord buie? (Knocks.)

div.stage: Enter Ziriff as in his Studie.

sp.speaker: 1 Serv.
sp.l: My Lord there are ome Souldiers without—

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Well I will dipatch them preently.

sp.speaker: 2 Serv.
sp.l: Th'Embaadours from the Caduians too—

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Shew them the Gallerie.

sp.speaker: 3 Serv.
sp.l: One from the King—

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Again? I come, I come. Exeunt Serving-men.
Greatnee, thou vainer hadow of the Princes beames,
Begot by meere reflection, nourih'd in extreames;
Firt taught to creepe, and live upon the glance,
Poorely to fare, till thine owne proper trength
Bring thee to urfet of thy elfe at lat.
How dull a Pageant, would this States-play eeme
To mee now; were not my love and my revenge
Mixt with it?—
Three tedious Winters have I waited here,
Like patient Chymits blowing till the coales,
And till expecting, when the bleed houre
Would com, hould make me mater of
The Court Elixar, Power, for that turnes all:
'Tis in projection now; downe, orrow, downe,
And well my heart no more, and thou wrong'd ghot
Of my dead father, to thy bed agen,
And leep ecurely;
It cannot now be long, for ure Fate mut,
As't has been cruell, o a while be jut. Exit.

div.stage: Enter King and Lords, the Lords intreating for Prioners.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I ay they hall not live; our mercie
Would turne inne, hould we but ue it er'e:
Pittie, and Love, the boes onely be
Of government meerly for how and ornament.
Feare is the bit that mans proud will retraines,
And makes its vice its vertue—See it done.
sp.stage: Enter to them Queen, Aglaura, Ladies, the King addrees himelfe to Aglaura.
sp.l: So early, and o curious in your dree, (faire Mitree?)
Thee prettie ambuhes and traps for hearts
Set with uch care to day, looke like deigne:
Speake, Lady, is't a maacre reolv'd?
Is conquering one by one growne tedious port?
Or is the number of the taken uch,
That for your afetie you mut kill out-right?

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Did none doe greater michiefe (Sir) than I,
Heav'n would not much be troubled with ad torie,
Nor would the quarrell man has to the Starres
Be kept alive o trongly.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: When hee does leave't
Woman mut take it up, and jutly too;
For robbing of the ex and giving all to you.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Their weakenees you meane and I confee Sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The greatet ubjects of their power or glorie.
Such gentle rape thou act't upon my oule,
And with uch pleaing violence dot force it till;
That when it hould reit, it tamely yeilds,
Making a kinde of hate to be undone,
As if the way to victorie were loe,
And conquet came by overthrow.

div.stage: Enter an Expree delivering a Packet upon his knee.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Prettie! The Queen looking upon a flower in one of the Ladies heads.
Is it the child of nature, or of ome faire hand?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: 'Tis as the beauty Madam of ome faces,
Arts iue onely.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Therames,
This concernes you mot, brought you her picture?

sp.speaker: Exp.
sp.l: Somthing made up for her in hat I have. (Preents

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: If he does owe no part of this faire dower (the Picture.
Vnto the Painter, he is rich enough.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: A kinde of merry adnee in this face
Becomes it much.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: There is indeed, Aglaura,
A prettie ullenee dret up in miles,
That ayes this beauty can both kill, and ave.
How like you her Therames?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: As well as any man can doe a houe
By eeing of the portall, here's but a face,
And faces (Sir) are things I have not tudied;
I have my dutie, and may boldly weare.
What you like bet will ever pleae me mot.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Spoke like Therames, and my onne,
Come! the day holds faire,
Let all the Hunt-men meet us in the vale,
We will uncouple there. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ariap.
sp.l: How odd a thing a croud is unto me!
Sure nature intended I hould be alone,
Had not that old doting man-mid-wife Time
Slept, when he hould have brought me forth I had
Been o too— Studies and Scratches his head.
To be borne nere, and onely nere a crowne—

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: How now my Lord?
What? walking o'th 'tops of Pyramids?
Whipering your elfe away
Like a deny'd lover? come! to hore, to hore,
And I will hew you treight a ight hall pleae you
More than kinde lookes from her you dote upon
After a falling out.

sp.speaker: Ariap.
sp.l: Prithee what is't?

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: Ile tell you as I goe.— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.l: Which way? which way?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: This is the grove 'tis omwhere here within.— Ex.

div.stage: Enter dogging of them, Ariapes, Jolas.

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: Gently! Gently!

div.stage: Enter Orames, Philan, a Huntman, two Courtiers.

sp.speaker: Hunts.
sp.l: No hurt, my Lord, I hope.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: None, none,
Thou wouldt have warranted it to another,
If I had broke my neck:
What? dot thinke my hore and I hew tricks?
That which way oever he throwes me
Like a tumblers boy I mut fall afe?
sp.p:
Was there a bed of roes there? would I were Eunuch
if I had not as leif h'a falne in the tate, as where I did; the ground was as hard, as if it had been pav'd with Platonicke Ladies hearts, and this unconcionable fellow askes whether I have no hurt; where's my hore.

sp.speaker: 1 Court.
sp.l: Making love to the next mare I thinke.

sp.speaker: 2 Court.
sp.l: Not the next I aure you,
Hee's gallop't away, as if all the purs ith' field
Were in his ides.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Why there's it the jades in the fahion too.
Now ha's done me an injurie, he will not come nere me.
Well when I hunt next, may it be upon a tarv'd cow,
Without a addle too.
sp.p: And may I fall into a aw-pit, and not be taken up, but with upition of having been private, with mine owne beat there. Now I better conider on't too, Gentlemen, 'tis but the ame thing we doe at Court; here's every man triving who hall be formot, and hotly puruing of what he eldome overtakes, or if he does, it's no great matter.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: He that's bet hors'd (that is bet friended) gets in oonet, and then all hee has to doe is to laugh at thoe tht are behind. Shall we helpe you my Lord?—

sp.speaker: Or • .
sp.l: Prithee doe—tay!
To be in view, is to be in favour,
Is it not?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: And he that has a trong faction againt him, hunts, upon a cold ent, and may in time come to a loe.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: Here's one rides two miles about, while another leapes a ditch and is in before him.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Where note the indirect way's the nearet.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Good againe—

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: And here's another puts on, and fals into a Quagmire, (that is) followes the Court till he has pent all (for your Court quagmire is want of money) there a man is ure to tick and then not one helps him out, if they doe not laugh at him.

sp.speaker: 1 Court.
sp.l: What think you of him, that hunts after my rate
And never ees the Deere?

sp.speaker: 2 Court.
sp.l: Why he is like ome young fellow, that follows
The Court, and never ees the King.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: To purre a hore till he is tir'd, is

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: To importune a friend till he be weary of you.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: For then upon the firt occaion y'are thrown off,
As I was now.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: This is nothing to the catching of your hore Orames.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Thou ay't true, I think he is no tranmigrated
Philoopher, & therfore not likely to be taken with morals.
Gentlemen—your help, the next I hope will be yours,
And then 'twill be my turne.— Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter againe married, Therames, Aglaura, Priet.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Feare not my Deare, if when Loves diet
Was bare lookes and thoe tolne too,
He yet did thrive! what then
Will he doe now? when every night will be
A feat, and every day freh revelrie.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Will he not urfet, when he once hall come
To groer fare (my Lord) and o grow icke,
And Love once icke, how quickly will it dye?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Ours cannot; 'tis as immortall as the things
That elemented it, which were our oules:
Nor can they ere impaire in health, for what
Thee holy rites doe warrant us to doe,
More than our bodyes would for quenching thirt
Come let's to hore, we hall be mit,
For we are envies marke, and Court eyes carry farre.
Your prayers and ilence Sir:—to the Priet. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: If it ucceed? I weare thee here my Jolas—

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: If it ucceed? will night ucceed the day?
Or houres one to another? is not his lut
The Idoll of his oule? and was not he
The Idoll of his lut? as afely he might
Have tolne the Diadem from off his head
And he would lee have mit it.
You now, my Lord, mut raie his jealouie,
Teach it to looke through the fale opticke feare,
And make it ee all double: Tell him the Prince
Would not have thus preum'd but that he does
Intend wore yet; and that his crowne and life
Will be the next attempt.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Right and I will urge
How dangerous 'tis unto the preent tate,
To have the creatures, and the followers
Of the next Prince (whom all now triue to pleae)
Too neere about him:

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: What if the male-contents that ue
To come unto him were dicovered?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: By no meanes; for 'twere in vaine to give
Him dicontent (which too mut needs be done)
If they within him gav't not nourihment.

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: Well Ile away firt, for the print's too big
If we be eene together.— Exit.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: I have o fraught this Barke with hope, that it
Dares venture now in any torme, or weather;
And if he inke or plits, all's one to me.
"Ambition eemes all things, and yet is none,
"But in diguie talkes to opinion
"And fooles it into faith, for every thing:
'Tis not with th'acending to a Throne
As 'tis with taires, and teps, that are the ame;
For to a Crowne, each humour's a degree;
And as men change, and differ, o mut wee.
The name of vertue doth the people pleae,
Not for their love to vertue, but their eae,
And Parrat Rumour I that tale have taught.
By making love I hold the womans grace,
'Tis the Court double key, and entrance gets
To all the little plots; the fierie pirits
My love to Armes hath drawne into my faction
All, but the minion of the Time, is mine,
And he hall be, or hall not be at all.
He that beholds a wing in pieces torne,
And knows not that to heav'n it once did beare
The high-flowne and elfe-les'ning bird will thinke
And call them idle Subjects of the winde:
When he that has the skill to imp and binde
Thee in right places, will thus truth dicover;
That borrowed Intruments doe oft convey
The Soule to her propos'd Intents, and where
Our Stars deny Art may upply— Exit.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: Thinke you it is not then
The little jealouies (my Lord) and feares,
Joy mixt with doubt, and doubt reviv'd with hope
That crownes all love with pleaure? thee are lot
When once we come to full fruition;
Like waking in the morning, when all night
Our fancie has been fed with ome new trange delight.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: I grant you, Madam, that the feares, and joyes,
Hopes, and deires, mixt with depaires, and doubts,
Doe make the port in love; that they are
The very dogs by which we hunt the Hare;
But as the dogs would top and traight give o're
Were it not for the little thing before;
So would our paions; both alike mut be
Fleht in the chae.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Will you then place the happinee, but there,
Where the dull plow-man, and the plow-mans hore
Can find it out? Shall Soules refin'd, not know
How to preerve alive a noble flame,
But let it die, burne out to appetite?

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: Love's a Chamelion and would live on aire,
Phyick for Agues, tarving is his food.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Why? there's it now! a greater Epicure
Lives not on earth? my Lord and I have been
In's Privie kitchin, een his bills of Fare.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: And how, and how my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: A mightie Prince,
And full of curioitie—Harts newly laine
Serv'd up intire, and tucke with little Arrowes
In tead of Cloaves—

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Sometimes a cheeke plumpt up
With broth, with creame and claret mingled
For auce, and round about the dih
Pomegranate kernells, trew'd on leaves of Lillies.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Then will he have black eyes, for thoe of late
He feeds on much, and for varietie
The gray—

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: You forget his cover'd dihes
Of Jene-trayes, and Marmalade of Lips,
Perfum'd by breath weet as the beanes firt bloomes.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: Rare!
And what's the drinke to all this meat, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Nothing but pearle diolv'd, teares till freh fetch'd
From Lovers eyes, which if they come to be
Warme in the carriage, are treight cool'd with ighs.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: And all this rich proportion, perchance
We Would allow him:

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: True! but therefore this is but his common diet;
Onely erves
When his chiefe Cookes, Liking and Opportunitie,
Are out o'th' way; for when hee feats indeed,
'Tis there, where the wie people of the world
Did place the vertues, i'th' middle—Madam.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: My Lord there is o little hope we hould co¯vert you;
And if we hould, o little got by it,
That weell not looe o much upon't as leepe.
Your Lordhips ervants—

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Nay Ladies weell wait upon you to your chambers.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Prithee lets pare the complement, we hall doe no good

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: By this hand Ile try,
They keepe me fating and I mut be praying. Exeunt.

div.stage: Aglaura undreing of her elfe, Jolina.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Undree mee:—
Is it not late, Iolina?
It was the longet day, this—

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Softly, as Death it elfe comes on,
When it does teale away the icke mans breath,
And tanders by perceive it not
Have I trod, the way unto thee lodgings.
How wiely doe thoe Powers
That give us happinee, order it?
Sending us till feares to bound our joyes,
Which ele would over-flow and loe themelves:
See where hee its,
Like day retir'd into another world.
Deare mine! where all the beautie man admires
In cattered pieces does united lye.
Where ene does feat and yet where weet deire
Lives in its longing like a Miers eye,
That never knew, nor • aw acietie:
Tell me by what approaches mut I come
To take in what remaines of my felicitie?

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Needs there any new ones, where the breach
Is made already? you are entred here—
Long ince (Sir) here and I have giv'n up all.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: All but the Fort and in uch wars, as thee,
Till that be yeilded up there is no peace,
Nor triumph to be made; come undoe, undoe,
And from thee envious clouds lide quicke
Into Loves proper Sphere, thy bed:
The wearie traveller whom the buie Sunne
Hath vex't all day, and cortchd almot to tinder.
Nere long'd for night as I have longd for this.
What rude hand is that? One knockes hatily.
Goe Iolina, ee but let none enter— Iolina goes to the doore

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: 'Tis Zeriff, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: —Oh—
Something of weight hath falne out it eemes,
Which in his zeale he could not keepe till morning.
But one hort minute, Deare, into that chamber.—
How now?
Thou tart't, as if thy innes had met thee,
Or thy Fathers ghot; what newes man?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Such as will end the blood of hatie meages
Unto the heart, and make it call
All that is man about you into councell?
Where's the Princee, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Why? what of her?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: The King mut have her—

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: The King mut have her (Sir)

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Though feare of wore makes ill, till relih better
And this looke handome in our friendhip, Ziriff,
Yet o evere a preparation—
There needed not: come, come! what it?
sp.stage: Ziriff leads him to the doore, and hewes him a Guard.
sp.l: A Guard! Therames,
Thou art lot; betray'd
By faithlee and ungratefull man,
Out of a happinee:— He teps between the doore and him and drawes.
The very thought of that,
Will lend my anger o much noble jutice,
That wert thou mater of as much freh life,
As th'at been of villany, it hould not erve,
Nor tocke thee out, to glorie, or repent
The leat of it.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Put up: put up! uch unbecomming anger
I have not eene you weare before.
What? draw upon your friend, Dicovers himelfe.
Doe you beleeve me right now?—

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: I carce beleeve mine eyes:— Zorannes.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: The ame, but how preerv'd, or why
Thus long diguis'd to you a freer houre mut peake:
That y'are betrai'd is certaine, but by whom,
Unlee the Priet himelfe, I cannot ghee
More than the marriage, though he knowes not of:
If you now end her on thee early ummons
Before the parks are growne into a flame,
You to redeeme th'offence, or make it lee;
And (on my life) yet his intents are faire,
And he will but beiege, not force affection.
So you gaine time; if you refue, there's but
One way; you know his power and paion.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Into how trange a labyrinth am I
Now falne! what hall I doe Zorannes?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Doe (Sir) as Sea-men, that have lot their light
And way: trike aile, and lye quiet a while.
Your forces in the Province are not yet
In readinee, nor is our friend Zephines
Arriv'd at Delphos; nothing is ripe, beides—

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Good heavens, did I but dreame that he was mine?
Upon imagination did I climbe up to
This height? let mee then wake and dye,
Some courteous hand natch mee from what's to come,
And ere my wrongs have being give them end:

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: How poore, and how unlike the Prince is this?
This trifle woman does unman us all;
Robs us o much, it makes us things of pittie.
Is this a time to looe our anger in?
And vainly breathe it out? when all wee have
Will hardly fill the aile of Reolution,
And make us beare up high enough for action.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: I have done (Sir) pray chide no more;
The lave whom tedious cutome has enur'd
And taught to thinke of mierie as of food,
Counting it but a necearie of life,
And o digeting it, hall not o much as once
Be nam'd to patience when I am poken of:
Marke mee; for I will now undoe my elfe
As willingly, as virgins give up all firt nights
To them they love:— Offers to goe out.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Stay, Sir, 'twere fit Auglara yet were kept
In ignorance: I will dimie the Guard,
And be my elfe againe. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: In how much wore etate am I in now,
Than if I neare had knowne her; privation,
Is a mierie as much above bare wretchednee,
As that is hort of happinee:
So when the Sunne does not appeare,
'Tis darker, caue it once was here.

div.stage: Enter Ziriff peakes to Orames and others halfe entred.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Nay, Gentlemen:
There needs no force, where there is no reitance:
Ile atisfie the King my elfe.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: —Oh 'tis well y'are come,
There was within me freh Rebellion,
And reaon was almot unking'd agen.
But you hall have her Sir— Goes out to fetch Aglaura.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: What doubtfull combats in this noble youth
Paion and reaon have!—

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Here Sir— Gives her, goes out.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: What meanes the Prince, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Madam, his wier feare has taught him to diguie
His love, and make it looke a little rude at parting.
Affaires that doe concerne all that you hope from
Happinee, this night force him away:
And let you hould have tempted him to tay,
(Which hee did doubt you would and would prevaile)
He left you thus: he does deire by mee
You would this night lodge in the little tower,
Which is in my command the reaons why
Himelfe will hortly tell you.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: 'Tis trange, but I am all obedience— Exeunt.

div.head: ACTUS II. SCENA I.
div.stage: Enter Therames, Jolas a Lord of the Counell

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: I Told him o, Sir, urg'd 'twas no common kn •
That to the tying of it two powerfull Princes,
Vertue and Love were joyn'd and that
A greater than thee two was now
Ingaged in it Religion; but 'twould, not doe,
The corke of paion boy'd up all reaon o
That what was aid wam but o'thtop of th'eare
Nere reach't the heart:

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Is there no way for Kings to hew their power,
But in their Subjects wrongs? no ubject neither
But his owne onne?

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: Right Sir:
No quarrie for his lut to gorge on, but on what
You fairly had flowne at and taken:
Well—wert not the King, or wert indeed
Not you that have uch hopes, and uch a crowne
To venter, and yet—
'Tis but a woman.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: How? that but againe and thou art more enjurious
Than hee, and woul't provoke me ooner.

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: Why Sir?
There are no Altars yet addret unto her,
Nor acrifice; if I have made her lee
Than what he is, it was my love to you:
For in my thoughts, and here within, I hold her
The Noblet peece Nature ere lent our eyes,
And of the which all women ele, are but
Weake counterfeits, made up by her journey-men
But was this fit to tell you?
I know you value but too high all that,
And in a loe we hould not make things more,
'Tis mieries happinee, that wee can make it lee
By art, through a forgetfulnee upon our ils,
Yet who can doe it here?
When every voyce, mut needs, and every face,
By hewing what he was not, hew what he was.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Ile intantly unto him— drawes.

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: Stay Sir:
Though't be the utmot of my Fortunes hope
To have an equall hare of ill with you:
Yet I could wih we old this trifle life,
At a farre dearer rate, then we are like to doe,
Since 'tis a King's the Merchant.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Ha!
King, I! tis indeed.
And there's no Art can canncell that high bond:

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: —He cooles againe.— (to himelfe.)
True Sir, and yet mee thinkes to know a reaon—
For paive nature nere had glorious end,
And he that States preventions ever learn'd,
Knowes, 'tis one motion to trike and to defend.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Some of the Lords without, and from the King,
They ay, wait you.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: What ubtle State tricke now?
But one turne here, and I am back my Lord.— Exit.

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: This will not doe; his reolution's like.
A kilfull hore-man and reaon is the tirrop,
Which though a udden hock may make
It looe yet does it meet it handomly agen.
Stay, 'tmut be ome udden feare of wrong
To her, that may draw on a udden act
From him and ruine from the King; for uth
A pirit will not like common ones, be
Rais'd by every pell, 'tis in loves circle
Onely 'twill appeare.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.l: I cannot beare the burthen of my wrongs
One minute longer.

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: Why! what's the matter Sir?

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.l: They doe pretend the afety of the State
Now, nothing but my marriage with Caduia
Can ecure th'adjoyning countrey to it;
Confinement during life for me if I refue
Diana's Nunnerie for her—And at that Nunn'rie, Iolas
Allegiance in me like the tring of a Watch
Wound up too high and forc'd above the nicke,
Ran back, and in a moment was unravell'd all.

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: Now by the love I beare to Jutice,
That Nunn'rie was too evere; when vertuous love's a crime
What man can hope to cape a punihment,
Or who's indeed o wretched to deire it?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Right!

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: What anwer made you, Sir!

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: None, they gave me till to morrow,
And e're that be, or they or I
Mut know our detinie:
Come friend let's in there is no leeping now;
For time is hort, and we have much to doe.— Exeunt

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Judge you, Gentlemen, if I be not as unfortunate
As a gameter thinks himelfe upon the loe
Of the lat take; this is the firt he
I ever wore too heartily and (by thoe eyes)
I thinke I had continued unperjur'd a whole moneth,
(And that's faire you'll ay.)

sp.speaker: 1 Court.
sp.l: Very faire—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Had he not run mad betwixt.—

sp.speaker: 2 Court.
sp.l: How? mad?
Who? Semanthe?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Yea, yea, mad, aske Philan ele.
People that want cleere intervalls talke not
So wildly: Ile tell you Gallants 'tis now, ince firt I
Found my elfe a little hot and quivering 'bout the heart,
Some ten dayes ince, (a tedious Ague) Sirs;
(But what of that?)
The gracious glance, and little whiper pat,
Approches made from th'hand unto the lip.
I came to viit her, and (as you know we ue)
Breathing a igh or two by way of prologue,
Told her, that in Loves Phyicke 'twas a rule,
Where the dieae had birth to eeke a cure;
It had no ooner nam'd love to her, but he
