Began to talke of Flames, and Flames,
Neither devouring, nor devour'd, of Aire,
And of Camelions—

sp.speaker: 1 Court.
sp.l: Oh the Platoniques.

sp.speaker: 2 Court.
sp.l: Thoe of the new religion in love! your Lordhip's merrie,
Troth how doe you like the humor on't?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: As thou wouldt like red haire, or leannee
In thy Mitree; curvily, 't does wore with handomnee,
Than trong deire would doe with impotence;
A meere tricke to inhance the price of kies—

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Sure thee illy women, when they feed
Our expectation o high, doe but like
Ignorant Conjurers, that raie a Spirit
Which handomly they cannot lay againe:

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: True, 'tis like ome that nourih up
Young Lions till they grow o great they are affraid of
Themelves, they dare not grant at lat,
For feare they hou d not atisfie.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Who's for the Town? I mut take up againe,

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: This villanous Love's as changeable as the Philoophers Stone and thy Mitree as hard to compae too!

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: The Platonique is ever o; they are as tedious
Before they come to the point, as an old man
Fall'n into the Stories of his youth;

sp.speaker: 2 Cour.
sp.l: Or a widow into the praies of her firt huband,

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Well if he hold out but one moneth longer,
If I doe not quite forget, I ere beleaguer'd there,
And remove the iege to another place, may all
The cures beguil'd virgins loe upon their perjur'd lovers
Fall upon mee.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: And thou woult deerve'em all.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: For being in the company of thoe
That tooke away the Prince's Mitree from him.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Peace, that will be redeem'd—
I put but on this wildnee to diguie my elfe;
There are brave things in hand, heark i'thy ear • :— (Whiper)

sp.speaker: 1. Court.
sp.l: Some evere plot upon a maiden-head.
Thee two young Lords make love,
As Embroyderers work againt a Mask, night and day;
They think importunity a neerer way then merit,
And take women as Schoole-boyes catch Squirrells.
Hunt 'em up and downe till they are wearie,
And fall downe before'm.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Who loves the Prince failes not—

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: And I am one: my injuries are great as thine,
And doe perwade as trongly.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: I had command to bring thee,
Faile not and in thine owne diguie,

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Why in diguie?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: It is the Princes policie and love;
For if we hould micarrie,
Some one taken might betray the ret
Unknowne to one another,
Each man is afe, in his owne valour;

sp.speaker: 2 Court.
sp.l: And what Mercers wife are you to cheapen now
In tead of his ilks?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Troth; 'tis not o well; 'tis but a Cozen of thine—
Come Philan let's along:— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: What is it thus within whipering remore,
And calls Love Tyrant? all powers, but his,
Their rigour, and our feare, have made divine!
But every Creature holds of him by ene,
The weetet Tenure; yea! but my husbands brother:
And what of that? doe harmlee birds or beats
Aske leave of curious Heraldrie at all?
Does not the wombe of one faire pring,
Bring unto the earth many weet rivers,
That wantonly doe one another chace
And in one bed, kie, mingle, and embrace?
Man (Natures heire) is not by her wi • l ti'de,
To hun all creatures are alli'd unto him
For then hee hould hun all; ince death and life
Doubly allies all them that live by breath:
The Aire that does impart to all lifes brood,
Refrehing, is o neere to it elfe, and to us all,
That all in all is individuall:
But, how am I ure one and the ame deire
Warmes Ariapes: for Art can keepe alive
A beddred love.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Alone, (Madam) and overcat with thought,
Uncloud—uncloud—for if wee may believe
The miles of Fortune, love hall no longer pine
In prion thus, nor undelivered travel •
With throes of feare, and of deire about it.
The Prince, (like to a valiant beat in nets)
Striving to force a freedome uddenly,
Has made himelfe at length, the urer prey:
The King tands only now betwixt, and is,
Jut like a ingle tree, that hinders all the propect:
'Tis but the cutting downe of him, and wee—

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Why would't thou thus imbarque into trange eas,
And trouble Fate, for what we have already?
Thou art to mee what thou now eek't a Kingdome;
And were thy love as great, as thy ambition;
I hould be o to thee.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Thinke you, you are not Madam?
As well and jutly may you doubt the truths,
Tortur'd, or dying men doe leave behind them:
But then my fortune turnes my mieri • ,
When my addition hall but make you lee;
Shall I indure that head that wore a crowne,
For my ake hould weare none? Firt let me loe
Th' Exchequer of my wealth, your love; nay, may
All that rich Treaurie you have about you.
Be rifled by the man I hated, and I looke on;
Though youth be full of inne, and heav'n be jut,
So ad a doome I hope they keepe not from me;
Remember what a quicke Apotacie he made,
When all his vowes were up to heav'n and you.
How, e're the Bridall torches were burnt out,
His flames grew weake, and icklier; thinke on that,
Thinke how unafe you are, if he hould now,
Not ell her honour at a lower rate,
Than your place in his bed.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: And would not you prove fale too then?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: By this—and this—loves break-fat: (Kies her.)
By his feats too yet to come, by all the
Beauty in this face, divinitie too great
To be prophan'd—

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: O doe not weare by that;
Cankers may eat that flow'r upon the talke,
(For icknee and michance, are great devourers)
And when there is not in thee cheeks and lips,
Left red enough to bluh at perjurie,
When you hall make it, what hall I doe then?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Our oules by that time (Madam)
Will by long • utome o acquainted be,
They will not need that duller truch-man Fleh,
But freely, and without thoe poorer helps,
Convere and mingle; meane time wee'll teach
Our loves to peake, not thus to live by ignes,
And action is his native language, Madam,
This box but open'd to the Sene will doe't.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: I undertake I know not what,

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Thine own afety (Dearet)
Let it be this night, if thou do't; Whiper and kie.
Love thy elfe or mee.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: That's very udden

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Not if wee be o, and we mut now be wie,
For when their Sun ets, ours begins to rie.— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Then all my feares are true, and he is fale;
Fale as a falling Star, or Glow-wormes fire:
This Devill Beauty is compounded trangely,
It is a ubtill point, and hard to know,
Whether 't has in't more active tempting,
Or more paive tempted; o oone it forces,
And o oone it yeelds—
Good Gods! hee eiz'd my heart, as if from you
Sh'ad had Commiion to have us'd me o;
And all mankinde beides—and ee, if the jut Ocean
Makes more hate to pay
To needy rivers, what it borrow'd firt,
Then hee to give, where he ne're tooke;
Mee thinks I feele anger, Revenges Harbenger
Chalking up all within, and thruting out
Of doores, the tame and ofter paions;—
It mut be o:
To love is noble frailtie, but poore in
When we fall once to Love, unlov'd agen. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: 'Twere fit your Jutice did conider, (Sir)
What way it tooke; if you hould apprehend
The Prince for Treaon (which he never did)
And which, unacted, is unborn; (at leat will be beleev'd o)
Lookers on, and the loud talking croud,
Will thinke it all but water colours
Laid on for a time,
And which wip'd off, each common eye would ee,
Strange ends through tranger wayes:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Think't thou I will compound with Treaon then?
And make one feare anothers Advocate?

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: Vertue forbid Sir, but if you would permit,
Them to approch the roome (yet who would advie
Treaon hould come o neere?) there would be then
No place left for excue.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How trong are they?

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: Weake, conidering
The enterprize; they are but few in number,
And thoe few too having nothing but
Their reolutions coniderable about them.
A Troope indeed deign'd to uffer what
They come to execute.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Who are they are thus wearie of their lives?

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Their names I cannot give you.
For thoe he ent for, he did till receive
At a back doore, and o dimit them too.
But I doe thinke Ziriff is one.—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Take heed! I hall upect thy hate to others,
Not thy love to me, begot this ervice;
This Treaon thou thy elfe do't ay
Has but an houres age, and I can give accompt
Of him, beyond that time.—Brother, in the little Tower
Where now Agla • ra's prioner,
You hall find him; bring him along,
Hee yet doth tand untainted in my thoughts,
And to preerve him o,
Hee hall not tirre out of my eyes command
Till this great cloud be over.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Sir, 'twas the Prince who firt—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I know all that! urge it no more!
I love the man;
And 'tis with paine, wee doe upect,
Where wee doe not dilike:
Th'art ure hee will have ome,
And that they will come to night?

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: As ure as night will come it elfe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Get all your Guards in readines, we wil our elfe
Dipere them afterwards; and both be ure
To weare your thoughts within: Ile act the ret: Exeunt.

sp.speaker: 2. Court.
sp.l: Well.—If there be not ome great torme towards,
Ne're trut mee; Whiper (Court thunder) is in
Every corner, and there has been to day
About the Towne a murmuring
And buzzing, uch as men ue to make,
When they doe feare to vent their feares;

sp.speaker: 1. Court.
sp.l: True, and all the State-men hang downe their heads,
Like full ear'd corne; two of them
Where I up't, askt what time of night it was,
And when 'twas told them, tarted, as if
They had been to run a race.

sp.speaker: 2. Court.
sp.l: The King too (if you mark him,) doth faigne mirth
And jollitie, but through them both,
Flahes of dicontent, and anger make ecapes:

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Gentlemen! 'tis pitty heav'n
Deign'd you not to make the Almanacks.
You ghee o hrewdly by the ill apects,
Or neere conjunctions of the great ones,
At what's to come till; that without all doubt
The Countrey had beene govern'd wholly by you,
And plow'd and reap'd accordingly; for mee,
I undertand this myterie as little
As the new Love, and as I take it too,
'Tis much about the Time that every thing
But Owles, and Lovers take their ret;
Good night, Philan—away— Exit.

sp.speaker: 1. Court.
sp.l: 'Tis early yet; let's goe on the Queens ide
And foole a little; I love to warme my elfe
Before I goe to bed, it does beget
Handome and prightly thoughts, and makes
Our dreames halfe olid pleaures.

sp.speaker: 2. Court.
sp.l: Agreed: agreed: Exeunt.

div.head: ACTUS III. SCENA I.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: COuldt thou not find cut Ziriff?

sp.speaker: 1. Court.
sp.l: Not peake with him my Lord;
Yet I ent in by everall men.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: I wonder Jolas meets us not here too.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: 'Tis trange, but let's on now how ere,
When Fortunes, honour, life, and all's in doubt
Bravely to dare, is bravely to get out.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Betrai'd! betraid!

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Shift for your elfe Sir, and let us alone,
Wee will ecure your way, and make our own. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Follow Lords, and ee quick execution done,
Leave not a man alive.
Who treads on fire, and does not put it out,
Diperes feare in many parks of doubt. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Conpirators, and the Guard upon them.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Stand friends, an equall party— (Fight.) Three of the Conpirators fall, & three of the Kings ide: Orames & Philan kil the ret. They throw of their diguies.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Brave Orames, 'tis pleaure to die neer thee.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Talke not of dying Philan, we will live,
And erve the noble Prince agen; we are alone,
Off then with thy diguie, & throw it in the buhes;
Quick, quick; befor the torrent comes upon us:
We hal be treight good ubjects, & I depair not
Of reward for this nights ervice: o.—
Wee two now kill'd our friends! 'tis hard,
But 'tmut be o.

div.stage: Enter Ariapes, Jolas, two Courtiers, part of the Guard.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Follow! Follow!

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Yes; o you may now, y'are not likely to overtake.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Orames, and Philan, how came you hither?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: The neeret way it eems, you follow'd (thank you)
As i • 'thad been through quickets:

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: 'Sdeath have they all ecap'd?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Not all, two of them we made ure;
But they cot deare, looke here ele.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Is the Prince there?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: They are both Princes I thinke,
They fought like Princes I am ure. Jolas pulls off the vizors.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Stephines, and Odîris—we trifle.
Which way tooke the ret?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Two of them are certainly here abouts.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Upon my life they wam the river;
Some treight to hore, and follow o're the bridge;
You and I my Lord will earch this place a little better.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Your Highnee will I hope remember, who were
The men were in—

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Oh! fear not, your Mitree hall know y'are valiant.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Philan! if thou lov't me, let's kill them upon the place.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Fie: thou now art wild indeed;
Thou taught't me to be wie firt,
And I will now keep thee o.—Follow, follow. Exeunt.

div.stage: The Prince comes and knocks within.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Madam!

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: What wretch is this that thus uurps
Upon the priviledge of Ghots, and walks
At mid-night?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Aglaura.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Betray me not
My willing ene too oone, yet if that voyce
Be fale.—

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Open faire Saint, and let me in.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: It is the Prince—
As willingly as thoe
That cannot leep do light; welcome (Sir,) (Opens.)
Welcome above.— Spies his word drawne.
Blee me, what means this unheath'd miniter of death?
If, Sir, on mee quick Jutice be to pae,
Why this? abence alas, or uch trange lookes
As you now bring with you would kill as oone:

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Softly! for I, like a hard hunted Deere,
Have only hearded here; and though the crie
Reach not our eares, yet am I follow'd cloe:
O my heart! ince I aw thee,
Time has been trangely Active, and begot
A Montrous iue of unheard of Storie:
Sit; thou halt have it all! nay, igh not.
Such blats will hinder all the paage;
Do't thou remember, how wee parted lat?

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Can I forget it Sir?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: That word of parting was ill plac'd, I weare,
It may be ominous; but do't thou know
Into whoe hands I gave thee?

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Yes into Ziriffs Sir.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: That Ziriff was thy brother, brave Zorannes
Preerv'd by miracle in that ad day
Thy father fell, and ince thus in diguie,
Waiting his jut revenge.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: You doe amaze me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: And mut doe more, when I tell all the torie.
The King, the jealous King, knew of the marriage,
And when thou thought't thy elfe by my direction,
Thou wert his Prioner;
Unlee I would renounce all right,
And ceae to love thee, (ô trange, and fond requet!)
Immur'd thou mut have been in ome ad place,
And lockt for ever, from Therames ight.
For ever—and that unable to indure
This night, I did attempt his life.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Was it well done Sir?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: O no! extremely ill!
For to attempt and not to act was poore:
Here the dead-doing Law, (like ill-paid Souldiers)
Leaves the ide 'twas on, to joyne with power,
Royall villany now will looke o like to Jutice,
That the times to come, and curious poteritie,
Will find no difference: weep't thou Aglaura?
Come, to bed my Love!
And wee will there mock Tyrannie, and Fate,
Thoe ofter houres of pleaure, and delight,
That like o many ingle Pearles, hould have
Adorn'd our thread of life, wee will at once,
By Loves myterious power, and this nights help
Contract to one, and make but one rich draught
Of all.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: What meane you Sir?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: To make my elfe incapable of mierie,
By taking trong preervative of happinee:
I would this night injoy thee:

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Doe: Sir, doe what you will with mee,
For I am too much yours, to deny the right
How ever claim'd—but—

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: But what Aglaura?

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Gather not rees in a wet and frowning houre,
They'll loe their weets then, trut me they will Sir.
What pleaure can Love take to play his game out,
When death mut keep the Stakes— A noie without.
Hark Sir—grave-bringers, and lat minutes are at hand,
Hide hide your elfe, for Loves ake hide your elfe.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: As oon the Sunne may hide himelfe, as I.
The Prince of Peria hide himelfe?

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: O talke not Sir; the Sunne does hide himelfe then;
When night and blacknee comes—

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Never weet Ignorance, he hines in th'other world
And o hall I, if I et here in glorie:
Enter Opens the doore. enter Ziriff.
Yee hatie eekers of life.
Sorannez.—

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: My brother!
If all the joy within mee come not cut,
To give a welcome to o deare an object,
Excue it Sir; orrow locks up all doores.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: If there be uch a Toy about you, Siter,
Keep't for your elfe, or lend it to the Prince;
There is a dearth of that Commoditie,
And you have made it Sir. Now?
What is the next mad thing you meane to doe?
Will you tay here? when all the Court's beet
Like to a wood at a great hunt and buie michiefe hates
To be in view, and have you in her power—

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: To mee all this—
For great griefe's deafe as well as it is dumbe,
And drives no trade at all with Counell: (Sir)
Why doe you not Tutor one that has the Plague,
And ee if he will feare an after ague it;
Such is all michiefe now to me; there is none left
Is worth a thought. death is the wort, I know,
And that compar'd to hame, does look more lovely now
Than a chate Mitree, et by common woman—
And I mut court it Sir?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: No wonder if that heav'n forake us, when we leave our elves:
What is there done hould feed uch high depaire?
Were you but afe—

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Deare (Sir) be rul'd,
If love, be love, and magick too,
(As ure it is where it is true;)
Wee then hall meet in abence, and in pight
Of all divorce, freely enjoy together,
What niggard Fate thus peevihly denies.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Yea: but if pleaures be themelves but dreames,
What then are the dreames of thee to men?
That monter, Expectation, will devoure
All that is within our hope or power,
And e're we once can come to hew, how rich
We are, we hall be poore,
Shall we not Sorannez?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: I undertand not this,
In times of envious penurie (uch as thee are)
To keepe but love alive is faire, we hould not thinke
Of feating him: come (Sir)
Here in thee lodgings is a little doore,
That leads unto another; that againe,
Unto a vault that has his paage under
The little river opening into the wood;
From thence 'tis but ome few minutes eaie buinee
Unto a Servants houe of mine (who for his faith
And honetie, hereafter mut
Looke big in Storie) there you are afe however;
And when this Storme has met a little calme,
What wild deire dares whiper to it elfe,
You may enjoy, and at the wort may teale:

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: What hall become of thee Aglaura then?
Shall I leave thee their rages acrifice?
And like dull Seamen threatned with a torme,
Throw all away, I have to ave my elfe?

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Can I be afe when you are not? my Lord?
Knowes love in us divided happinee?
Am I the afer for your being here?
Can you give that you have not for your elfe?
My innocence is my bet guard and that your tay
Betraying it unto upition takes away.
If you did love mee?—

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Grows that in quetion? then 'tis time to part:— Kies her.
When we hall meet again Heav'n onely knowes,
And when wee hall, I know we hall be old:
Love does not calculate the common way,
Minutes are houres there, and the houres are dayes,
Each day's a yeare and every yeare an age;
What will this come to thinke you?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Would this were all the ill,
For thee are pretty little harmlee nothings;
Times hore runs full as fat, hard borne and curb'd,
As in his full carreere, looe-rain'd and purr'd:
Come, come, let's away.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Happinee, uch as men lot in mierie
Would wrong in naming, 'tis o much above them.
A • l that I want of it, all you deerve,
Heav'n end you in my abence.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: And mierie uch as wittie malice would
Lay out in cures, on the thing it hates,
Heav'n end me in the tead if when y'are gone
I welcome it, but for your ake alone.— Exeunt. Leads him out, & enters up out of the vault.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Stir not from hence, Sir, til you hear from me
So goodnight deare Prince.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Goodnight deere friend.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: When we meet next all this will but advance—
Joy never feats o high,
As when the firt coure is of mierie. Exeunt.

div.head: ACTUS IV. SCENA I.

sp.speaker: 1 Court.
sp.l: BY this light—a brave Prince,
He made no more of the Guard, than they
Would of a Taylor on a Maske night, that has refus'd
Truting before.

sp.speaker: 2 Court.
sp.l: Hee's as Active as he is valiant too;
Did't mark him how he tood like all the points
O'th' Compae, and as good Pictures,
Had his eyes, towards every man.

sp.speaker: 3 Court.
sp.l: And his word too,
All th'other ide walk up and down the Court now,
As if they had lot their way, and tare,
Like Grey-hounds, when the Hare has taken the furze.

sp.speaker: 1 Court.
sp.l: Right.
And have more troubles about'em
Than a Serving-man that has forgot his meage
When he's come upon the place.—

sp.speaker: 2 Court.
sp.l: Yonder's the King within chafing, & wearing
Like an old Falconer upon the firt flight
Of a young Hawke, when ome Clowne
Has taken away the quarrie from her;
And all the Lords tand round about him,
As if he were to be baited, with much more feare,
And at much more ditance,
Than a Countrey Gentlewoman ees the Lions the firt time:
Look: he's broke looe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Find him; or by Oiris elfe, you all are Traitours;
And equally hall pay to Jutice; a ingle man,
And guiltie too, breake through you all!

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Confidence!
(Thou paint of women, and the State-mans widome,
Valour for Cowards, and of the guilties Innocence,)
Ait me now.
Sir, end thee Starers off:
I have ome buinee will deerve your privacie.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Leave us.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: How the villaine wells upon us?— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Not to punih thought,
Or keepe it long upon the wrack of doubt,
Know Sir,
That by corruption of the waiting woman,
The common key of ecrets, I have found
The truth at lat, and have dicover'd all:
The Prince your Sonne was by Aglaura's meanes,
Convey'd lat night unto the Cypree Grove,
Through a cloe vault that opens in the lodgings:
Hee does intend to joyne with Carimania,
But e're he goes, reolves to finih all
The rites of Love, and this night meanes
To teale what is behind.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How good is Heav'n unto mee!
That when it gave me Traitours for my Subjects,
Would lend me uch a Servant!

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: How jut (Sir) rather,
That would betow this Fortune on the poore.
And where your bountie had made debt o infinite
That it grew de • erate, their hope to pay it—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Enoug • of that, thou do't but gently chide
Me for a fault, hat I wîll mend; for I
Have been toopoore, and low in my rewards
The quetio • is, whether we hall rely
Upon our Guards agen?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: • y no meanes Sir:
Hope <> his future fortunes, or their Love
Unto his peron, has o icklied o're
Their reolutions, that we mut not trut them,
Beides, it were but needlee here
Hee paes through the vault alone, and I
My elfe durt undertake that buinee,
If that were all, but there is omething ele,
This accident doth prompt my zeale to erve you in.
I know you love Aglaura (Sir) with paion,
And would enjoy her; I know beides
Shee loves him o that whooe're hall bring
The tidings of his death, mut carrie back
The newes of hers, o that your Jutice (Sir)
Mut rob your hope: but there is yet a way—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Here! take my heart; for I have hitherto
Too vainly pent the treaure of my love,
I'le have it coyn'd treight into friendhip all,
And make a preent to thee.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: If any part of this rich happinee.
(Fortune prepares now for you) hall owe it elfe
Unto my weake endeavours, I have enough,
Aglaura without doubt this night expects
The Prince, and why
You hould not then upply his place by tealth,
And in diguie—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I apprehend thee Ziriff,
But there's difficultie—

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Who trades in love mut be an adventurer, (Sir)
But here is carce enough to make the pleaure dearer:
I know the Cave; your Brother and my elfe
With Iolas, (for thoe w'are ure doe hae him,)
With ome few choen more betimes wll wait
The Princes paing through the vault; i • hee
Comes firt, hee's dead; and if it be yourelfe,
Wee will conduct you to the chamber door •
And tand 'twixt you and danger afterwards.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I have conceiv'd of joy, and am grown • reat:
Till I have afe deliverance, time's a cripple
And goes on crutches.—as for thee my Ziriff,
I doe here entertaine a friendhip with thee,
Shall drowne the memorie of all patternes pat;
Wee will oblige by turnes; and that o thick,
And fat, that curious tudiers of it,
Shall not once dare to cat it up, or ay
By way of ghee, whether thou or I
Remaine the debtors, when wee come to die. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Semanthe, Orithie, Philan, Orames, Lords and Ladies.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Is the Queen ready to come out?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Not yet ure the Kings brother is but newly entred;

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: Come my Lord, the Song then.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: The Song.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: A vengeance take this love, it poyles a voyce
Wore than the loing of a maiden-head.
I have got uch a cold with riing
And walking in my hirt a nights, that
A Bittorne whooping in a reed is better muicke.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: This modetie becomes you as ill, my Lord,
As wooing would us women; pray, put's not to't.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Nay Ladies, you hall finde mee,
As free, as the Muicians of the woods
Themelves; what I have, you hall not need to call for
Nor hall it cot you any thing.

lg.l: WHy o pale and wan fond Lover?
Prithee why o pale?
Will, when looking well can't move her,
Looking ill prevaile?
Prithee why o pale?
Why o dull and mute young Sinner?
Prithee why o mute?
Will, when peaking well can't win her,
Saying nothing doo't?
Prithee why o mute?
Quit, quit, for hame, this will not move
This cannot take her;
If of her elfe hee will not Love,
Nothing can make her,
The Devill take her.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: I hould have ghet, it had been the iue of
Your braine, if I had not been told o;

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: A little foolih counell (Madam) I gave a friend
Of mine foure or five yeares agoe, when he was
Falling into a Conumption.—

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Which of all you have eene the faire prioner
Since hee was confinde?

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: I have Madam.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: And how behaves hee now her elfe?

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: As one that had intrench'd o deepe in Innocence
Shee fear'd no enemies, beares all quietly,
And miles at Fortune, whil't hee frownes on her

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: So gallant! I wonder where the beautie lies
That thus inflames the royall bloud?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Faces, Madam, are like bookes, thoe that do tudy them
Know bet, and to ay truth, 'tis till
Much as it pleaes the Courteous Reader.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Thee Lovers ure are like Atronomers,
That when the vulgar eye dicovers, but
A Skie above, tudded with ome few tars,
Finde out beides trange fihes, birds, and beats.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: As men in icknee corch'd into a raving
Doe ee the Devill, in all hapes and formes,
When tanders by wondring, aske where, and when;
So they in Love, for all's but feaver there,
And madnee too.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: That's too evere Semanthe;
But we will have your reaons in the parke;
Are the doores open through the Gardens?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: The King has newly led the way. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Ariapes: Ziriff, with a warrant ealed.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Thou art a Tyrant, Ziriff: I hall die with joy.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: I mut confee my Lord; had but the Princes ills
Prov'd leight, and not thus dangerous,
Hee hould have ow'd to me, at leat I would
Have laid a claime unto his afetie; and
Like Phyicians, that doe challenge right
In Natures cures, look'd for reward and thanks;
But ince 'twas otherwie, I thought it bet
To ave my elfe, and then to ave the State.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: 'Twas wiely done.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Safely I'me ure, my Lord! you know 'tis not
Our cutome, where the Kings dilike, once wells to hate,
There to ingage our elves; Court friendhip
Is a Cable, that in tormes is ever cut,
And I made bold with it; here is the warrant eal'd
And for the execution of it, if you thinke
We are not trong enough, we may have
Iolas, for him the King did name.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: And him I would have named.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: But is hee not too much the Prince's (Sir?)

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Hee is as lights in Sceanes at Maques,
What glorious hew o e're he makes without
I that et him there, know why, and how; Enter Jolas.
But here he is.—
Come Jolas; and ince the Heav'ns decreed,
The man whom thou hould't envie, hould be uch,
That all men ele mut doo't; be not aham'd
Thou once wert guiltie of it;
But blee them, that they give thee now a meanes,
To make a friendhip with him and vouchafe
To find thee out a way to love, where well
Thou couldt not hate.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: What meanes my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Here, here he tands that has preerv'd us all!
That acrific'd unto a publique good,
(The dearet private good we mortalls have)
Friendhip: gave into our armes the Prince,
When nothing but the word (perchance a ruine)
Was left to doe it.

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: How could I chide my love, and my ambition now,
That thrut me upon uch a quarrell? here I doe vow—

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Hold doe not vow my Lord, let it deerve it firt;
And yet (if Heav'n blee honet mens intents)
'Tis not Impoible.
My Lord, you will be pleas'd to informe him in particulars,
I mut be gone.—
The King I feare already has been left
Too long alone.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Stay—the houre and place.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Eleven, under the Tarras walke;
I will not faile you there. Goes out, returns back again.
I had forgot:—
'Tmay be, the mall remainder of thoe lot men
That were of the conpiracie, will come along with him:
'Twere bet to have ome choen of the Guard
Within our call— Exit Ziriff.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l:
Honet, and carefull Ziriff:
Jolas tands muing.
How now Planet trooke?

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: This Ziriff will grow great with all the world,

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Shallow man hort •• ghteder than Travellers in mits,
Or women that outlive themelves; do't thou not ee,
That whil't hee does prepare a Tombe with one hand
For his friend, he digs a Grave with th'other for himelfe?

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: How o?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Do't thinke hee hall not feele the weight of this,
As well as poore Therames?

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: Shall wee then kill him too at the ame intant?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: And ay, the Prince made an unluckie thrut.

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: Right.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Dull, dull, he mut not dye o uelely.
As when we wipe off filth from any place,
We throw away the thing that made it cleane,
So this once done, hee's gone.
Thou know't the People love the Prince, to their rage
Something the State mut offer up; who fitter
Than thy rivall and my enemy?

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: Rare! our witnee will be taken.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Pih! let me alone.
The Giants that made mountaines ladders,
And thought to take great Iove by force, were fooles:
Not hill on hill, but plot on plot, does make
Us it above, and laugh at all below us.— Exeunt

div.stage: Enter Aglaura, and a Singing Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Madam 'twill make you melancholly,
I'le ing the Prince's Song, that's ad enough.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: What you will Sir.

lg.l: NO, no, faire Heretique, it needs mut bee
But an ill Love in mee,
And wore for thee.
For were it in my Power,
To love thee now this hower,
More than I did the lat;
I would then o fall,
I might not Love at all;
Love that can flow, and can admit increae,
Admitts as well an Ebb and may grow lee.
True Love is til the ame; the torrid Zones,
And thoe more frigid ones,
It mut not know:
For Love growne cold or hot,
Is Lut, or Friendhip, not
The thing wee have;
For that's a flame would die,
Held downe, or up to high
Then think I love more than I can expree,
And would love more, could I but love thee lee.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Leave mee! for to a Soule, o out of Tune,
As mine is now; nothing is harmony:
When once the maine-pring, Hope, is falne into
Diorder; no wonder, if the leer wheeles,
Deire, and Ioy, tand till; my thoughts like Bees
When they have lot their King, wander
Confuedly up and downe, and ettle no where.

sp.speaker: Orithie.
sp.l: flie! flie the roome,
As thou would't hun the habitations
Which Spirits haunt, or where thy nearer friends
Walk after death; here is not only Love,
But Loves plague too—misfortune; and o high,
That it is ure infectious!

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Madam, o much more mierable am I this way than you,
That hould I pitie you, I hould forget my elfe:
My ufferings are uch, that with lee patience
You may indure your owne, than give mine Audience.
There is that difference, that you may make
Yours none at all, but by conidering mine!

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: O peake them quickly then! the marriage day
To Paionate Lovers never was more welcome,
Than any kinde of eae would be to mee now.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Could they be poke, they wre not then o great.
I love, and dare not ay I love; dare not hope,
What I deire; yet till too mut deire—
And like a tarving man brought to a feat,
And made ay grace, to what he nere hall tate,
Be thankfull after all, and kie the hand,
That made the wound thus deepe.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: 'Tis hard indeed, but with what unjut cales,
Thou took't the weight of our mi-fortunes,
Be thine owne Judge now.
Thou mourn't for loe of that thou never hadt,
Or if thou hadt a loe, it never was
Of a Therames.
Would't thou not thinke a Merchant mad, Orithie?
If thou houldt ee him weepe, and teare his haire,
Becaue hee brought not both the Indies home?
And wouldt not thinke his orrowes very jut.
If having fraught his hip with ome rich Treaure,
Hee unke i'th' very Port? This is our cae.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: And doe you thinke there is uch odds in it?
Would Heaven we women could as eaily change
Our fortunes as ('tis aid) we can our minds.
I cannot (Madam) thinke them mierable,
That have the Princes Love.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Hee is the man then—
Bluh not Orithie, 'tis a inne to bluh
For loving him, though none at all to love him.
I can admit of rivalhip without
A jealouie—nay hall be glad of it:
Wee two will it, and thinke and think and igh,
And igh, and talke of love—and of Therames.
Thou halt be praiing of his wit, while I
Admire he governes it o well:
Like this thing, aid thus, th'other thing thus done,
And in good language him for thee adore,
While I want words to doo't, yet doe i • more.
Thus will wee doe till death it elfe hall us
Divide, and then whoe fate 'thall be to die
Firt of the two by legacie hall all
Her love bequeath, and give her tock to her
That hall urvive; for no one tock can erve.
To love Therames o as he'll deerve.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What have we here impoibilitie?
A contant night, and yet within the roome
That, that can make the day before the Sunne?
Silent Aglaura too?

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: I know not what you ay:
Is't to your pitie, or your corne, I owe
The favour of this viit (Sir?) for uch
My fortune is, it doth deerve them both:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And uch thy beauty is, that it makes good
All Fortunes, orrow lookes lovely here;
And there's no man, that would not entertaine
His griefes as friends, were he but ure they'd hew
No wore upon him—but I forget my elfe,
I came to chide.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: If I have inn'd o high, that yet my punihment
Equalls not my crime,
Doe Sir; I hould be loth to die in debt
To Jutice, how ill oere I paid
The cores of Love.—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And thoe indeed thou hat but paid indifferently
To me, I did deerve at leat faire death,
Not to be murthered thus in private:
That was too cruell, Mitree.
And I doe know thou do't repent, and wilt
Yet make me atisfaction:

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: What atisfaction Sir?
I am no montet, never had two hearts;
One is by holy vowes anothers now,
And could I give it you, you would not take it,
For 'tis alike impoible for mee,
To love againe, as you love Perjurie.
O Sir! conider, what a flame love is.
If by rude meanes you thinke to force a light,
That of it elfe it would not freely give,
You blow it out, and leave your elfe i'th' darke.
The Prince once gone, you may as well perwade
The light to tay behinde, when the Sun pots
To th'other world, as mee; alas! wee two,
Have mingled oules more than two meeting brooks;
And whooever is deign'd to be
The murtherer of my Lord, (as ure there is,
Has anger'd heav'n o farre that 'tas decreed
Him to encreae his punihment that way)
Would he but earch the heart, when he has done,
Hee there would find Aglaura murther'd too.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou hut o'recome me, mov'd o handomely
For pitie, that I will di-inherit
The elder brother, and from this houre be
Thy Convert, not thy Lover.—
Ziriff, dipatch away—
And he that brings newes of the Prince's welfare,
Looke that he have the ame reward, we had decreed
To him, brought tidings of his death.
'Tmut be a buie and bold hand, that would
Unlinke a chaine the Gods themelves have made:
Peace to thy thoughts: Aglaura— Exit.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: What e're he ayes beleeve him not Aglaura
For lut and rage ride high within him now:
He knowes Therames made th'ecape from hence,
And does conceale it only for his ends:
For by the favour of mitake and night,
He hopes t'enjoy thee in the Prince's roome;
I hall be mit—ele I would tell thee more;
But thou mayet ghee, for our condition
Admits no middle wayes, either we mut
Send them to Graves, or lie our elves in dut— Exit.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Ha! 'tis a trange Act thought puts me now upon;
Yet ure my brother meant the elfe-ame thing,
And my Therames would have done 't for me:
To take his life that eekes to take away
The life of Life, (honour from me;) and from
The world the life of honour, Therames;
Mut needs be omething ure, of kin to Jutice.
If I doe faile, th'attempt howe're was brave,
And I hall have at wort a handome grave— Exit.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: What? are we growne, Semanthe, night, and day?
Mut one till vanih when the other comes?
Of all that ever Love did yet bring forth
(And 'thas been fruitfull too) this is
The tranget iue.—

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: What my Lord?

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Hate Semanthe.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: You doe mitake, if I doe hun you, 'tis,
As bahfull Debtors hun their Creditors,
I cannot pay you in the elfe-ame coyne,
And am aham'd to offer any other.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: It is ill done Semanthe, to plead bankrupt,
When with uch eae you may be out of debt;
In loves dominions, native commoditie
Is currant payment, change is all the Trade,
And heart for heart the richet merchandize,

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: 'Twould here be mean my Lord, ince mine would prove
In your hands but a Counterfeit, and yours in mine
Worth nothing; Sympathy, not greatnee,
Makes thoe Jewells rie in value.

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: Sympathy! ô teach but yours to love then,
And two o rich no mortall ever knew.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: That heart would Love but ill that mut be taught,
Such fires as thee till kindle of themelves.

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: In uch a cold, and frozen place as is
Thy breat? how hould they kindle of themelves
Semanthe?

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: Aske how the Flint can carrie fire within?
'Tis the leat miracle that Love can doe:

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Thou art thy elfe the greatet miracle,
For thou art faire to all perfection,
And yet do't want the greatet part of beautie,
Kindnee thy crueltie (next to thy elfe,)
Above all things on earth takes up my wonder.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: Call not that crueltie, which is our fate,
Beleeve me Iolas the honet Swaine
That from the brow o ome teepe cliffe far off,
Beholds a hip labouring in vaine againt
The boyterous and unruly Elements, ne're had
Lee power, or more deire to help than I;
At every igh, I die, and every looke,
Does move; and any paion you will have
But Love, I have in tore: I will be angrie,
Quarrell with detinie, and with my elfe
That itis no better; be melancholy;
And (though mine owne dia •• ers well might plead
To be in chiefe,) yours only hall have place,
I'le pitie, and (if that's too low) I'le grieve,
As for my innes, I cannot give you eae;
All this I doe, and this I hope will prove
'Tis greater Torment not to love, than Love.— Exit.

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: So perihing Sailours pray to tormes,
And o they heare agen. So men
With death about them, looke on Phyitians that
Have given them o're, and o they turne away:
Two fixed Stars that keep a contant ditance,
And by lawes made with themelves mut know
No motion excentrick, may meet as oone as wee:
The anger that the foolih Sea does hew,
When it does brave it out, and rore againt
A tubborne rock that till denies it paage,
Is not o vaine and fruitlee, as my prayers.
Yee mighty Powers of Love and Fate, where is
Your Jutice here? It is thy part (fond Boy)
When thou do't find one wounded heart, to make
The other o, but if thy Tyranny
Be uch, that thou willt leave one breat to hate,
If we mut live, and this urvive,
How much more cruell's Fate?— Exit.

div.head: ACTUS V. SCENA I.

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: A Glorious night!

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Pray Heav'n it prove o.
Are wee not there yet?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: 'Tis about this hollow. Enter the Cave.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: How now! what region are we got into?
Th'enheritance of night;
Are we not mita • en a tur • ing Ziriff,
And tept into ome m • lancholy Devils Territorie?
Sure 'tis a part of the firt Chaos,
That would endure no change.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: No matter Sir, 'tis as proper for our purpoe,
As the Lobbie for the waiting womans.
Stay you here, I'le move a little backward,
And o we hall be ure to put him pat
Retreat: you know the word if't be the prince. (Goes to the mouth of the Cave.

div.l: Here Sir, follow me, all's quiet yet.—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hee is not come then?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where's Ariapes?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Waiting within. He leads him on, teps behind him, gives the fale word they kill the king.

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: I do not like this waiting,
Nor this fellowes leaving us.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: This place does put odd thoughts into thee,
Then thou art in thine owne nature too, as jealous
As either Love or Honor: Come weare thy word in readinee,
And thinke how neere we are a Crowne.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Revenge!
So let's drag him to the light and earch
His pockets, there may be papers there that will
Dicover the ret of the Conpiratours.
Iolas, your hand— Draw him out.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Whom have we here? the King!

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Yes, and Zorannes too. Illo! hoe!— Enter Paithas and others.
Unarme them.
D'ee tare?
This for my Fathers injuries & mine: Points to the Kings dead body.
Halfe Love, halfe Duties Sacrifice,
This—for the noble Prince, an offering to friendhip: (runs at Jolas.

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: Baely! and tamely— Dies.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: What hat thou done?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Nothing—kill'd a Traytour,
So—away with them, and leave us,
Paithas be onely you in call.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: What do't thou pawe?
Hat thou remore already murtherer?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: No foole: 'tis but a difference I put
Betwixt the crimes: Orbella is our quarrell;
And I doe hold it fit, that love hould have
A nobler way of Jutice, than Revenge
Or Treaon; follow me out of the wood,
And thou halt be Mater of this againe:
And then, bet arme and title take it. They go out & enter agen.
There— Gives him his Sword.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Extreamly good! Nature tooke paines I weare,
The villaine and the brave are mingled handomely.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: 'Twas Fate that tooke it when it decreed
Wee two hould meet, nor hall they mingle now
Wee are brought together trait to part.— Fight.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Some Devill ure has borrowed this hape. Pawe.
My Sword ne're tay'd thus long to find an entrance.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: To guiltie men, all that appeares is Devill,
Come Trifler, come.— Fight againe, Ariapes falls.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Whither whither, thou fleeting Coward life?
Bubble of Time Natures hame, tay; a little, tay!
Till I have look'd my elfe into revenge,
And tar'd this Traytour to a carkae firt.
—It will not be:— Falls.
The Crowne, the Crowne, too
Now is lot, for ever lot—oh!—
Ambition's, but an Ignis fatuns, I ee
Mileading fond mortalitie,
That hurries us about, and ets us downe
Jut—where—wee—firt—begun— Dies.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: What a great preading mightie thing this was,
And what a nothing now? how oone poore man
Vanihes into his noone-tide hadow?
But hopes o're fed have eldom better done:— (Hollows.)
Take up this lump of vanity, and honour, Enter Paithas.
And carry it the back way to my lodging,
There may be ue of State-men, when th'are dead:
So.—for the Cittadell now, for in uch times
As thee, when the unruly multitude
Is up in warmes, and no man knowes which way
They'll take, 'tis good to have retreat. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: The Dog-tar's got up high, it hould be late:
And ure by this time every waking eare,
And watchfull eye is charm'd; and yet me thought
A noye of weapons truck my eare jut now.
'Twas but my fancie ure, and were it more,
I would not tread on tep, that did not lead
To my Aglaura, tood all his Guard betwixt,
With lightning in their hands;
Danger! thou Dwarfe dret up in Giants clothes,
That hew't farre off, till greater than thou art:
Goe, terrifie the imple, and the guiltie, uch
As with fale Opticks, till doe looke upon thee.
But fright not Lovers, wee dare looke on thee
In thy wort hape, and meet thee in them too.
Stay—Thee trees I made my marke, 'tis hereabouts
—Love guide me but right this night,
And Lovers hall retore thee back againe
Thoe eyes the P •• ts tooke o boldly from thee. Exit

div.stage: Aglaura with a torch in one hand and a dagger in the other.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: How ill this does become this hand how much the wore
This uits with this, one of the two hould goe.
The hee within mee ayes, it mut be this—
Honor ayes this—and honour is Therames friend.
What is that hee then? it is not a thing
That ets a Price, not upon me, but on
Life in my name, leading me into doubt,
Which when 'tas done, it cannot light me out.
For feare does drive to Fate, or Fate if wee
Doe flie, oretakes, and holds us, till or death,
Or infamie, or both doth eize us.— Puts out the light.
Ha!—would 'twere in agen.
Antiques and trange mihapes,
Such as the Porter to my Soule, mine Eye,
Was ne're acquainted with, Fancie lets in,
Like a ditracted multitude, by ome trange accident
Piec'd together, feare now afreh comes on,
And charges Love to home.
—Hee comes—he comes—
Woman, if thou would't be the Subject of mans wonder,
Not his corne hereafter now hew thy elfe.
sp.stage: Enter Prince riing from the vault he tabs him two or thre • times, hee falls he goes back to her chamber.
sp.l: Sudden and fortunate.
My better Angell ure did both infue
A trength, and did direct it. Enter Ziriff.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Aglaura!

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Brother—

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: The ame.
So low to let in uch a long'd for Guet?
Mut Joy tand knocking Siter? come, prepare,
Prepare.—
The King of Peria's comming to you trait!
The King!—marke that.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: I thought how poore the Joyes you brought with you,
Were in repect of thoe that were with me:
Joyes, are our hopes tript of their feares,
And uch are mine; for know, deare Brother,
The King is • ome already, and is gone—marke that.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Is this intinct, or riddle? what King? how gone?

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: The Cave will tell you more—

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Some ad mitake—thou hat undone us all. Goes out, enters hatily againe.
The Prince! the Prince! cold as the bed of earth
He lies upon, as enlee too; death hangs
Upon his lips.
Like an untimely frot, upon an early Cherrie;
The noble Guet, his Soule, tooke it o ill
That you hould ue his old Acquaintance o,
That neither pray'rs, nor teares, can e're perwade
Him back againe.— Aglaura wounes: rubs her.
Hold hold! wee cannot ure part thus!
Siter! Aglaura! Therames is not dead,
It is the Prince that calls—

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: The Prince, where?—
Tell me, or I will trait goe back againe,
Into thoe groves of Geemine, thou took't me from,
And finde him out, or loe my elfe for ever.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: For ever.—I: there's it!
For in thoe Groves thou talk't of,
There are o many by-wayes, and odd rurnings.
Leading unto uch wild and dimall places,
That hould we goe without a guide, or tir
Before Heav'n calls, 'tis trongly to be feared
We there hould wander up and downe for ever,
And be benighted to eternitie!—

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Benighted to eternitie?—What's that?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Why 'tis to be benighted to eternitie;
To it i'th' darke, and doe I know not what;
Unriddle at our owne ad cot and charge,
The doubts the learned here doe onely move—

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: What place have murtherers brother there? for ure
The murtherer of the Prince mut have
A punihment that Heaven is yet to make.—

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: How is religion fool'd betwixt our loves,
And feares? poore Girle, for ought that thou hat done,
Thy Chaplets may be faire and flourihing,
As his in the Elyium:

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Doe you thinke o?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Yes, I doe thinke o.
The juter Judges of our Actions,
Would they have been evere upon
Our weaknees,
Would (ure) have made us tronger.—
Fie! thoe teares
A Bride upon the marriage day as properly
Might hed as thou, here widowes doo't
And marrie next day after:
To uch a funerall as this, there hould be
nothing common—
Wee'll mourne him o, that thoe that are alive
Shall thinke themelves more buried far than hee;
And wih to have his grave, to find his Obequies:

l.stage: Brings up the body, he woun • and dies.

sp.l: Agen! Siter—Aglaura—
O peake once more, once more looke out faire Soule.—
Shee's gone.—
Irrevocably gone.—And winging now the Aire,
Like a glad bird broken from ome cage:
Poore Bankrupt heart, when 'thad not wherewithall
To pay to ad diater all that was its due,
It broke—would mine would doe o too.
My oule is now within mee
Like a well metled Hauke, on a blind Faulk'ners fit,
Me thinkes I feele it baiting to be gone:
And yet I have a little foolih buinee here
On earth; I will dipatch:— Exit.

div.stage: Enter Paithas, with the body of Ariapes.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p:
Let me be like my burthen here, if I had not as lieve kill two of the Bloud-royall for him, as carrie one
of them; Thee Gentlemen of high actions are three times as heavie after death, as your private retir'd ones; looke if he be not reduc'd to the tate of a Courtier of the econd forme now? and cannot tand upon his owne legs, nor doe any thing without helpe, Hum.—And what's become of the great Prince, in prion as they call it now, the toy within us, that makes us talke, and laugh, and fight, I! why there's it, well, let him be what he will, and where he will, I'le make bold with the old Tenement here. Come Sir—come along:— Exit.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: All's fat too, here—
They leepe to night
I'their winding heets I thinke, there's uch
A generall quiet.
Oh! here's light I warrant:
For lut does take as little ret, as care, or age.—
Courting her glae, I weare, fie! that's a flatterer Madam,
In me you hal ee trulier what you are. (Knocks. Ent. the Queen

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: What make you up at this trange houre my Lord?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: My buinee is my boldnee warrant,
(Madam)
And I could well afford t'have been without it now,
Had Heav'n o pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: 'Tis a ad Prologue,
What followes in the name of vertue?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: The King.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: I: what of him? is well is he not?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Yes.—
If to be free from the great load
Wee weat and labour under, here on earth
Be to be well, he is.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Why hee's not dead, is hee?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Yes Madam, laine—and the Prince too

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: How? where?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: I know not, but dead they are.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Dead?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Did't ee them dead?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: As I ee you alive.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Dead!

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Yes, dead.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Well, we mut all die;
The Siters pin no cables for us mortalls
Th'are thred; and Time, and chance—
Trut me I could weepe now,
But watrie ditillations doe but ill on graves,
They make the lodging colder. She knocks.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: What would you Madam?

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Why my friends, my Lord!
I would conult and know, what's to be done.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Madam 'tis not o afe to raie the Court;
Things thus unetled, if you pleae to have—

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Where's Ariapes?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: In's dead leepe by this time I'm ure,

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: I know he is not! find him intantly.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: I'm gone,— Turnes back againe.
But Madam, why make you choyce of him, from whom
If the ucceion meet diturbance,
All mut come of danger?

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: My Lord, I am not yet o wie, as to be jealous;
Pray dipute no further.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Pardon me Madam, if before I goe
I mut unlock a ecret unto you; uch a one
As while the King did breathe durt know no aire,
Zorannes lives.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: And in the hope of uch a day as this
Has lingred out a life, natching, to feed
His almot famih'd eyes,
Sights now and then of you, in a diguie.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Strange! this night is big with miracle!

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: If you did love him, as they ay you did,
And doe o till; 'tis now within your power!

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: I would it were my Lord, but I am now
No private woman, If I did love him once
(And 'tis o long agoe, I have forgot)
My youth and ignorance may well excus't.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Excue it?

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Yes, excue it Sir.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Though I confee I lov'd his father much.
And pitie him, yet having offer'd it
Unto your thoughts: I have dicharg'd a trut;
And zeale hall tray no further.
Your pardon Madam: Exit. Queen tudies.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: May be 'tis a plot to keep off Ariapes
Greatnee, which hee mut feare, becaue he knowes
He hates him: for thee great State-men,
That when time has made bold with the King & Subject,
Throwing down all fence that tood betwixt their power
And others right, are on a change,
Like wanton Salmons comming in with flouds,
That leap o're wyres and nets, and make their way
To be at the returne to every one a prey.

div.stage: Enter Ziriff, and Paithas throwing down the dead body of Ariapes.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Ha! murthered too!
Treaon—treaon—

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: But uch another word, and halfe o loud,
And th'art,—

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Why? thou wilt not murther me too?
Wilt thou villaine?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: I do not know my temper— Dicovers himelfe
Looke here vaine thing, and ee thy ins full blowne:
There's carce a part in all this face, thou hat
Not been forworn by, and Heav'n forgive thee for't!
For thee I lot a Father, Countrey, friends,
My elfe almot, for I lay buried Long;
And when there was no ue thy love could pay
Too great, thou mad't the principle away:
Had I but taid, and not began revenge
Till thou had't made an end of changing,
I had had the Kingdome to have kill'd:
As wantons entring a Garden, take
The firt faire flower, they meet, and
Treaure't in their laps.
Then eeing more, do make freh choyce agen,
Throwing in one and one, till at the length
The firt poor flower o're-charg'd, with too much weight
Withers, and dies:
So hat thou dealt with mee,
And having kill'd me firt, I will kill—

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Hold—hold—
Not for my ake, but Orbella's (Sir) a bare
And ingle death is uch a wrong to Jutice,
I mut needs except againt it.
Find out a way to make me long a dying;
For death's no punihment, it is the ene,
The paines and feares afore that makes a death:
To thinke what I had had, had I had you,
What I have lot in loing of my elfe;
Are deaths farre wore than any you can give:
Yet kill me quickly, for if I have time,
I hall o wah this oule of mine with teares,
Make it o fine, that you would be afreh
In love with it, and o perchance I hould
Again come to deceive you. Sheries up weeping, & hanging down her head

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: So ries day, bluhing at nights deformitie:
And o the prettie flowers blubber'd with dew,
And ever waht with raine, hang downe their heads,
I mut not looke upon her: (Goes towards him.)

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Were but the Lillies in this face as freh
As are the Roes; had I but innocence
Joyn'd to their bluhes, I hould then be bold,
For when they went on begging they were ne're deni'de,
'Tis but a parting kie Sir—

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: I dare not grant it.—

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Your hand Sir then, for that's a part I hall
Love after death (if after death we love)
'Caue it did right the wrong'd Zorannes, here—
sp.stage: Steps to him, and opens the box of poyon, Zorannes falls.
sp.l: Sleepe, leepe for ever, and forgotten too,
All but thy ills, which may ucceeding time
Remember, as the Sea-man does his marks,
To know what to avoyd, may at thy name
All good men tart, and bad too, may it prove
Infection to the Aire, that people dying of it
May help to cure thee for me. (Turnes to the body of Ariapes.
Could I but call thee back as eas'ly now;
But that's a Subject for our teares, not hopes!
There is no piecing Tulips to their talks,
When they are once divorc'd by a rude hand;
All we can doe is to preerve in water
A little life, and give by couretous Art
What canted Nature wants Commiion for,
That thou halt have: for to thy memorie
Such Tribute of moyt orrow I will pay,
And that o purifi'd by love, that on thy grave
Nothing hall grow but Violets & Primroes,
Of which too, ome hall be
Of the myterious number, o that Lovers hall
Come thither not as to a tomb, but to an Oracle. She knocks, and raies the Court.

div.stage: Enter Ladies and Courtiers, as out of their beds.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Come! come! help me to weep my elfe away,
And melt into a grave, for life is but
Repentance nure, and will conpire with memorie,
To make my houres my tortures.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: What Scene of orrow's this? both dead?

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Dead? I! and 'tis but halfe death's triumphs this,
The King and Prince lye omewhere, jut
Such empty truncks as thee.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: The Prince?
Then in griefes burthen I mut beare a part.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: The noble Ariapes—valiant Ziriff too.— Weeps.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Weep't thou for him, fond Prodigall? do't know
On whom thou pend't thy teares? this is the man
To whom we owe our ills; the fale Zorannes
Diguis'd, not lot; but kept alive, by ome Enter Paithas, urveys the bodyes, finds his Mater
Incened Power, to punih Peria thus:
He would have kill'd me too, but Heav'n was jut,
And furniht me with meanes, to make him pay
This core of villanie, e're he could do more.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Were you his murth'rer then?— Paithas runs at her, kills her, and flies.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Ah me! the Queene.— Rub her till he come to her elfe.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: How doe you Madam?

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Well,—but I was better, and hall— Dies.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: Oh! he is gone for ever.

div.stage: Enter Lords in their night-gownes, Orames, Philan.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: What have we here?
A Church-yard? nothing but ilence, and grave?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Oh! here has been (my Lords)
The blacket night the Perian world e're knew,
The King and Prince are not themelves exempt
From this arret; but pale and cold, as thee,
Have meaured out their lengths.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Impoible! which way?

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: Of that we are as ignorant as you:
For while the Queene was telling of the Storie,
An unknowne villaine here has hurt her o,
That like a ickly Taper, he but made
One flah, and o expir'd:

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Here he is, but no confeion.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Torture mut force him then:
Though 'Twill indeed, but weakly atisfie
To know now they are dead, how they did die.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Come take the bodies up, and let us all
Goe drowne our elves in teares, this maacre
Has left o torne a State, that 'twill be policie
Awell as debt, to weep till we are blinde,
For who would ee the mieries behinde?

lg.l: OVr Play is done, and yours doth now begin:
What different Fancies, people now are in?
How trange, and odd a mingle it would make,
If e're they rie; 'twere poible to take
All votes.—
But as when an authentique Watch is howne,
Each man wi • des up, and rectifies his owne,
So in our very Judgements; firt there its
A grave Grand Jurie on it of Towne-wits;
And they give up their verdict; then agin
The other Jurie of the Court comes in
(And that's of life and death) for each man ees
That oft condemnes, what th' other Jurie frees:
Some three dayes hence, the Ladies o • the Towne
Will come to have a Judgement of their owne:
And after them, their ervants; then the Citie,
For that is modet, and is till lat wittie.
'Twill be a weeke at leat yet e're they have
Reolv'd to let it live, or give't a grave:
Such difficultie, there is to unite
Opinion; or bring it to be right.
THat th' abuing of your eare's a crime,
Above th' excue any ix lines in <>
Can make, the Poet knowes: I am but en •
T' intreat hee may not be a Preident,
For hee does thinke that in this place the • e hee
Many have done't as much and more than hee
But here's, he ayes, the difference of the Fates,
Hee begs a Pardon after't, they Etates.

div.p: AGLAURA. REPRESENTED At the Court, by his Majeties Servants.
Written by Sir JOHN SVCKLING.
LONDON, Printed for Tho Walkley, and are to be old by Humphrey Moeley, at his hop, at the igne of the Princes armes in St. Pauls Church-yard, 1646.

lg.l: FOre love, a mighty Seions: and I feare,
Though kind lat Sizes, 'twill be now evere;
For it is thought, and by judicious men,
Aglaura 'cap't onely by dying then:
But 'twould be vaine for mee now to indeare,
Or peake unto my Lords, the Judges here,
They hold their places by condemning till,
And cannot hew at once mercie and skill;
For wit's o cruell unto wit, that they
Are thought to want, that find not want ith' play,
But Ladies you, who never lik'd a plot.
But where the Servant had his Mitree got,
And whom to ee a Lover dye it grieves,
Although 'tis in wore language that he lives,
Will like't w are confident, ince here will bee,
That your Sex ever lik'd varietie.
TIs trange perchance (you'll thinke) that he that di' d •
At Chritmas, hould at Eater be a Bride:
But 'tis a privilege the Poets have,
To take the long-ince dead out of the grave:
Nor is this all, old Heroes a leepe
'Twixt marble coverlets, and ix foot deep •
In earth, they boldly wake, and make them doe
All they did living here—ometimes more too,
They give freh life, revere and alter Fate,
And yet more bold, Almightie-like create:
And out of nothing onely to deifie
Reaon, and Reaons friend, Philoophie,
Fame, honour, valour, all that's great, or good,
Or is at leat 'mongt us, o undertood,
They give, heav'ns theirs, no handome woman dies,
But if they pleae, is trait ome tar i'th' skies—
But oh—
How thoe poore men of Meetre doe
Flatter themelves with that, that is not true,
And 'caue they can trim up a little proe,
And poile it handomly, vainly uppoe
Th' are Omnipotent, can doe all thoe things
That can be done onely by Gods and Kings.
Of this wild guilt, hee faine would bee thought free,
That writ this Play, and therefore (Sir) by mee,
Hee humbly begs, you would be pleas'd to know,
Aglaura's but repriev'd this night, and though
Shee now appeares upon a Poets call,
Shee's not to live, unlee you ay hee hall.

div.head: ACTUS V. SCENA I.
div.stage: Enter Ziriff, Paithas, and Guard: hee places 'em: and Exit. A State et out. Enter Ziriff, Jolas, Ariapes.

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: A Glorious night!

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Pray Heav'n it prove o.
Are wee not there yet?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: 'Tis about this hollow. They Enter the Cave.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: How now! what region are we got into?
Th'enheritance of night;
Have wee not mitaken a turning Ziriff,
And tept into the confines of ome melancholy
Devils Territorie?

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: Sure 'tis a part of the firt Chaos,
That would not uffer any change.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: No matter Sir, 'tis as proper for our
Purpoe, as the Lobbie for the waiting womans.
Stay you here, I'le move a little backward,
And o we hall be ure to put him pat
Retreat: you know the word if it be the prince. Ziriff goes to the doore

sp.speaker: Ziriff.
sp.l: Here Sir, follow me, al • 's quiet yet.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Is hee not come then?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where's Ariapes?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Waiting within.

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.l: I do not like this waiting,
Nor this fellowes leaving of us.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: This place does put odd thoughts into thee.
Then thou art in thine owne nature too,
As jealous, as Love, or Honour; weare thy word
In readinee, and thinke how neere we are a Crowne.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Revenge!— Guard eieth on'em.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ha! what's this?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Bring them forth.— Brings them forth.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: The King.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Yes, and the Princes friend— Dicovers himelfe.
D'you know this face?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Zorannes.

sp.speaker: Zor.
sp.l: The very ame,
The wrong'd Zorannes,—King—
D you tare.—
Away with them where I appointed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Villaine, thou dar't not doe this—

sp.speaker: Zor.
sp.l: Poore Counterfeit,
How faine thou now would't act a King and art not:
Stay you,— to Ariapes.
Unhand him,— Whipers.
Leave us now.— Exeunt. Manet Ariap. Zoran.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: What does this meane?
Sure hee does intend the Crowne to mee.

sp.speaker: Zor.
sp.l: Wee are alone
Follow mee out of the wood, and thou halt be
Mater of this againe,
And then bet a • me and title take it.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Thy offer is o noble, in gratitude Icannot
But propound gentler conditions,
Wee will divide the Empire.

sp.speaker: Zor.
sp.l: Now by my fathers oule,
I doe almot repent my firt intents,
And now could kill thee curvily, for thinking
If I had a minde to rule
I would not rule alone,
Let not thy eaie faith (lot man)
Foole thee into o dull an hereie;
Orbella is our quarrell, & I have thought it fit,
That love hould have a nobler way of Jutice,
Than Revenge, or Treaon.
If thou dar't die handomly, follow me. Ex. And enter both agen

sp.speaker: Zor.
sp.l: There,— Gives him his word.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Extremely good; Nature tooke paines I weare,
The villaine and the brave are mingled handomely:—

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: 'Twas Fate that tooke it, when it decreed
Wee two hould meet, nor hall they mingle now,
Wee are but brought together trait to part.— Fight.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Some Devill ure has borrowed this hape,
My word ne're taid thus long to finde an entrance.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: To guiltie men, all that appeare is Devill;
Come trifler come.— Fight.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Dog, thou hat it,

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Why then it eemes my tar's as great as his, Ariapes pants, and runs at him to catch his word
I mile at thee,
Thou now would't have me kill thee,
And 'tis a courteie I cannot afford thee,
I have bethought my elfe, there will be ue
Of thee,—Paithas—to the ret with him. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Paithas, and two of the Guard.—Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: The Dog-tar's got up high, it hould be late:
And ure by this time every waking eare
And watchfull eye is charm'd; and yet mee thought
A noye of weapons truck my eare jut now.
'Twas but my Fancie ure, and were it more,
I would not tread one tep, that did not lead
To my Aglaura, tood all his Guard betwixt,
With lightning in their hands.
Danger, thou Dwarfe dret up in Giants clothes,
That hew't far off till greater than thou art,
Goe, terrifie the imple, and the guiltie, uch
As with fale Opticks till doe looke upon thee:
But fright not Lovers wee dare looke on thee
In thy wort hapes and meet thee in them too.—
Stay thee trees I made my marke, tis hereabouts,
—Love guide mee but right this night,
And Lovers hall retore thee back againe
Thoe eyes the Poets tooke o boldly from thee. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Aglaura, with a Torch in one hand, a Dagger in the other.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: How ill this does become this hand? much wore
This uits with this, one of the two hould goe.
The hee within mee ayes, it mut be this—
Honor ayes this—and honour is Therames friend.
What is that hee then? is it not a thing
That ets a Price, not upon me, but on
Life in my name, leading me into doubt,
Which when 'tas done it cannot light me out.
For feare does drive to Fate, or Fate if wee
Doe flie, oretakes, and holds us, till or death,
Or infamie, or both doe eize us.— Puts out the light.
Ha!—would 'twere in agen. Antiques & trange mihapes,
Such as the Porter to my Soule, mine Eye,
Was ne're acquainted with, Fancie lets in,
Like a dirouted multitude, by ome trange accident
Piec'd together, feare now afreh comes on,
And charges Love too home.
—Hee comes, he comes.— A little noye below.
Woman, if thou would't be the Subject
Of mans wonder, Not his corne hereafter,—
—Now hew thy elfe.

div.stage: Enter Therames from the vault, he tabs him as hee rieth.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Unkindly done—

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: The Princes voyce, defend it Goodnee?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: What art thou that thus poorely
Hat detroy'd a life?

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Oh ad mitake, 'tis hee?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Hat thou no voyce?

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: I would I had not, nor a being neither.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Aglaura, it cannot be?

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Oh till beleeve o, Sir,
For 'twas not I Indeed, but fatall Love.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Loves wounds us'd to be gentler than thee were,
The paines they give us have ome pleaure
In them, and that thee have not. Enter Ziriff with a taper.
Oh doe not ay 'twas you, for that does wound agen:
Guard me my better Angell,
Doe I wake? my eyes (ince I was man)
Ne're met with any object gave them o much trouble,
I dare not aske neither to be atisfied,
Shee lookes o guiltily—

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Why doe you tare and wonder at a thing
That you your elfe have made thus mizerable?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Good gods, and I o'the partie too.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Did you not tell me that the King this night
Meant to attempt my honour; that our condition
Would not admit of middle wayes, and that we mut
Send them to graves, or lye our elves in dut?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Unfortunate mitake? Ziriff knocks.
I never did intend our afety by thy hands: Enter Paithas.
Paithas, goe intantly and fetch Andrages
From his bed; how is it with you Sir?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: As with the beieg'd:
My oule is o beet it does not know,
Whether't had bet to make a deperate
Sally out by this port or not?

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Sure I hall turne tatue here.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: If thou do't love me, weepe not Aglaura:
All thoe are drops of bloud and flow from me.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Now all the gods defend this way of expiation,
Think't thou thy crime, Aglaura would be lee,
By adding to it? or cant thou hope
To atisfie thoe powers, whom great ins
Doe dipleae, by doing greater.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Dicourteous courteie!
I had no other meanes left mee than this,
To let Therames know I would doe nothing
To him, I would not doe unto my elfe,
And that thou taket away.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Friend, bring me a little neerer,
I find a kind of willingnee to tay
And find that willingnee omething obey'd.
My bloud now it perwades it elfe
You did not call in earnet,
Makes not uch hat.—

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Oh my dearet Lord,
This kindnee is o full of crueltie,
Puts uch an uglinee on what I have done,
That when I looke upon it needs mut fright
Me from my elfe, and which is more inufferable.
I feare from you.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Why hould that fright thee, which mot comforts mee?
I glorie in it, and hall mile i'th' grave
To thinke our love was uch, that nothing
But it elfe could e're detroy it.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Detroy it? can it have ever end?
Will you not be thus courteous then in the other world?
Shall we not be together there as here?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: I cannot tell whether I may or not.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Not tell?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: No:
The Gods thought me unworthy of thee here,
And when thou art more pure
Why hould I not more doubt it?

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Becaue if I hall be more pure,
I hall be then more fit for you.
Our Priets aure us an Elyium,
And can that be Elyium where true Lovers
Mut not meet? Thoe Powers that made our loves,
Did they intend them mortall,
Would ure have made them of a courer tuffe,
Would they not my Lord?—

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Prethee peake till,
This muique gives my oule uch pleaing buinee,
Takes it o wholly up, it findes not leiure to
Attend unto the ummons death does make;
Yet they are loud and peremptorie now,
And I can onely— Faints.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Some pitying Power inpire me with
A wa • to follow him: heart wilt thou not
Breake it of thy elfe.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: My grie • es beot me:
His ou • e will ai • e out with this purple tide,
And I hall here be found taring
After't like a man that's come too hort o'th' hip,
And's left behind upon the land. Shee wounes.
Oh welcome, we come here lyes Andrages
Alas too great a tr • all for thy art.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: There's life in him: from whence thee wounds?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Oh 'tis no time for torie.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: 'Tis not mortall my Lord, bow him gently,
And help me to infue this into him;
The ou e is but aleepe and not gone forth.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Oh—ho:—

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Hearke the Prince does live.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: What e're thou art hat given me now a life,
And with it all my cares and mieries,
Expect not a reward no not a thanks.
If thou would't merit from me,
(Yet wh would be guilty of o lot an action)
Retore me to my quietnee agen,
For life and that are mot incompatible.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Still in depaires:
I did not thinke till now 'twas in the power
Of Fortune to have robb'd Therames of himelfe,
For pitie, Sir and reaon live;
If you will die die not Aglaura's murther'd,
That's not o handome: at leat die not
Her murthered and her murtherer too;
For that will urely follow. Looke up, Sir,
This violence of Fortune cannot lat ever:
Who knowes but all thee clouds are hadowes,
To et off your fairer dayes, if it growes blacker,
And the tormes doe rie, this harbour's alwayes open.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: What ay't thou Aglaura?

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: What ayes Andrages?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Madam, would Heaven his mind would admit
As eafie cure, as his body will,
'Twas onely want of bloud,
And two houres ret retores him to himelfe.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: And by that time it may be Heaven
Will give our mieries ome eae:
Come Sir, repoe upon a bed,
There's time enough to day.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Well, I will till obey,
Though I mut feare it will be with me,
But as 'tis with tortured men,
Whom States preerve onely to wrack agen. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: All fat too, here
They leepe to night
I'their winding heets, I thinke, there's uch
A generall quiet.
Oh! here's light I warrant you:
For lut does take as little ret, as care, or age.
Courting her glae, I wear, fie! that's a flatterer Madam,
In me you hall ee trulier what you are He knocks, Enter Queen.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: What make you up at this trange houre, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: My buinee is my boldnee warrant,
(Madam)
And I could well afford t'have been without it now,
Had Heav'n o pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: 'Tis a ad Prologue,
What followes in the name of vertue?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: The King—

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: I: what of him? is well, is he not?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Yes,—
If to be on's journey to the other world
Be to be well, hee is.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Why he's not dead, is he?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Yes, Madam, dead.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: How? where?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: I doe not know particulars.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Dead!

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Yes (Madam.)

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Art ure hee's dead?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Madam, I know him as certainly dead,
As I know you too mut die hereafter.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Dead!

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Yes, dead.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: We mut all die.
The Siters pin no cables for us mortalls;
Th'are threds; and Time, and chance—
Trut me I could weep now,
But watrie ditillations doe but ill on graves,
They make the lodging colder. Shee knocks.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: What would you Madam?

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Why my friends, my Lord;
I would conult and know what's to be done.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: (Madam) 'tis not o afe to raie the Court;
Things thus unetled, if you pleae to have—

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Where's Ariapes?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: In's dead leepe by this time ure,

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: I know he is not! find him intantly.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: I'm gone,— Turnes back againe.
But Madam, why make you choyce of him, from whom
If the ucceion meet diturbance,
All mut come of danger?

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: My Lord, I am not yet o wie, as to be
Jealous; Pray dipute no further.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Pardon me (Madam) if before I goe
I mut unlock a ecret to you; uch a one
As while the King did breathe durt know no aire,
Zorannes lives.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: And in the hope of uch a day as this
Has lingred out a life, natching, to feed
His almot famih'd eyes,
Sights now and then of you, in a diguie.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Strange! this night is big with miracle!

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: If you did love him, as they ay you did,
And doe o till; 'tis now within your power!

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: I would it were, my Lord, but I am now
No private woman, if I did love him once,
(as 'tis o long agoe, I have forgot)
My youth and ignorance may well excus't.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Excue it?

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Yes, excue it Sir.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Though I confee I lov'd his father much
And pitie him, yet having offer'd it
Unto your thoughts: I have dicharg'd a trut;
And zeale hall tray no further.
(Your pardon Madam:) Exit.

sp.speaker: Orb.
