sp.l: May be 'tis but a plot to keep off Ariapes
Greatnee which he mut feare, becaue he knowes
Hee hates him: for thee great States-men,
That when time has made bold with the King
And Subject, throwing downe all fence
That tood betwixt their power
And others right, are on a change,
Like wanton Salmons comming in with flouds,
That leap o're wyres and nets and make their way
To be at the returne to every one a prey.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Looke here vaine thing and ee thy ins full blown:
There's carce a part in all this face, thou hat
Not been forworne by, and Heav'n forgive thee for't!
For thee I lot a Father, Countrey, friends,
My elfe almot, for I lay buried long;
And when there was no ue thy love could pay
Too great, thou mad't the principle away:— Prompt.
As wantons entring a Garden, take
The firt faire flower they meet, and
Treaur't in their laps.
Then eeing more, doe make freh choyce agen,
Throwing in one and one, till at the length
The firt poor flower o're-charg'd, with too much weight
Withers and dies:
So hat thou dealt with me,
And having kill'd me firt, I will kill—

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Hold—hold—
Not for my ake, but Orbella's (Sir) a bare
And ingle death is uch a wrong to Jutice,
I mut needs except againt it.
Find out a way to make me long a dying;
For death's no punihment, it is the ene,
The paines and feares afore that makes a death:
To thinke what I had had, had I had you,
What I have lot in loing of my elfe;
Are deaths farre wore than any you can give:
Yet kill me quickly, for if I have time,
I hall o wah this oule of mine with teares,
Make it o fine, that you would be afreh
In love with it, and o perchance I hould
Again come to deceive you. She ries up weeping, & hanging down her head.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: So ries day, bluhing at nights deformitie:
And o the prettie flowers blubber'd with dew,
And over waht with raine, hang downe their heads
I mut not looke upon her: (Queen Goe • towards him.)

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Were but the Lillies in this face as freh
As are the Roes; had I but innocence
Joyn'd to thee bluhes, I hould then be bold,
For when they went a begging they were ne're deni'de,
'Tis but a parting kie Sir—

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: I dare not grant it.—Paithas—away with her.
A bed put •• t. Therames and Aglaura on it, Andrages by.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Shee wake't me with a igh,
And yet hee leepes her elfe, Sweet Innocence,
Can it be inne to love this hape,
And if it be not, why am I perecuted thus?—
Shee ighs agen, leepe that drownes all cares,
Cannot I ee charme loves? blet pillowes,
Through whoe finenee does appeare
The Violets, Lillies and the Roes
You are tuft withall, to whoe oftnee
I owe the weet of this repoe,
Permit me to leave with you this,— Kies them, hee wakes.
See if I have not wake't her,
Sure I was borne, Aglaura, to detroy
Thy quiet.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Mine, my Lord,
Call you this drowinee a quiet then?
Beleeve me, Sir, 'twas an intruder I much
Struggled with, and have to thanke a dreame,
Not you, that it thus left me.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: A dreame! what dreame, my Love?

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: I dreamp't (Sir) it was day,
And the feare you hould be found here.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: Awake; how is it with you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Well, extreamly well, o well, that had I now
No better a remembrancer than paine,
I hould forget I e're was hurt,
Thanks to Heav'n, and good Andrages.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: And more than thanks I hope we yet hall
Live to pay him. How old's the night?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Far-pent I feare, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: I have a caue that hould be heard
Yet ere day breake and I mut needs intreat
You Sir to be the Judge in't.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: What caue Zorannes?

sp.speaker: Zir.
sp.l: When you have promis'd— (Zorannes.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: 'Twere hard I hould deny thee any thing.— Exit
Know't thou, Andrages, what he meanes?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Nor cannot ghee, Sir,— Draw in the bed.
I read a trouble in his face, when firt
Hee left you, but undertood it not.

div.stage: Enter Zorannes, King Ariapes, Jolas, Queene and two or three Guard.

sp.speaker: Zor.
sp.l: Have I not pitcht my nets like a good Huntman?
Looke, Sir, the noblet of the Herd are here.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: I am atonihed.

sp.speaker: Zor.
sp.l: This place is yours.— Helps him up.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: What wouldt thou have me doe.

sp.speaker: Zor.
sp.l: Remember, Sir, your promie,
I could doe all I have to doe, alone;
But Jutice is not Jutice unlee't be jutly done:
Here then I will begin, for here began my wrongs.
This woman (Sir) was wondrous faire, and wondrous
Kinde,—I, faire and kind, for o the torie runs,
She gave me looke for looke, and glance for glance,
And every igh like eccho's was return'd,
Wee ent up vow by vow, promie on promie,
So thick and trangely multiplyed,
That ure we gave the heavenly Regiters
Their buinee, and other mortalls oaths
Then went for nothing, we felt each others paines,
Each others joyes, thought the ame thought,
And poke the very ame;
Wee were the ame and I have much a doe
To thinke he could be ill, and I not
Be o too, and after this, all this (Sir)
Shee was fale, lov'd him, and him,
And had I not begun revenge,
Till he had made an end of changing,
I had had the Kingdome to have killd,
What does this deerve?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: A punihment he bet can make
That uffered the wrong.

sp.speaker: Zor.
sp.l: I thanke you, Sir,
For him I will not trouble you,
His life is mine, I won it fairly,
And his is yours, he lot it foully to you—
To him (Sir) now:
A man o wicked that he knew no good,
But o as't made his ins the greater for't.
Thoe ills, which ingly acted bred depaire
In others, he acted daily, and ne're thought
Upon them.
The grievance each particular has againt him
I will not meddle with, it were to give him
A long life, to give them hearing,
I'le onely peake my owne.
Firt then the hopes of all my youth,
And a reward which Heaven had ettled on me,
(If holy contracts can doe any thing)
He raviht from me, kill'd my father,
Aglaura's father, Sir, would have whor'd my iter,
And murther'd my friend, this is all:
And now your entence, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: We have no punihment can reach thee crimes:
Therefore 'tis jutet ure to end him where
Th'are wittier to punih than we are here:
And caue repentance oft tops that proceeding,
A udden death is ure the greatet punihment.

sp.speaker: Zor.
sp.l: I humbly thanke you Sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What a trange glae thhave hew'd me now my elfe
In; our ins like to our hadowes,
When our day is in its glorie carce appear'd,
Towards our evening how great and montrous
They are.

sp.speaker: Zor.
sp.l: Is this all you have to ay?— Drawes.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Hold:—now goe you up.

sp.speaker: Zor.
sp.l: What meane you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Nay, I denyed not you,—
That all thy accuations are jut,
I mut acknowledge,
And to thee crimes, I have but this t'oppoe,
Hee is my Father, and thy Soveraigne.—
'Tis wickednee (deare Friend) wee goe about
to punih, and when w'have murther'd him,
What difference is there 'twixt him and
Our elves, but that hee firt was wicked?—
Thou now would't kill him 'caue he kill'd thy Father,
And when th'hat kill'd, have not I the elfe ame
Quarrell?

sp.speaker: Zor.
sp.l: Why Sir, you know you would your elfe
Have done it.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: True: and therefore 'tis I beg his life,
There was no way for mee to have
Redeem'd th'intent, but by a reall

Saving of it.
• e ready Courtiers, and Guard, with their words drawne, at the brets of the Prioners.
If he did ravih from thee thy Orbella,
Remember that that wicked iue had
A noble parent Love,—Remember
How he lov'd Zorannes when he was Ziriff,—
Ther's omething due to that.
If you mut needs have bloud for your revenge,

Take it here—depie it not Zorannes:
Zorannes turnes away.
The gods themelves, whoe greatnee
Makes the greatnee of our ins,
And heightens'em above what wee can doe
Unto each other, accept of acrifice
For what wee doe 'gaint them,
Why hould not you, and 'tis much thriftier too:
You cannot let out life there, but my honour
Goes, and all the life you can take here,
Poterity will give mee back agen;
See, Aglaura weepes:
That would have beene ill Rhetorique in mee,
But where it is, it cannot but perwade.

sp.speaker: Zor.
sp.l: Th'have thaw'd the ice about my heart;
I know not what to doe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come downe come downe, I will be King agen,
There's none o fit to be the Judge of this
As I; the life you hew'd uch zeale to ave,
I here could willingly returne you back;
But that's the common price of all revenge.

div.stage: Enter Guard, Orames, Philan, Courtiers, Orithie, Semanthe.

sp.speaker: Jol. Ari.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha: how they looke now?

sp.speaker: Zor.
sp.l: Death: what's this?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Betray'd agen;
All th'eae our Fortune gives our mieries is hope,
And that till proving fale, growes part of it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: From whence this Guard?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Why Sir, I did corrupt, while we were his prioners,
One of his owne to raie the Court; hallow oules,
That thought wee could not countermine,
Come Sir, y'are in good poture to dipatch them.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Lay hold upon his intrument:
Fond man, do't thinke I am in love with villany?
All the ervice they can doe mee here
Is but to let thee ee the right I doe
Them now is uncontrain'd, then thus I doe proceed.
Upon the place Zorannes lot his life,
I vow to build a tomb, and on that tomb
I vow to pay three whole yeares penitence,
If in that time I finde that heaven and you
Can pardon; I hall finde agen the way
To live amongt you.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Sir be not o cruell to your elfe this is an age,—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: 'Tis now irrevocable, thy Fathers lands
I give thee back agen, and his commands;
And with them, leave to weare the Tyara,
That man there has abus'd.—
To you Orbella,
Who it eemes are foule as well as I,
I doe precribe the elfe ame phyick
I doe take my elfe:
But in another place, and for a longer time,
Diana's Nunnerie.

sp.speaker: Orb.
sp.l: Above my hopes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: For you, who till have beene
The ready intrument of all my cruelties,
And there have cancell'd all the bonds of brother,
Perpetuall banihment: nor, hould
This line expire, hall thy right have a place.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Hell and Furies.— Exit.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thy crimes deerve no lee; yet 'caue thou wert
Heavens intrument to ave my life,
Thou onely hat that time of banihment,
I have of penitence.— Comes down. Ziriff offers to kie the Kings hand

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: May it be plague and famine here till I returne.
No: thou halt not yet forgive mee:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Aglaura thus I freely part with thee,
And part with all fond flames and warme deires,
I cannot feare new agues in my bloud
Since I have overcome the charmes
Thy beauty had, no other ever can
Have o much power, Therames, thou look't pale,
Is't want of ret?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: No Sir; but that's a torie for your eare— They whiper.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: A trange and happy change.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: All joyes wait on you ever.

sp.speaker: Agl.
sp.l: Orithie
How for thy ake now could I wih
Love were no Mathematick point,
But would admit diviion, that Therames might.
Though at my charge, pay thee the debt he owes thee

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Madam, I loved the Prince, not my elfe;
Since his vertues have their full rewards,
I have my full deires.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What miracles of preervation have wee had?
How wiely have the tars prepar'd you for felicitie?
Nothing endeares a good more than the contemplation
Of the difficultie wee had to attaine to it:
But ee, Nights Empire's out,
And a more glorious aupitiouly does begin;
Let us goe erve the gods, and then prepare
For jollitie, this day Ile borrow from my vowes.
Nor hall it have a common celebration;
Since't mut be,
A high record to all poteritie.— Exeunt omnes.

lg.l: PLays are like Feats, and every Act hould bee
Another Coure, and till varietie:
But in good faith proviion of wit
Is growne of late o difficult to get,
That doe wee what wee can, wee are not able,
Without cold meats to furnih out the Table.
Who knowes but it was needlee too? may bee
'Twas here, as in the Coach-mans trade; and hee
That turnes in the leat compae, hewes mot Art:
How e're, the Poet hopes (Sir) for his part,
You'll like not thoe o much, who hew their skill
In entertainment, as who hew their will.

div.p: THE GOBLINS A Comedy. Preented at the Private Houe in Black-Fryers, by His Majeties ervants.
WRITTEN By Sir JOHN SUCKLING.
LONDON, Printed for Humphrey Moeley, and are to be old at his hop, at the Signe of the Princes Armes in St Pauls Churchyard. MDCXLVI.

lg.l: WIt in a Prologue, Poets jutly may
Stile a new impoition on a Play.
When Shakepeare, Beamont, Fletcher rul'd the Stage,
There carce were ten good pallats in the age,
More curious Cooks then guets; for men would eat
Mot hartily of any kind of meat,
And then what trange variety each Play,
A Feat for Epicures, and that each day.
But marke how odly it is come about,
And how unluckily it now fals out:
The pallats are growne, higher number increas't,
And there wants that which hould make up the Feat;
And yet y'are o unconcionable. You'd have
Forooth of late, that which they never gave,
Banquets before; and after.—
Now pox on him that firt good Prologue writ,
He left a kind of rent charge upon wit;
Which if ucceding Poets faile to pay,
They forfeit all their worth, and thats their play:
Y' have Ladies humors, and y'are growne to that,
You will not like the man lee that his boots and hat
Be right; no play, unlee the Prologue be,
And Epilogue writ to curioitie.
Well (Gentiles)' • is the grievance of the place,
And pray conider't, for here's jut the cae;
The richnee of the ground is gone and pent,
Mens braines grow barren, and you raie the Rent.

div.head: ACT I. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter as to a Duell: Samorat, Philatell, Torcular.

lg.l: BUt my Lords,
May not this harh buinee
Yet be left undone!
Mut you hate me becaue I love your iter;
And can you hate at no lee rate then death?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No, at no lee:
Thou art the blater of our fortunes,
The envious cloud that darknet all our day,
While he thus prodigally, and fondly
Throwes away her love on thee;
She has not wherewithall to pay a debt
Unto the Prince.—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Is this all?

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Faith, what if in hort we doe not thinke
You worthy of her?—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I weare that hall not make a quarrell.
I thinke o too;
'Have urg'd it often to my elfe;
Againt my elfe have worn't as oft to her,
Pray let this atisfie.—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sure (Torcular) he thinks we come to talke
Looke you Sir;— drawes.
And brother ince his friend has fail'd him,
Doe you retire.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Excue me (Philatell)
I have an equall interet in this,
And fortune hall decide it.—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: It will not need, hee's come.—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Mercury protect me! what are thee?
The brothers of the high way!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: A tranger by his habit.—

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: And by his looks a Gentleman.
Sir,—will you make one!
We want a fourth.—

sp.speaker: Or
sp.l: I hall be rob'd with a tricke now!

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: My Lords excue me!
This is not civill.
In what concernes my elfe,
None but my elfe mut uffer.—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: A duell by this light,—
Now has his modetie,
And t'others forwardnes warm'd me— goes towards them.
Gentlemen, I weare a word,
And commonly in readines,
If you want one, peake Sir.— to Samorat.
I doe not feare much uffering.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Y'are noble Sir,
I know not how t'invite you to it;
Yet, there is Jutice on my ide,
And ince you pleae to be a witnee
To our actions, 'tis fit you know our Story.—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: No Story Sir I beeech you,—
The caue is good enough as 'tis,
It may be poil'd i'th telling.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Come we trifle then.—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: It is impoible to preerve I ee
My honor and repect to her.
And ince you know this too my Lord,
It is not handome in you thus to pree me,
But come.—
Torcular beckens to Orabrin.—
Oh! I undertand you Sir.— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: In poture till.—
Oh, y'are mortall then it eemes.— A light wound.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Thou hat undone thy elfe rah man,
For with this bloud thou hat let out a pirit
Will vex thee to thy grave.—

div.stage: Fight agen, Samorat takes away Philatells word, and takes breath, then gives it him.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I'm coole agen,
Here my Lord.—
And let this Preent bind your friendhip.—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Yes thus.— Runs at him.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Treacherous, and low.—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: I have dril'd my gentleman,
I have made as many holes in him
As would inke a Ship Royall
In ight of the Haven:—
How now?— Samorat upon his knee.
S'foot yonder's another going that way too.—
Now have I forgot of which ide I'm on,
No matter.
I'le help the weaket;
There's ome Jutice in that.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: The Villaine ure has laine my brother.
If I have any friends above,
Guide now my hand unto his heart.— Orabrin puts it by, runs at him, Samo teps in.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Hold noble youth!
Detroy me not with kindnee:
Men will ay he could have kil'd me,
And that injutice hould not be
For honours ake, leave us together.—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: 'Tis not my buinee fighting— puts up.
Th'employment's yours Sir:
If you need me,
I am within your call.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: The gods reward thee:—
Now Philatell thy wort.— They fight agen, and cloe, Samo: forces his word.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Hell and the Furies are broke looe upon us,
Shift for your elfe Sir.— Flyes • nto the woods • verall wayes purued by Theeves in Devils habits.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: It will not be,—
My body is a Jade:
I feele it tire, and languih under me.
Thoe thoughts came to my oule
Like Screech-owles to a ick mans window.—

sp.speaker: Thee.
sp.l: Here—here—

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Oh! I am fetcht away alive.-Exeunt. They bend him, and carry him away.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Now the good gods preerve my enes right,
For they were never in more danger:
'Ith name of doubt, what could this be?
Sure 'twas a Conjurer I dealt withall:
And while I thought him buie at his praiers,
'Twas at his circle, levying this Regiment.
Heere they are agen.—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Friend—Stranger—Noble youth—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Heere—heere—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Shift, hift the place,
The wood is dangerous,
As you love afety,
Follow me.— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Th' have left the place,
And yet I cannot find the body any where—
May be he did not kill him then,
But he recover'd trength,
And reacht the Towne—
—It may be not too.—
Oh that this houre could be call'd backe agen.
—But 'tis too late,
And time mut cure the wound that's given by fate.— Exit.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: I'th hape of Lions too ometimes,
And Beares?—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Often Sir.—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Pray unriddle.—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: The wier ort doe thinke them Theeves,
Which but aume thee formes to rob
More powerfully.—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Why does not then the State
Set out ome forces and uppree them?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: It often has (Sir) but without uccee.—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: How o?—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: During the time thoe leavies are abroad,
Not one of them appeares,
There have been
That have attempted under ground;
But of thoe as of the dead
There has been no returne.—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Strange.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: The common people thinke them a race
Of honet and familiar Devills,
For they do hurt to none,
Unlee reited;
They eldome take away but with exchange;
And to the poore they often give,
Returne the hurt, and icke recover'd
Reward, or punih, as they do find caue.—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: How caue?—

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: Why Sir, they blind till thoe they take,
And make them tell the tories of their lives,
Which known, they do accordingly.—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: You make me wonder! Sir,—
How long is't ince they thus have troubled you?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: It was immediately upon
The great deciding day, fought
'Twixt the two pretending families,
The Samorats, and the Orabrins.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Ha! Orabrin?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: But Sir, that torie's ad, and tedious,
W'are entring now the Town,
A place lee afe then were the Woods,
Since Torcular is laine.—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: How S r?—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Yes.—
He was the Brother to the Princes Mitris,
The lov'd one too.
If wee do prize our elves at any rate,
We mut embarque, and change the clime,
There is no afety here.—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Hum.—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: The little tay we make, mut be
In ome darke corner of the Towne:
From whence, the day hurried to th'other world,
Wee'le ally out to order for our journey.
That I am forc't to this, it grieves me not;
But (gentle youth) that you hould for my ake.—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Sir, looe not a thought on that
A torme at Sea threw me on Land,
And now a Storme on Land drives me
To Sea agen.—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Still noble,— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Why; uppoe 'tis to a Wench,
You would not goe with me, would you?—

sp.speaker: Pella.
sp.l: To chue,—to chue,—

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Then there's no remedy.— Flings down his hat, unbuttons himelf drawes.

sp.speaker: Pella.
sp.l: What doet meane?—

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Why? ince I cannot leave you alive,
I will trie to leave you dead.

sp.speaker: Pella.
sp.l: I thanke you kindly Sir, very kindly.
Now the Sedgly cure upon thee,
And the great Fiend, • ide through thee
Booted and Spur'd, with a Sith on his necke;
Pox on thee, I'le ee thee hang'd firt;
S'foot, you hall make none of your fine
Points of honour, up at my charge:
Take your coure if you be o hot.
Be doing,—be doing,— Ex.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: I am got free of him at lat:
There was no other way;
H'as been as troubleome as a woman that
Would be lov'd whether a man would or not:
And h'as watcht me as if he had been
My Creditors Sergeant. If they hould have dipatcht
In the meane time, there would be fine
Opinions of me.—I mut cut his throat
In earnet, if it hould be o.— Ex.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: A prize—A prize—A prize—

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.l: Some duell (Sir) was faught this morning, this
Weakned with loe of blood, we tooke, the ret
Ecap't.—

sp.speaker: Tamoren.
sp.l: Hee's fitter for our Surgeon, then for us,
Hereafter wee'le examine him—

sp.speaker: Thee.
sp.l: A prize—A prize—A prize—(They et them down) Ardelan, Piramant.

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: Bring them, bring them, bring them in,
See if they have mortall Sin,
Pinch them, as you dance about,
Pinch them till the truth come out.—

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: What art?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Extreamely poore, and mierable.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: 'Tis well, 'tis well, proceed,
No body will take that away from thee,
Feare not,—what Country?—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: —Francelia—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Thy name?—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Ardelan.—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: And thine,—

sp.speaker: Pira.
sp.l: Piramant.—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Thy tory,—come—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What tory!—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Thy life, thy life.—(Pinch him)

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Hold hold,—
You hall have it;—(he ighs)
It was upon the great defeat
Given by the Samorats unto the Orabrins,
That the old Prince for afety of the young,
Commit • ed him unto the trut of Garradan,
And ome few ervants more,
'Mongt whom I fil'd a place.—

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: Ha! Garradan!

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: Speake out, and et me nearer;
So; void the place, proceed.—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: We put to Sea, but had carce lot the ight
Of Land, ere we were made a prey
To Pirates, there Garradan
Reiting the firt Boord, chang'd life with death;
With him the ervants too,—
All but my elfe and Piramant.
Under thee Pirats ever ince
Was Orabrin brought up,
And into everall Countries did they carry him.

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: Knew Orabrin himelfe?—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Oh! no, his pirit was too great;
We durt not tell him any thing,
But waited for ome accident
Might throw us on Francelia,
Bout which we hover'd often,
And we were neere it now,
But Heaven decreed it otherwie:—(he ighs)

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: Why dot thou igh?—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Why do I igh? (indeed,)
For teares cannot recall him;
Lat night about the econd watch, the
Winds broke looe,
And vext our Ships o long,
That it began to reele and totter,
And like a drunken man,
Took in o fat his liquor,
That it unke downe i'th place.—

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: How did you cape?—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I bound my elfe unto a mate,
And did advie my Mater to do o,
For which he truck me only,
And aid I did conult too much with feare.—

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: 'Tis a ad tory.—(within there)
Let them have Wine and
Fire,—but hearke you,— (Whipers)

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: A Prize.—A prize,—A prize.—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Set him downe,—

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: —Sings.—
—And for the blew,—
Give him a Cup of Sacke 'twill mend his hew.—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Drunke as I live.— (Pinch him, pinch him.
What art?—

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: I am a Poet,
A poore dabler in Rime.—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Come confee, confee;

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: I do confee, I do want money.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: By the decription hee's a Poet indeed.
Well proceed.— (Pinch him)

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: What d'you meane?—
Pox on you.
Prethee let me alone,
Some Candles here,—
And fill us t'other Quart, and fill us
Rogue, Drawer, the t'other Quart,
Some mall Beere.—
And for the blew,
Give him a Cup of Sack 'twill mend his hew.—

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: Set him by till hee's ober,
Come lett's go ee our Duellit
Dret.— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Hee's omething tall, and for his Chin,
It has no buh below:
Marry a little wooll, as much as an unripe
Peach doth weare;
Jut enough to peake him drawing towards a man.—

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Is he of furie?
Will he foine,
And give the mortall touch?

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Oh no!
He eldome weares his Sword.

sp.speaker: Ser,
sp.l: Topo is the word if he do,
Thy debt, my little Mirmidon.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: A yard and a halfe I aure you without abatement.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: 'Tis well, 'tis wondrous well:
Is he retired into this houe of pleaure?

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: One of thee hee's entred;
'Tis but a little waiting,
You hall find me at the next Taverne.— Exit.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Stand cloe, I here one comming.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: This houe is ure no S • minary for Lucreces,
Then the Matron was o over diligent,
And when I ask't for meate or drinke,
Shee look't as if I had mitooke my elfe,
And cald for a wrong thing,
Well • 'tis but a night, and part of it I'le pend
In eeing of this Towne,
So famous in our Tales at Sea.—

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Looke looke, mufled, and as melancholy after't
As a Gameter upon loe; upon him, upon him,

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: How now my friends,
Why do you ue me thus?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Quietly; 'twill be your bet way

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Bet way? for what?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Why, 'tis your bet way,
Becaue there will be no other,
Topo is the word,
And you mut along.—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Is that the word?
Why then, this is my Sword— (Run away)

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Murder, murder, murder;
H'as kil'd the Princes Officer,
Murder—Murder—Murder.—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: I mut not tay,
I heare them warme.— Exit.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Where is he, where is he?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Here,—here—oh a Manmender,
A Manmender,
Has broacht me in o many places,
All the Liquor in my body will run out.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: In good ooth (neighbour) has tapt you at the
Wrong end too;
He has been buie with you here behind;
As one would ay, lend a hand, ome of you,
And the ret follow me.— Exeunt

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Still puru'd!
Which way now?
I ee no paage;
I mut attempt this wall,—
Oh—a luckie doore.
And open.— Exit.

lg.l: Where am I now?
A garden, and a handome houe,
If't be thy will a Porch too't,
And I'm made;
'Twill be the better lodging of the two.— (goes to the Porch)

sp.speaker: Phemilia.
sp.l: Oh! welcome, welcome Sir,
My Lady hath been in uch frights for you.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Hum! for me?—

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: And thought you would not come to night:

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Troth, I might very well have fail'd her:

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Shee's in the Gallery alone i'th darke.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Good, very good.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: And is o melancholly,—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Hum.—

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Have you hut the Garden doores?
Come I'le bring you to her, enter, enter.—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Yes, I will enter:
He who has lot himelfe makes no great venter.— Exit.

div.head: ACT II.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: OH welcome, welcome, as open aire to prioners,
I have had uch feares for you.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Shees warme, and oft as lovers language:
Shee poke too, pretilie;
Now have I forgot all the danger I was in.—

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: What have you done to day (my better part)

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Kind little Rogue!
I could ay the finet things to her mee thinks,
But then hee would dicover me,
The bet way will be to fall too quietly.— (kies her)

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: How now my Samorat,
What aucy heat hath tolne into thy bloud,
And heightned thee to this?
I feare you are not well.—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: S'foot! 'tis a Platonique:
Now cannot I o much as talke that way neither.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Why are you ilent, Sir?
Come I know you have been in the field to day.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: How does hee know that?—

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: If you have kill'd my brother, peake:
It is no new thing that true Love
Should be unfortunate:

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: 'Twas her brother I kill'd then,
Would I were with my Devils agen:
I got well of them,
That will be here impoible.—

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Oh! Madam, Madam,
Y'are undone;
The garden walls are cal'd,
A floud of people are entring th'houe.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Good—why here's varietie of ruine yet.—

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: 'Tis o,
The Feet of Jutice
Like to thoe of time,
Move quick,
And will detroy I feare as ure:
Oh Sir, what will you do,
There is no ventring forrh,
My Cloet is the afet,
Enter there,
While I goe down and meet their fu • ie
Hinder the earch if poible.— Exit.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Her Cloet,
Yea where's that?
And, if I could find it,
What hould I do there?
Shee will returne,—
I will venture out.— Exit.

div.stage: Enter the Prince, Philatell Phontrell, Companie, Muique.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: The lightet aires; 'twill make them
More ecure,—
Upon my life hee'le viite her to night.— Muick plaies and ings.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Nor hee, nor any leer light
Appeares,—
The calme and ilence 'bout the place,
Perwardes me hee does leep.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: It may be not, but hold,
It is enough,—let us retire
Behind this Pillar, Phontrell, is thy place,
As thou didt love thy Mater hew thy care,
You to th'other Gate,
There's thy Ladder.— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Come forth my Samorat, come forth,
Our feares were fale,
It was the Prince with Muicke,
Samorat, Samorat.,
He leepes,—Samorat,
Or ele hee's gon to find me out
I'th Gallery, Samorat, Samorat, it mut be o.— Exit.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: This houe is full of Threholds,
And Trap-doores,
I have been i'th Cellar,
Where the Maids lie too,
I laid my hand groping for my way
Upon one of them,
And hee began to queake,
Would I were at Sea agen i'th torme,
Oh! a doore:
Though the Devill were the Porter,
And kept the Gate, I'de out.—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Ha! guarded? taken in a trap?
Nay, I will out,
And there's no other
But this.— (Retires and d • a • es, runs at him Another p • e they cloe.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Philatell in ambuh on my life-

div.stage: Enter Sabrina, and Phemillia with a light

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Where hould he be?
Ha!—
Good Heavens what pectacle is this? my Samorat!
Some apparition ure,— (They dicover one another • y the light, throw away their weapons, and e • b • ace.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: My noble friend,
What angry, and malicious Planet.
Govern'd at this point of time!—

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: (My wonder does grow higher)

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: That which governes ever:

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: It does amaze me Sir, to find you here.
How entred you this place?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Forc't by unruly men it'h treet.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Now the mitake is plaine.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Are you not hurt?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: No,—but you bleed?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: I do indeed,
But 'tis not here,
This is a cratch,
It is within to ee this beauty;
For by all circumtance, it was her brother,
Whom my unlucky Sword found out to day.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Oh! my too cruell fancy.— (Weepes)

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: It was indeed thy Sword,
But not thy fault,
I am the caue of all thee ills.
Why d'you weep Sabrina!—

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Unkind unto thy elfe, and me,
The tempet, this ad newes has rai'd within me
I would have laid with Sheares,
But thou diturb't me,
Oh! Samorat.
Had't thou conulted but with love as much
As honour, this had never been.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I have no love for thee that has not had
So trict an union with honour till,
That in all things they were concern'd alike,
And if there could be a diviion made,
It would be found
Honour had here the leaner hare:
'Twas love that told me 'twas unfit
That you hould love a Coward.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Thee handome words are now
As if one bound up wounds with ilke,
Or with fine knots,
Which do not helpe the cure,
Or make it heale the ooner:
Oh! Samorat this accident
Lies on our love,
Like to ome foule dieae,
Which though it kill it not,
Yet wil't detroy the beauty;
Difigur't o,
That't will looke ugly to th' world hereafter.—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Mut then the Acts of Fate be crimes of men?
And hall a death he pul'd upon himelfe,
Be laid on others?
Remember Sweet, how often
You have aid it in the face of Heaven,
That 'twas no love,
Which length of time, or cruelty of chance,
Could leen, or remove,
Oh kill me not that way Sabrina,
This is the nobler;
Take it, and give it entrance any where— Kneeles and preents his Sword.
But here,
For you o fill that plaee,
That you mut wound your elfe.—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Am I o light a thing?
So bankerupt?
So unanwerable in this world?
That being principally i'th debt,
Another mut be cal'd upon,
And I not once look't after?
Madam why d'you throw away your Teares]
On one that's irrecoverable?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Why? therefore Sir,
Becaue hee's irrecoverable.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: But why on him?
He did not make him o.

sp.speaker: Sab
sp.l: I do confee my anger is unjut,
But not my orow Sir,
Forgive thee tear •• my Samorat,
The debts of nature mut be paid,
Though from the tocke of love:
Should they not Sir?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Yes.—
But thus the precious minutes pae,
And time, e're I have breath'd the ighs,
Due to our parting,
Will be calling for me.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Parting?—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Oh yes Sabrina, I mut part,
As day does from the world,
Not to returne till night be gone,
Till this darke Cloud be over,
Here to be found,
Were foolihly to make a preent
Of my life unto mine enemy,
Retire into thy Chamber faire,
There thou halt know all.—

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: I know too much already.— Exeunt.

lg.l: Hold rope for me, and then hold rope for him.
Why, this is the widome of the Law now,
A Prince looes a ubject, and does not
Think himelfe paid for the lo • ,
Till he looes another:
Well I will do my endeavour
To make him a aver;
• or this was Samorat..— Exit.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Let it bleed on,—you hall not tirre
I weare.—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Now by the friendhip that I owe thee,
And the Gods beide, I will
Noble youth, were there no danger in thy wound,
Yet would the loe of bloud make thee
Unfit for travell,
My ervants waite me for direction,
With them my Surgeon, I'le bring him intantly,
Pray go back.— Exit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: There.— (places them at the door • .
You to the other Gate,
The ret follow me.— Ex.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Hearke a noie Sir.
This tread's too loud to be my Samorats.

sp.speaker: Searchers.
sp.l: (Which way?—which way)— (to them.
Some villany in hand,
Step in here Sir, quick, quick.— Locks him into her Cloet.

div.stage: Enter Philatell, Guard, and pae ore the Stage.

sp.speaker: Phi
sp.l: Looke every where.— (Philatell dragging out his Siter.
Protect thy brothers murderer?
Tell me where thou hat hid him,
Or by my fathers ahes I will earch
In every veine thou hat about thee, for him.— (O • ab • in • ounces thri • e • t the doore, it • l •• s op •• .

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Ere uch a villany hould be
The Gods would lend unto a ingle arme
Such trength, it hould have power to punih
An Armie, uch as thou art.—

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Oh! are you here Sir?—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Yes I am here Sir.— (ight)

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Kill her.— (Shee interpos'd

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Oh! ave thy elfe faire excellence,
And leave me to my Fate.—
Bae— Comes behind him, •• t • hes bold of his Armes.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: So bring him one,
The other is not far,— Exeunt.

lg.l: To the Garden walls,
And meet my Samorat,
Tell him, oh tell him any thing,
Charge him by all our loves
He intantly take Hore,
And put to Sea,
There is more afety in a torme,
Then where my brother is.— Exeunt.

div.head: ACT III.

sp.speaker: Thee.
sp.l: A Prize—A prize, A prize,

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Bring him forth, bring him forth; (They dance about him and ing.
Welcome w •• come, mortall wight,
To the • anion of the night:
Good or bad, thy life dicover
Truly all thy deeds declare;
For about thee Spirits hover
That can tell, tell what they are.
—Pinch him, if he peake not true,
—Pinch him, pinch him black and blew,

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Stra
sp.l: I was a man.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Of whence?—

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: • he Court.—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Whether now bound?

sp.speaker: Str,
sp.l: To my owne houe.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Thy name?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Stramador.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Oh you fill a place about his Grace,
And keep out men of parts, d'you not?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Yes.—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: A foolih Utenill of State,
Which like old Plate upon a Gaudy day,
'Sbrought forth to make a how, and that is all;
For of no ue y'are, y'had bet deny this:

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Oh no!—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Or that you do want wit,
And then talke loud to make that pae for it?
You thinke there is no wiedom but in forme;
Nor any knowledge like to that of whipers:—

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Right, right.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Then you can hate, and fawn upon a man
At the ame time,
And dare not urge the vices of another,
You are o foule your elfe;
So the Prince eldome heares truth.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Oh! very eldome.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: And did you never give his Grace odde Councels.
And when you aw they did not proper,
Perwade him take them on himelfe.—

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Yes, yes, often.—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Get baths of Sulphur quick,
And flaming oyles,
This crime is new, and will deerve it.
He has inverted all the rule of State;
Confoun • ed policie,
There is ome rea • on why a Subject
But why a Prince hould • ear •
The faults of's Miniters, none, none at
All.—Cauldrons of Brimtone there.

sp.speaker: Thee.
sp.l: Great Judge of this infe • nall p • ace
Allow him yet the mercy of the Cou • t.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Kind Devill.—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Let him be boyl'd in calding lead a while
T'enure, and to prepare him for the other.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Oh! heare me, heare me,

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Stay!
Now I have better thought upon't,
He hall to earth agen:
For villanie is catching, and will pread:
He will enlarge our Empire much,
Then w'are ure of him at any time,
So 'tis enough—where's our Governour?— Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Goalor, Samorat, Naurat, Pellegrin, three others in diguie

sp.speaker: Iai.
sp.l: His haire curles naturally,
A handome youth.—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: The ame,— (Drinkes to him.
Is there no peaking with him?
He owes me a trifling umme.—

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: Sure Sir the debt is omething deperate,
There is no hopes he will be brought
To cleare with the world,
He truck me but for perwading him
To make even with Heaven,
He is as urly as an old Lion,
And as ullen as a Bullfinch,
He never eate ince he was taken.— Gentlemen

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I mut needs peake with him,
Heark in the eare.—

sp.speaker: Iai.
sp.l: Not for all the world.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Nay I do but motion uch a thing,

sp.speaker: Iai.
sp.l: Is this the buinee Gentlemen?
Fare you well.—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: There is no choice of waies then.— (Run after him, draw their dag • ers, et • t t • his B • et.
Stir not, if thou but think't a noie,
Or breath't aloud, thou breath' • t thy lat.
So bind him now.—
Undoe,
Quickly, quickly,
His Jerkin, his Hat.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: What will you do?
None of thee Beards will erve,
There's not an eye of white in them.

sp.speaker: Pell.
sp.l: Pull out the Silver'd ones in his
And ticke them in the other.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Cut them, cut them out,
The buh will ute well enough
With a grace till.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Deperate wounds mut have deperate
Cures, extreames mut thus be erv'd,—
You know your parts,
Feare not, let us alone.—
Sings a Catch.
Some drinke,—what Boy,—ome drinke—
Fill it up, fill it up to the brinke,
When the Pots crie clinke,
And the Pockets chinke,
Then 'tis a merry world.
To the bet, to the bet, have at her,
And a Pox take the Woman-hater.—
The Prince of darknee is a Gentleman,
Mahu, Mohu is his name,
How d'you Sir?
You gape as you were leepy,
Good faith he lookes like an— O yes.

sp.speaker: Pell
sp.l: Or as if he had overtrain'd himelfe
At a deep note in a Ballad.—

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: What think you of an Oyter at a low ebb?
Some liquor for him;
You will not be a Pimpe for life you Rogue,
Nor hold a doore to ave a Gentleman,
You are—Pox on him, what is he Pellagrin?
If you love me, let's tifle him,
And ay 'twas a udden judgement upon him
For wearing; the poture will confirme it.

sp.speaker: Pell.
sp.l: We're in excellent humour,
Let's have another bottle,
And give out that Anne my wife is dead,
Shall I Gentlemen?—

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Rare Rogue in Buckram,
Let me bite thee,
Before me thou halt go out wit,
And upon as good termes,
As ome of thoe in the Ballad too.—

sp.speaker: Pell.
sp.l: Shall I o?—Why then foutree for the Guie,
Saines hall accrew, and ours hall be,
The black ey'd beauties of the time,
I'le ticke you for old ends of Plaies:—
They ing,—
A Round,—A Round,—A Round,—
A Round,—A Round,—A Round— (Knock)
Some bodie's at doore.
Preethee, preethee, Sirra, Sirra,
Trie thy skill.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Who's there.

sp.speaker: Meen.
sp.l: One Sturgelot a Jaylor here?—

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Such a on there was my friend,
But hee's gone above an houre ago:
Now did this Rogue whisper in his heart
That's a lie,—and for that very reaon,
I'le cut his throat.—

sp.speaker: Pell.
sp.l: No prethee now,—for thinking?
Thou halt not take the paines,
The Law hall do't—

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: How,—how?—

sp.speaker: Pell.
sp.l: Marry wee'le write it over when wee're gone,
He joyn'd in the plot, and put himelfe
Into this poture, meerely to diguie it to
The world.—

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Excellent,
Here's to thee for that conceit,
Wee hould have made rare Statemen,
We are o witty in our michiefe.
Another ong, and o let's go,
It will be time.
—Sing.—
A health to the Nut browne Lae,
With the hazell eyes let it pae.
Shee that has good eyes
Has good thighs,
Let it pae,—let it pae.—
A much to the lively Grey,
'Tis as good it'h night as the day,
Shee that has good eyes,
Has good thighs,
Drinke away,—drinke away.—
I pledge, I pledge, what ho ome Wine,
Here's to thine, and to thine,
The colours are Divine.—
But oh the blacke, the black
Give me as much agen, and let't be Sacke:
Shee that has good Eyes,
Has good Thighs,
And it may be a better knack.—

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: A reckoning Boy.— (They knock)
There.— (paies him)
Dot heare
Here's a friend of ours 'has forgotten himelfe
A little (as they call it)
The Wine has got into his head,
As the frot into a hand, he is benum'd,
And has no ue of himelfe for the preent.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Hum Sir.— ( •• l • s.)

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Prethee lock the dore, and when he
Comes t' himelfe,
Tell him he hall find us at the old place,
He knowes where.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I will Sir.— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: To di • ! yea what's that?
For yet I never thought on't eriouly;
It may be 'tis.—hum.—
It may be 'tis not too.—
sp.stage: Enter Samorat, as Goaler undoes his Fetters.
sp.l: Ha.—(as amaz'd.)
What happy interceion wrought this change?
To whoe kind prayers owe I this my friend?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Unto thy vertue—Noble youth
The Gods delight in that as well as praiers.
I am—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Nay, nay,—
Be what thou wilt,
I will not quetion't:
Undoe, undoe.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Thy friend Samorat.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Lay by thy wonder,
And put on thee cloathes,
In this diguie thou'lt pae unto the
Prion-gates, there you hall finde
One that is taught to know you;
He will conduct you to the corner
Of the wood, and there my hores waite
Us.—
I'le throw this Goaler off in ome odde place,

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: My better Angell.— Exennt.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: It is 'een as hard a world for Theeves
As honet men,—nothing to be got—
No prize tirring.—

sp.speaker: 1. Thee.
sp.l: None, but one with hores,
Who eem'd to tay for ome
That were to come,
And that has made us waite thus long.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: A leane dayes worke, but what remedie?
Lawyers, that rob men with their owne conent,
Have had the ame:
Come, call in our Perdues,
We will away.— (they whitle.)

div.stage: Enter Orabrin, as eeking the hores.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: I heare them now,
Yonder they are.—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Hallow, who are thee?
Any of ours?

sp.speaker: Thee.
sp.l: No, tand cloe,
They hall be preently,
Yeeld—yeeld.—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Agen betraid? there is no end of my misfortune,
Michiefe vexes me
Like a quotidian,
It intermits a little, and returnes
E're I have lot the memory of
My former fit.—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Sentences, entences,
A way with him—A way with him.— Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Goaler, Drawers, over the Stage.

sp.speaker: Jailer.
sp.l: I am the Goaler, undone, undone,
Conpiracie, a cheat, my prioner, my prioner.— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: No men?—nor hores?—
Some trange mitake,—
May it be, th' are heltred in the wood.—

div.stage: Enter Peridor and other Theeves, examining the young Lord Torcular that was hurt.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.l: And if a Lady did but tep aide,
To fetch a Maque or o,
You follow'd after till,
As if hee had gone proud?
Ha; i't not o?—

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Yes.—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: And if you were u'd but civillie in a place,
You gave out doubtfull words upon't,
To make men thinke you did enjoy.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Oh! yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Made love to every peece of cried-up beauty
And wore the ame things over to them.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: The very ame.—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Abominable.
Had he but worne new things, yet't had been
Tollerable.—
Reades the umme of the Confeion

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Let me ee—let me ee.
Hum.
Court Ladies Eight,
Of which two great ones.—
Country Ladies twelve.
Tearmers all.—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Is this right?

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Very right.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Citizens wives of everall trades,
He cannot count them.—
Chamber maides, and Country wenches,
About thirty:—
Of which the greater part,
The night before th'were married,
Or ele upon the day:

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: A modet reckoning, is this all?—

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: No.—
I will be jut t'a cruple.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Well aid,—well aid,—
Out with it.—

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Put down two old Ladies more.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I'th name of wonder,
How could he thinke of old,
In uch variety of young?

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Alas I could never be quiet for them.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Poore Gentleman.
Well what's to be done with him now?
Shall he be thrown into the Cauldron
With the Cuckolds,
Or with the Jealous?
That's the hotter place.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Thou mitake • 't,
'Tis the ame, they go together till:
Jealous and Cuckolds differ no otherwie
Then Sheriffe and Alderman;
A little time makes th'one th'other.
What thinke you of Gelding him,
And ending him to earth agen,
Amongt his women?
'Twood be like throwing a dead fly
Into an Ants net.
There would be uch tearing, pulling,
And getting up upon him,
They would worry the poore thing
To death,—

sp.speaker: Th. 1.
sp.l: Excellent,
Or leave a tring as they do ometimes
In young Colts:
Deire and impotence,
Would be a rare punihment.
Fie, fie, the common dieae of age,
A very old man has it.
A prize,—A prize,—A prize, (Hornes blow, Brae Plots, &c.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: This mut be Hell by the noie

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: Set him down, et him down;
Bring forth the newet wrack,
And flaming pinching Irons,
This is a tubborne peece of fleh,
'Twould have broke looe.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: So, this comes of wihing my elfe
With Divels agen.—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What art?—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: The lave of Chaunce,
One of Fortunes fooles;
A thing hee kept alive on earth
To make her port,

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Thy name?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Orabrin.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Ha! he that liv'd with Pirats?
Was lately in a torme?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: The very ame.—

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: Such repect as you have paid to me,— (whipers)
Prepare to Revels, all that can be thought on:
But let each man till keep his hape.— (Exit.)
They unbind him, all bow to him,

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Ha!
Another fale mile of Fortune?— (They bring out everall uite of cloathes, and a banquets
Is this the place the gowned Clearkes
Do fright men o on earth with?
Would I had been here before.
Mater Devill;
To whoe ue are thee et out?

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: To yours Sir.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: I'le make bold to change a little— (takes a hat.
Could you not affoord a good plaine Sword (drees himelf.
To all this gallantry?—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Wee'le ee Sir.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: A thouand times civiller then men,
And better natur'd.

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: All leave the roome.
I like not this.— Ex.

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: Cupid do thou the ret,
A blunter arrow, and but lackly drawne,
Would perfect what's begun,
When young and handome meet,
—The work's halfe done.—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: She cannot be lee then a goddee;
And 't mut be Proerpine:
I'le peake to her, though Pluto's elfe tood by,
Thou beauteous Queene of this darke world,
That mak't a place o like a hell,
So like a Heaven, intruct me
In what forme I mut approach thee,
And how adore thee?—

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: Tell me what thou art firt:
For uch a creature
Mine eyes did never yet behold.—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: I am that which they name above a man:
I'th watry Elements I much have liv'd,
And there they terme me Orabrin.
Have you a name too?—

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: Why doe you aske?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Becaue I'de call upon it in a torme,
And ave a Ship from perihing ometimes.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: 'Tis Reginella.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Are you a woman too?
I never was in earnet untill now.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: I know not what I am,
For like my elfe I never yet aw any.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Nor ever hall.
Oh! how came you hither?
Sure you were betraied.
Will you leave this place,
And live with uch as I am?

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: Why may not you live here with me?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Yes.—
But I'de carry thee where there is a glorious light,
Where all above is pread a Canopie,
Studded with twinckling Gems,
Beauteous as Lovers eies;
And underneath Carpets of • lowry Meads
To tread on.—
A thouand thouand pleaures
Which this place can ne're affoord thee.—

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Yes indeed—
I'le bring thee unto hady walkes,
And Groves fring'd with Silver purling treams,
Where thou halt heare oft feathered Queriters
Sing weetly to thee of their own accord.
I'le fill thy lap with early flowers;
And whilt thou bind't them up myterious waies,
I'le tell thee pretty tales, and igh by thee:
Thus pree thy hand and warme it thus with kies

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: Will you indeed?—

div.stage: Enter King Per. above with others.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: Fond Girle:
Her rahnee ullies the glory of her beauty,
'Twil make the conquet cheape,
And weaken my deignes,
Go part them intantly.
And bind him as before;
Be you his keeper Peridore.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Yes, I will keep him.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Her eyes like lightning hoot into my heart
They'le melt it into nothing,
Eere I can preent it to her,
Sweet Excellence.—

lg.l: Ha! why is this hatefull curtaine drawne before my eyes?
If I have inn'd, give me ome other punihment;
Let me but looke on her till,
And double it, oh whether, whether doe you hurry me?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Madam you mut in.— (carry him away.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.l: Ay me, what's this?—

Mut!—
• x.

sp.speaker: Th. 1.
sp.l: We have had uch port;
Yonder's the raret Poet without,
Has made all his confeion in blanke vere:
Not left a God, nor a Goddee in Heaven,
Has made uch a decription of Stix,
And the Ferry,
And verily thinks has pat them.
Enquires for the blet hades,
And askes much after certaine Brittih blades,
One Shakepeare and Fletcher:
And grew o peremptory at lat,
He would be carried where they were.

sp.speaker: Th. 2.
sp.l: And what did you with him?

sp.speaker: Th. 1.
sp.l: Mounting him upon a Cowle-taffe,
Which (toing him omething high)
He apprehended to be P • gaus.
So we have left him to tell trange lies,
Which hee'le turne into vere;
And ome wie people hereafter into Religion.

div.head: ACT IV.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: GGod faith 'tis wondrous well,
We have ee'n done like eager diputers;
And with much adoe
Are got to be jut where we were.
This is the corner of the wood.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Ha! 'tis indeed.—

sp.speaker: P • ll.
sp.l: Had we no walking • ire,
Nor awcerey'd Devill of thee woods that led us?
No • am I as weary
As a married man after the firt weeke.
And have no more deire to move forwards,
Then a Pot-hore that has pat his Stage.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: 'Sfoot yonder's the night too, tealing away
With her blacke gowne about her:
Like a kind wench, that had taid out the
Lat minute with a man.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: What hall we doe, Gentlemen?
I apprehend falling into this Jaylors
Hands trangely; hee'd ue us wore
Then we did him.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: And that was ill enough of Concience:
What thinke you of turning Beggars?
Many good Gentlemen have don't: or Theeves?

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: That's the ame thing at Court:
Begging is but a kind of robbing th' Exchequer.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Looke foure fathome and a halfe OOS—
In contemplation of his Mitres:
There's a Feat, you and I are out now Pellegrin;
'Tis a pretty tricke, this enjoyning in abence.
What a rare invention 'twood be,
If a man could find out a way to make it reall.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: Dot thinke there's nothing in't as tis?

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Nothing, nothing.
Did't never heare of a dead Alexander,
Rais'd to talke with a man?
Love's a learned Conjurer,
And with the glae of Fancie will doe as trange things?
You thrut out a hand,
Your Mitree thruts out another:
You hake that hand that hakes you agen:
You put out a lip; he puts out hers:
Talke to her, he hall anwer you;
Marrie, when you come to grape all this,
It is but ayer. (As out of his Study.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: It was unluckie,—
Gentlemen, the day appeares,
This is no place to tay in;
Let's to ome neighbouring Cottage,
May be the Searchers will neglect
The neerer places,
And this will but advance unto our afety.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Who are there?

sp.speaker: Fid. 1.
sp.l: Now if the pirit of melancholy hould poee them

sp.speaker: F. 2.
sp.l: Why if it hould,
An honourable retreate.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: I have the raret fancie in my head,—
Whether are you bound my friends o early?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: To a Wedding Sir.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: A Wedding?
I told you o.
Whoe?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: A Country wenches here hard by,
One Erblins daughter.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Good: Erbl • n: the very place.
To ee how things fall out.
Hold, here's money for you.
Harke you, you mut ait me in a mall deigne.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: What do't meane?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Let me alone,
I have a plot upon a wench.—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Your Worhip is merry.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Yes faith, to ee her only.
Looke you, ome of you hall go back to 'th' Towne,
And leave us your Coats,
My friend and I am excellent at a little Intrument,
And then wee'l ing catches.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: I undertand thee not;
Thou hat no more forecat then a Squirrell
And hat lee wie conideration about thee.
Is there a way afer then this!
Dot thinke what we have done
Will not be pread beyond this place with ev'ry light.
Should we now enter any houe
Thus near the Towne, and tay all day,
Twould be upitious: What pretence have we?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: He peaks reaon Samorat.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: I doe not like it.
Should any thing fall out 'twould not looke well,
I'de not be found o much out of my elfe,
So far from home as this diguie would make me,
Almot for certainty of afety.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Certainty? Why, this will give it us,
Pray let me governe once.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Well, you uffered firt with me,
Now 'tis my turne.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Prethee name not uffering,

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Come, come, your Coats,
Our Beards will uite rarely to them:
There's more money,
Not a word of any thing as you tender—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: O Sir.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: And ee you carry't gravely too.—
Now afore me Pellagrins rarely tranlated.
'Sfoot they'l apprehend the head of the Bae Violl
As oone as thee;
Thou art o likely,
Only I mut confee, that has a little the better face,

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Has it o?—
Pox on thee, thou look't like I cannot tell what.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Why, o I would foole,
Th' end of my diguie is to have none
Know what I am:
Looke, looke, a Devill ayring himelf. (Enter a Divell.
I'le catch him like a Mole ere he can get under ground.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Nahorat, Nahorat.—

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Pox on that noie, hee's earth't.
Prethee let's watch him and ee
Whether hee'le heave agen.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Ar't madde?—

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: By this light, three or foure of their skins
And wee'd rob • e.
'I would be the better way.—
Come, come, let's go— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Let the Hore s ••• t about this place,
Weele make a earch within— Ex.

lg.l: Now dipere
I'th hollow of the wood,
Wee'le meet agen.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Who goes there?
Speake,—Oh! th'are Fidlers.—
Sawe you no Men nor Hore
I'th wood to day,—as you came along.

div.stage: (Nahorat puls one of the Fidlers by the skirt)

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Speake, peake Rogue.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: None Sir,—

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Pae on.— Ex.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Gentlemen what ay you to th'invention now,
I'm a Rogue if I do not think
I was deign'd for the Helme of State,
I am o full of nimble Stratagems:
That I hould have ordered affaires, and
Carried it againt the treame of a Faction,
With as much eae as a Skippar,
Would laver againt the wind.— Ex.

div.stage: Enter Captaine and Soldiers meet agen.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: What, no newes of any?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: No,—not a man tirring.
Sa how, away,—away.—

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: What, any dicovery?

sp.speaker: 1. Sol.
sp.l: Yes, the Hore has taid three fellowes,
Fidlers they call themelves;
There's omething in't; they looke upitiouly;
One of them has offer'd at confeion once or twice,
Like a weake tomacke at vomiting,
But 'twould not out.—

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: A little cold Iron thrut downe his throat
Will fetch it up.—
I am excellent at dicoverie,
And can draw a ecret out of a Knave,
With as much dexterity as a Barber-Surgeon
Woo'd a hollow tooth.
Let's joyne forces with them.— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Sure 'tis eternall night with me;
Would this were all too—
For I begin to thinke the ret is true,
Which I have read in books,
And that there's more to follow.—

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: Sure this is he.— (She unbinds him.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: The pure and firt created Light
Broke through the Chaos thus.—
Keep off, keep off thou brighter Excellence,
Thou faire Divinity: If thou com't neere,
(So tempting is the hape thou now aum't)
I hall grow awcy in deire agen,
And entertaine bold hopes which will but draw
More, and freh punihment upon me.—

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: I ee y' are angry Sir:
But if you kill me too, I meant no ill:
That which brought me hither,
Was a deire I have to be with you,
Rather then thoe I live with: This is all
Beleeve't.—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: With me? Oh thou kind Innocence!
Witnee all that can punih falhood,
That I could live with thee,
Even in this darke and narrow prion:
And thinke all happinee confin'd within the wals—
Oh, hadt thou but as much of Love as I.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: Of Love? What's that?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Why 'tis a thing that's had before 'tis knowne:
A gentle flame that teales into a heart,
And makes it like one object • o, that it carce cares
For any other delights, when that is preent:
And is in paine when 't's gone thinks of that alone,
And quarrels with all other thoughts that would
Intrude and o divert it.—

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: If this be Love, ure I have ome of it,
It is no ill thing, is it Sir?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Oh mot Divine,
The bet of all the gods trangely abound in't,
And Mortals could not live without it:
It is the oule of vertue, and the life of life.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: Sure I hould learne it Sir, if you would teach it.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Alas, thou taught't it me;
It came with looking thus.— (They gaze upon one another.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I will no longer be conceal'd,
But tell her what I am,
Before this mooth fac'd youth
Hath taken all the roome
Up in her heart,
Ha! unbound! and ure by her!
Hell and Furies.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: What ho—within there— Enter other Theeves.
Practie ecapes?
Get me new yrons to load him unto death.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: I am o us'd to this,
It takes away the ene of it:
I cannot thinke it trange.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: Alas, he never did intend to goe.
Ue him for my ake kindly:
I was not wont to be deny'd.
Ah me! they are hard hearted all.
What hall I doe? I'le to my Governour,
Hee'l not be thus cruell.— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: 'Tis a rare wench, he 'ith blew tockings:
What a complexion he had when he was warme—
'Tis a hard quetion of thee Country wenches,
Which are impler, their beauties or themelves.
There's as much difference betwixt
A Towne-Lady, and one of thee,
As there is betwixt a wilde Pheaant and a tame.

sp.speaker: Pell.
sp.l: Right:—
There goes uch eening, wahing, perfuming,
Da • bing, to th' other that they are the leat part
Of themelves.
Indeed the • e's o much auce, a man cannot tate the meat.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Let me kie thee for that;
By this light I hate a woman dret up to her height,
Wore then I doe Sugar with Muskadine:
It leaves no roome for me to imagine:
I could improve her if he were mine:
It looks like a Jade with his • ayle tyed up with ribbons,
Going to a • ayre to be • old.

sp.speaker: Pell.
sp.l: No, no, thou hatet it out of another reaon, Nahorat.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Prethee, what's that?

sp.speaker: Pell.
sp.l: Why th'are o ine, th'are of no ue that day.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Pellegrin is in good feeling.
Sirra, did't marke the Lae 'ith green upon yellow,
How he bridled in her head,
And danc't a troake in, and a troake out,
Like a young Fillet training to a pace.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: And how he kit,
As if he had been ealing and delivering her elf up
To the ue of him that came lat,
Parted with her weet-hearts lips till
As unwillingly, and unto wardly,
As • oft Wax from a dry Seale.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: True; and when he kies a Gentleman,
She makes a Curtey, as who hould ay,
The favour was on his ide.
What dull fooles are we to beiege a face
Three moneths for that trifle.
Sometimes it holds out longer,—
And then this is the weeter fleh too,—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: You hall have hores ready at the time,
And good ones too (if there be truth in drinke)
And for your letters, they are there by this.—

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: An excellent Officer.—

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.l: Tut, tut, tut,
That's a good one y'faith, not dance?
Come, come, trike up. (Enter ouldiers mufled up in their cloaks.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Who are thoe that eye us o everely?
Belong they to the wedding?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: I know 'em not.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Gentlemen, wil't pleae you dance.— (Offer their women.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: No, keep your women, wee'l take out others here.
Samorat, if I mitake not.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Ha! betraid?— (A bule.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: How now! what's the matter? abue our Fidlers?

sp.speaker: 2 Sol.
sp.l: Thee are no Fidlers, fools obey the Princes officers,
Unlee you deire to goe to prion too.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: The thought of what mut follow diquiets not at all:
But tamely thus to be urpriz'd
In o unhandome a diguie?— (They carry him away

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: I't ee'n o? Why then,
Farewell the plumed Troops, and the big Wars,
Which made ambition vertue.—

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: I, I, Let them goe, let them goe.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: Have you ever a tratagem Naharot?
'Twood be very eaonable. What thinke you now?
Are you deign'd for the helme of State?
Can you laver againt this Tempet?

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Prethee let me alone, I am thinking for life.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Yes, 'tis for life indeed, would 'twere not.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: This is very trange; Let's follow after,
And ee if we can undertand it.— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: A meere Phantame
Rais'd by Art to trie thee.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Good kind Devill,
Trie me once more.
Help me to the ight of this Phantame agen.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Thou art undone,
Wer't thou not amorous
In th' other world?
Did't not love women?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Who did hate them?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Why there's it;
Thou thought't there was no danger in the inne,
Becaue 'twas common.
Above the halfe of that vat multitude
Which fils this place, Women ent hither:
And they are highliet puniht till,
That love the handomet.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: A very lying Devill this
Certainly.—

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: All that had their women with you,
Suffer with us.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: By your friendhips favour though,
There's no jutice in that:
Some of them uffered enough
In all concience by 'em there.—

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Oh, this is now your mirth:
But when you hall be pinch't
Into a gellie,
Or made into a crampe all over,
Thee will be ad truths.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: He talkes odly now, I doe not like it.
Do't heare?—
Prethee exchange ome of thy good counell
For deeds.
If thou bee't an honet Devill,
(As thou eem't to be)
Put a word into my hand,
And help me to the ight of this
Apparition agen.—

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Well, ome thing I'le doe for thee,
Or rather for my elfe.— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: 1. D.
sp.l: Come, let's goe relieve our Poet.

sp.speaker: 2. D.
sp.l: How, relieve him? hee's releas't; is he not?

sp.speaker: 1. D.
sp.l: No, no;
Berat bethought himelfe at the mouth of the Cave,
And found he would be neceary to our Maque too night.
We have et him with his feet in a great tub of water,
In which he dabbles and beleeves it to be Helicon:
There hee's contriving i'th honour of Mercury,
Who I have told him comes this night of a meage
From Jupiter to Pluto, and is feated here by him.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Oh, they have fetcht him off.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Carer per o lo carer,
Or he that made the fairie Queene.

sp.speaker: 1 Th.
sp.l: No, none of thee:
They are by themelves in ome other place;
But here's he that writ Tamerlane.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: I beeech you bring me to him,
There's omething in his Scene
Betwixt the Emprees a little high and clowdie,
I would reolve my elfe.

sp.speaker: 1 Th.
sp.l: You hall Sir.
Let me ee—the Author of the bold Beauchams,
And Englands Joy.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: The lat was a well writ peice, I aure you,
A Brittane I take it; and Shakepeares very way:
I deire to ee the man,

sp.speaker: 1 Th.
sp.l: Excue me, no eeing here.
The gods in complement to Homer,
Doe make all Poets poore above,
And we all blind below.
But you hall con • ee Sir.
Follow.— Ex.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Hallight and freh aire agen? (Peridor unbinds him and lips away.
The place I know too.—
The very ame I fought the Duell in.
The Devill was in the right;
This was a meere Aparition:
But 'twas a handome one, it left impreions here,
Such as the fairet ubtance I hall ere behold,
Will care deface.
Well I mut reolve, but what, or where?
I, that's the quetion.
The Towne's unafe, there's no returning thither,
And then the Port.— (Enter ome to pae over.
Ha! What means the buie hate of thee.—
Honet friend.—No— (Paes hatily.
Do't heare,— (To another.
What's the matter pray?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Gentlemen, gentlemen,
That's good atisfaction indeed.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Prethee good fellow tell me. (Enter another.
What caues all this hurry?— (To another.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: One Samorat is led to prion Sir,
And other Gentlemen about Lord Torcular.
Ha! Samorat!
There is no meane nor end of fortunes malice:
I'm made a boy whipt on anothers backe:
Cruell, I'le not endure't by heaven,
He hall not dye for me:
I will not hold a wretched life upon uch wretched termes.

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: Flie; flie abroad, earch every place, and
Bring him back:
Thou hat undone us all with thy neglect,
Detroi'd the hopes we had to be our elves agen;
I hall run mad with Anger;
Fly, be gone.— Exeunt all but Tam.
My Reginella, what brings you abroad?

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: Deare Governour? I have a ute to you.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: To me my pretty weetnee, what?

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: You will deny me Sir I feare,
Pray let me have the tranger that came lat in keeping.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: Stranger? Alas hee's gone, made an ecape

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: I fear'd he would not tay they us'd him o unkindly.
Indeed I would have us'd him better, (weeps.
And then he had been here till.

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: Come doe not weep my girle:
Forget him pretty penivenee, there will
Come others every day as good as he.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: Oh! never: I'le cloe my ey's to all now hee's gone.

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: How catching are the parkes of love? Still this
Michance howes more and more unfortunate.
I was too curious.—
Come indeed, you mut forget him,
The gallant't and the godli't to the eye are not the bet,
Such handome and fine hapes as thoe
Are ever fal • e and foule within.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: Why Governour dyou then put
Your finet things till in your finet Cabinets?

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: Pretty Innocence: no, I doe not;
You ee I place not you there,
Come no more teares:
Lets in and have a Mate at Chee,
"Diverion cures a loe, or makes it elfe.— Extunt.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: CRot all the High-wayes, earcht the Woods,
Beat up and down with as much pain & diligence,
As ever Huntman did for a lot Deere.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: A race of Criples, are y' all
Iue of Snayles, he could not ele have cap't us.
Now? what newes bring you?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Sir, we have found him out,
The party is in prion.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: How? in prion?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: For certaine Sir.
It eemes young Samorat and he
Were thoe that fought the duell t'other day,
And left our Torcular o wounded there.
For his uppoed death was Samorat taken,
Which when this youth had found,
He did attempt to free him (caling the wall
By night) but finding it impoible,
Next Morning did preent himelfe
Into the hands of Jutice, imagining
His death that did the fact, an equall acrifice.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: Brave Orabrin.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Not knowing that the greedy Law ask's more,
And doth precribe the accearie
As well as principall.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: Jut o 'ith nicke? 'ith very nicke of time?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Hee's troubled.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: It will be excellent.
Be all in ouldiers traight,
Where's Torcular?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Forth comming Sir.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: How are his wounds?
Will they endure the Aire?
Under your gaberdines weare Pitols all.]

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What does he meane?

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: Give me my other habit and my word
'Ith' leat upected way hat after me.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: All?

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: All but Peridor; I will abroad,
My broken hopes and uff'rings
Shall have now ome cure.
Fortune pite of her elfe hall be my friend,
And either hall redree, or give them end.— Ex.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: I've found it out,
He doe's intend to fetch this tranger backe,
And give him Reginella,
Or ele—No, no, it mut be that
His anger, and the earch declare it;
The ecret of the prion-houe hall out I weare.
I'le et all firt on fire,
For middle waies to uch an end are dull.— Ex.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Since he was refus'd to peake with you Sir,
Nor looke of any,
Languihes o fat,
Her ervants feare he will not live
To know what does become of him.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Sir 'tis high time you viit her.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: I cannot looke upon her, and deny her.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Nor need you Sir,
All hall appeare to her mot gracious:
Tell her the former part o'th' Law
Mut pae, but when it comes t'execute,
Promie her that you intend to interpoe.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: And hall then Samorat live?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Oh!—
Nothing lee! The cenure pat,
His death hall follow without noie:
Tis but not owning of the fact,
Digracing for a time a Secretarie,
Or o—the thing's not new—
Put on forgiving looks Sir,
We are there—
A mourning ilence
Siter Sabrina—

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Hence, hence,
Thou cruell hunter after life:
Thou art a paine unto my eyes as great,
As my deare Mother had when he did
Bring thee forth—And ure that was
Extreme, ince he produc't a monter.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Speake to her your elfe,
Shee's o incent againt me,
She will not welcome happines,
Becaue I bring it.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Faire ornament of griefe,
Why are you troubled—
Can you beleeve there's any thing within
My power which you hall mourne for?
If you have any feares, impart them;
Any deires, give them a name,
And I will give thee ret:
You wrong the greatnes of my love,
To doubt the goodnes of it.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Alas, I doe not doubt your love my Lord,
I feare it; 'tis that which does undoe me.
For 'tis not Samorat that's prioner now,
It is the Princes Rivall;
Oh! for your owne ake Sir be mercifull:
How poorely will this ound hereafter,
The Prince did feare another's merit o,
Found o much vertue in his rivall, that
He was forc't to murder it, make it away.
There can be no addition to you Sir by his death,
By his life there will; You get the point
Of honour, fortune does offer here
What time perchance cannot agen:
A handome opportunity to how
The bravery of your minde—

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: This pretty Rhetorique cannot perwade me (faire.
To let your Samorat live for my ake:
It is enough he hall for yours.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Though vertue till rewards it elfe, yet here
May it not tay for that; but may the gods
Showre on you uddenly uch happines,
That you may ay, my mercy brought me this—

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: The gods no doubt will heare when you doe pray
Right waies: But here you take their names in vaine,
Since you can give your elfe that happines
Which you doe aske of them.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Mot gracious Sir, doe not—

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Hold, I dare not heare thee peake,
For feare thou now hould't tell me,
What I doe tell my elfe;
That I would poorely bargaine for any favours;
Retire and banih all thy feares,
I will be kind and jut to thee Sabrina,
What s'ere thou prov't to me.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Rarely acted Sir,— Ex Sabr.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Ha!—

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Good faith to th' very life.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Acted?—No,—'twas not acted.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I was in earnet.
I meane to conquer her this way,
The others low and poore.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Ha?—

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I told thee 'twould be o before.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Why Sir, you doe not meane to ave him?—

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Yes—I doe—

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Sure you forget I had a brother Sir,
And one that did deerve Jutice at leat.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: He did—
And he hall have it:
He that kil'd him hall dye—
And 'tis high atisfaction, that,
Looke not—
It mut be o— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: No Devils Stramador,
Beleeve your eyes—To which I
Cannot be o lot but
You may call to minde
One Peridor.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Ha? Peridor? thou did't
Command that day
In which the Tamorens fell.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: I did—
Yet Tamoren lives.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Not Tamoren the Prince, he fell indeed;
But Tamoren his brother, who that day
Led our hore:
Young Reginella too,
Which is the ubject of the uit,—
You have ingag'd your elfe by oath,
The King hall grant.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Oh! 'tis impoible,
Intruct me how I hould beleeve thee.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Why thus—
Neceity upon that great defeat
Forc't us to keep the Woods, and hide our elves
In holes which ince we much inlarg'd,
And fortifi'd them in the entrance o,
That 'twas a afe retreate upon puruite:
Then wore we all allegeance to this Tamoren.
Thee habits better to diguie our elves, we took at firt;
But finding with what eae we rob'd,
We did continue 'em, and tooke an Oath,
Till ome new troubles in the State hould happen,
Or faire occaion to make knowne our elves
Offer it elfe, we would appeare no other:
But come, let's not looe
What we hall ne're recover,
This opportunitie—

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Nahorat, you have not thought of any
Stratagem yet—

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Yes I have thought—

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: What?—

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: That if you have any accompts with heaven,
They may goe on—
This villanous dying's, like a trange tune,
Has run o in my head,
No wholome conideration would enter it.
Nothing angers me neither, but that
I pae by my Mitrees window to't.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Troth, that's unkinde,
I have omething troubles me too.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: What's that.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: The people will ay as we goe along,
Thou art the properer fellow.
Then I breake an appointment
With a Merchants Wife,
But who can help it?— (Nahorat.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Yea who can help it indeed,
She's to blame though 'faith, if he
Does not beare with thee,
Conidering the occaion—

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Conidering the occaion as you ay,
A man would thinke he might be borne with.
There's a Scrivener I hould have paid
Some money to, upon my word,
But—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: By faire Sabrina's name,
I conjure you not to refue the mercy
Of the Prince—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: It is reolv'd Sir, you know my anwer.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Whether am I falne?
I thinke if I hould live a little longer,
I hould be made the caue of all the michiefe
Which hould arie to the world—
Hither I came to ave a friend,
