And by a light of fortune I detroy him:
My very wayes to good prove ills.
Sure I can looke a man into misfortune:
The Plague's o great within me 'tis infectious.
Oh! I am weary of my elfe:
Sir I beeech you yet accept of it,
For I hall be his way
A ufferer,
And an executioner too—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: • I beg of thee no more,
Thou do't beget in me deire to live:
For when I finde how much I am
Behind in noble acts of friendhip,
I cannot chue but wih for longer time, that I might
Struggle with thee, for what thou hat too clearly now
Got from me: The point of honour—
Oh! it is wiedome and great thrift to dye;
For who with uch a debt of friendhip and
Of Love, as you and my Sabrina mut expect from me
Could ere ubit.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: They are complementing;
'Sfoot they make no more of it,
Then if 'twere who hould goe in firt at
A doore—I thinke Pellegrine, as you and I
Have cat it up, it comes to omething
More—

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.l: Gentlemen, prepare, the Court is etting.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Friends, this is no time for ceremonie;
But what a racke have I within m • ,
To • e you uffer.
And yet I hope the Prince will let this anger dye
In me, not to take the forfeiture of you.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: If he hould, Pellegrin and I are reolv'd,
And are ready, all but our peeches to the people,
And thoe will not trouble us much,
For we intend not to trouble them. (Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Not accept it?
Loe this way too?—What hall I doe?
He makes advantages of mine,
And like a skilfull Tennis-player,
Returnes my very bet with excellent deigne.
It mut not be,
Bring to the Cloet here above, the chiefe o'th' Jury:
I'le try another way.— Ex.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Of all wayes of detroying mankinde,
Thee Judges have the eaiet,
They leep and doe it.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: To my thinking now,
This is but a olemner kind of Puppet-play:
How the Devill came we to be acters in't?
So; it beginnes.

sp.speaker: 1 Judg.
sp.l: The Princes Councell:
Are they ready?

sp.speaker: Lawy.
sp.l: Here—

sp.speaker: Judg.
sp.l: Begin then—

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: My Lords, that this o great and trange.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Mot reverend Judges,
To ave th' expence of breath and time,
And dull Formalities of Law—
I here pronounce my elfe guilty.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: from above. Agen he has prevented me—

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: So guilty that no other can pretend
A hare—
This noble youth, a tranger to every thing
But Gallantry, ignorant in our Lawes and Cutomes,
Has made perchance
(In trange everity) a forfeit of himelfe;
But hould you take it,
The gods when he is gone will ure revenge it.
If from the talke you pull this bud of vertue,
Before 't has pread and hewne it elfe abroad,
You doe an injury to all mankinde;
And publique michiefe cannot be private Jutice.
This man's as much above a common man,
As man's above a beat; And if the Law
Detroyes not man for killing of a beat,
It hould not here, for killing of a man.
Oh what mitake 'twould be?
For here you it to weed the Cankers out
That would doe hurt 'ith' State, to punih vice;
And under that y'oud root out vertue too—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: If I doe bluh, 'tis not (mot gracious Judges)
For any thing which I have done, 'tis for that
This much mitaken youth hath here deliver'd.
'Tis true (and I confee) I ever had
A little tocke of honour (which I till preerv'd)
But that (by leaving me behinde alive)
He now mot cunningly doe's thinke to get from me:
And I beeech your Lordhips to ait me;
For 'tis mot fraudulent all he deires.
Your Lawes I hope are reaonable,
Ele why hould reaonable men
Be ubject to them; and then
Upon what grounds is he made guilty now?
How can he be thought accearie
To th' killing of a man,
That did not know o'th' fighting with him?
Witnee all thoe pow'rs which earch mens hearts,
That I my elfe, (untill he beckned me)
Knew nothing of it, if uch a thing
As acrifice mut be—why? Man for mans enough:
Though elder times t'appeae diviner Jutice,
Did offer up—
(Whither through gallantrie, or ignorance)
Vat multitudes of Beats in acrifice,
Yet numbers of men is eldome heard of:
One ingle Curtius purg'd a whole States in:
You will not ay th' offence is now as great,
Or that you ought to be more highly atisfied
Then Heaven—

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Brave youths—

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: Pellegrin, you and I will let our p • eches alone.

sp.speaker: 1 Judg.
sp.l: If that the Law were of o fine a web,
As wit and fancie pin it out to, here,
Then thee defences would be jut, and ave:
But that is more ubtantiall,
Of another make—
And Gentlemen, if this be all,
Sentence mut pae—

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: Orabrin!

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Ha! who names me there?

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: A friend: heare me:
I am an Officer in that darke world
From whence thou cam't, ent
Thus diguis'd by Reginella our faire Queene,
And to redeeme thee.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Reginella!
I'th' midt of all thee ills,
How preciouly that name doe's ound?

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: If thou woult weare to follow me,
At th' intant th' art releat;
I'le ave thee and thy friends,
In pite of Law.—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Doubt not of that;
Bring me where Reginella is:
And if I follow not, perpetuall miery follow me:
It cannot be a Hell
Where he appeares—

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: Be confident.— (Goes out and brings To • cul •• .
Behold (grave Lords) the man
Whoe death quetion'd the life of thee,
Found and recovered by the Theeves
ith Woods;
And recued ince by us, to recue Innocence.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Rare Devill,
With what dexteritie h'as raied this
Shape up; to delude them—

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Ha? Torcular alive?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Torcular?

l.U: hould as oone beleeve my brother

sp.l: Neere in being too.

sp.speaker: Tor
sp.l: You cannot wonder more to finde me here,
Then I doe to finde my elfe.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Come unbinde, unbinde, this matter's anwered.

sp.speaker: Judg. 2.
sp.l: Hold: they are not free, the Law exacts
The ame for breach of prion that it did before.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: There is no caping out of fortunes hands.
Doet heare; hat never a trick for this?—

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: Doubt me not, I have without, at my command,
Thoe which never fail'd me;
And it hall cot many a life yet
Sir, ere yours be lot—

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Stramador you have been a tranger here of late.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Perue this paper Sir, you'l find there was good reaon for't.
Sramador, Peridor, Reginella meet them below.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: How! old Tamorens brother, Captaine
Of the Theeves, that has infeted thus
Our Countrey?
Reginella too, the heire of that fear'd Familie!
A happy and a trange dicovery.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: Peridor, and Reginella, the villaine
Has betrai'd me.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: 'Tis Orabrin, they have kept their words.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: O let me goe.

sp.speaker: Jay.
sp.l: You doe forget ure what you are.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: I doe indeed: oh, to unriddle now!

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: And to this man you owe it Sir,
You find an ingagement to him there;
And I mut hope you'l make me jut to him.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: He does deerve it,
Seize on him—

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: Nay then all truths mut out.
That I am lot and forfeit to the Law,
I doe confee,
Yet ince to ave this Prince.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Prince!

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: (Our Mephoto-philus is mad.)

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: Yet, Prince, this is the Orabrin.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Ha!—

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: So long agoe,
Suppoed lot,
Your Brother Sir:
Fetch in there Ardelan and Piramont.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: What mad Planet rules this day
Ardelan, and Piramont.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: The Divel's wanton,
And abues all mankinde to day.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: Thee faces are well knowne to all Francelians,
Now let them tell the ret—

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: My noble Mater living! found in Francelia?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: The gods have atisfied our tedious hopes.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Some Impoture.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: A new deigne of fortune—
I dare not trut it.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: Why peake you not?

sp.speaker: Piram.
sp.l: I am o full of joy, it will not out.
Know ye Francelians,
When Sanborne fatall field was fought,
So deperate were the hopes of Orabrin,
That 'twas thought fit to end away this Prince,
And give him afety in another clime;
That pite of an ill day, an Orabrin might be
Preerv'd alive.
Thus you all know,
To Garradans chiefe charge he was committed:
Who when our Barke by Pyrats was urpris'd,
(For o it was) was laine 'ith firt encounter;
Since that we have been forc't to wait
On Fortunes pleaure.
And Sir, that all this time we kept
You from the knowledge of your elfe,
Your pardon; It was our zeale that err'd,
Which did conclude it would be prejudiciall.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: My Lords you looke as if you doubted till:
If Piramont and I be lot unto your memory,
Your hands I hope are not—
Here's our Commiion:
There's the Diamond Elephant,
That which our Princes Sons are ever knowne by:
Which we to keep him undicovered,
Tore from his riband in that fatall day
When we were made prioners:
And here are thoe that tooke us,
Which can witnee all circumtance,
Both how, and when, time and place;
With whom we ever ince have liv'd by force:
For on no Kingdome, friend unto Francelia,
Did Fortune ever land us, ince that houre;
Nor gave us meanes to let our Country know
He liv'd—

sp.speaker: T.
sp.l: Thee very truths, when they could have no ends,
(For they beleev'd him lot)
I did receive from them before,
Which gave me now the boldnes to appeare
Here, where I'm lot by Law.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Pellegrin let's econd this:
Right or wrong 'tis bet for us.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Oberve, oberve.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: What houts are thoe?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Souldiers of Tamorens the firt;
The econd was the peoples, who
Much pree to ee their long lot Prince.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis mot evident, and all agrees,
This was his colour'd haire,
His Aire, though alter'd much with time:
You weare too trange a face upon this newes;
Sir, you have found a brother
I, Torcular, the Kingdomes happines;
For here the plague of Robberies will end.
It is a glorious day—

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: It is indeed, I am amaz'd, not ad;
Wonder doe's keep the paage o,
Nothing will out.
Brother (for o my kinder Stars will have it)
I here receive you as the bounty of the gods;
A bleing I did not expect,
And in returne to them, this day,
Francelia ever hall keep holy.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Fortune by much abuing me, has
So—dul'd my faith, I cannot
Credit any thing.
I know not how to owne uch happines.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Let not your doubts leen your joyes:
If you have had diaters heretofore,
They were but given to heighten what's to come.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Here's as trange a turne as if 'twere the
Fift Act in a Play.—

sp.speaker: Peli.
sp.l: I'm ure 'tis a good turne for us.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Sir, why tands that Lady o neglected there,
That does deerve to be the buines of mankinde.
Oh ye gods: ince you'l be kind
And bountifull, let it be here.
As fearfully, as jealous husbands aske
After ome ecrets which they dare not know;
Or as forbidden Lovers meet i'th night,
Come I to thee (and 'tis no ill igne this,
Since flames when they burne highet tremble mot)
Oh, hould he now deny me!

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: I know not perfectly what all this meanes;
But I doe finde ome happinee is neare,
And I am pleas'd, becaue I ee you are—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: She undertands me not—

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: He eemes t'have paion for her.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: Sir, in my darke commands thee flames broke out
Equally, violent at firt ight;
And 'twas the hope I had to reconcile my elfe.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: It is a holy Magicke that will make
Of you and I but one.—

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: Any thing that you wou'd aske me, ure I might grant.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Harke Gentlemen, he doe's conent,
What wants there ele?

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: My hopes grow cold, I have undone my elfe.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Nothing, we all will joyne in this;
The long liv'd feu'd between the Families
Here dyes, this day the Hyminaeall
Torches hall burne bright;
So bright, that they hall dimme the light
Of all that went before—
See Sabrina too.— (Enter Sabrina.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: Sir, I mut have much of pardon,
Not for my elfe alone, but for all mine—

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Rie, had't thou not deerv'd what now thou u't for,
This day hould know no clouds.

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: Taught by the Princes mercy; I forgive too.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Frighted hither Sir.
They told me you woo'd not accept the Princes mercy.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Art thou no further yet in thy intelligence?
See, thy brother lives—

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: My brother?—

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: And 'tis the leat of wonders has falne out.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Yes, uch a one as you are, faire, (Reginella looks at Sabrina
And you hall be acquainted.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Oh could your hate my Lords, now,
Or your love dye.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Thy merit has prevail'd
With me.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: And me.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: And has almot with me.
Samorat thou do't not doubt thy Mitree Contancia.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Then I will beg of her,
That till the Sun returnes to viit us,
She will not give away her elfe for ever.
Although my hopes are faint,
Yet I would have 'em hopes,
And in uch jolly houres as now attend us.
I would not be a deperate thing,
One made up wholly of depaire.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: You that o freely gave me Samorats life,
Which was in danger,
Mot jutly, jutly, may be uffer'd to attempt
Upon my love, which is in none.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: What ayes my noble Rivall?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Sir, y' are kind in this, and wiely doe
Provide I hould not urfeit:
For here is happines enough beides to lat the Sun's returne.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: You and I are but avers with all this Pellegrin.
But by the Lord 'tis well we came off
As we did, all was at take—

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Come, no more whipers here,
Let's in, and there unriddle to each other—
For I have much to aske.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: A Life! a Friend! a Brother! and a Mitres!
Oh! what a day was here:
Gently my Joyes ditill,
Leat you hould breake the Veell you hould fill.

lg.l: ANd how, and how, in faith,—a pretty plot;
And martly carried through too, was it not?
And the Devils, how, well? and the fighting,
Well too;—a foole, and't had bin jut old writing.
O what a monter wit mut that man have,
That could pleae all which now their twelve pence gave:
High characters (cries one) and he would ee
Things that ne're were, nor are, nor ne're will be.
Romances cries eaie-oules, and then they weare,
The Playe's well wr • t, though carce a good line's there.
The Women—Oh if Stephen houl • be kil'd,
Or mie the Lady, how the plot is pil'd?
And into how many pieces a poore Play
Is taken till before the econd day?
Like a trange Beauty newly come to Court;
And to ay truth, good faith 'tis all the port:
One will like all the ill things in a Play,
Another, ome o' th' good, but the wrong way;
So from one poore Play there comes t' arie
At everall Tables, everall Comedies.
The ill is only here, that 't may fall out
In Plaies as Faces; and who goes about
To take aunder oft detroyes (we know)
What altogether made a pretty hew.

div.p: BRENNORALT. A Tragedy. Preented at the Private Houe in Black-Fryers, by His Majeties ervants.
WRITTEN By Sir JOHN SUCKLING.
LONDON, Printed for Humphrey Moeley, and are to be old at his hop, at the Signe of the Princes Armes in St Pauls Churchyard. MDCXLVI.
The Scaene. Poland.

list.head: The Actors.
list.item:
Miefla.
Melidor.
A Lord. Councellors to the King.

Villanor.
Grainevert.
Marinell. Cavaliers and Officers under Brennoralt.
Pallatine of Menecke, Governour, one of the chiefe Rebels.
Orilla, a waiting woman to Francelia.
Reguelin, A ervant in the Governors houe, but

div.head: ACT I. SCENE I.

lg.l: I Say, the Court is but a narrow circuit;
Though omthing elevate above the common;
A kind of Ants net in the great wilde field,
O're charg'd with multitudes of quick Inhabitants,
Who till are mierably buied to get in,
What the looe foot of prodigality,
As fat do's throw abroad.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Good:
A mot eternall place of low affronts,
And then as low ubmiions.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Right.
High cowards in revenges 'mongt themelves,
And only valiant when they michiefe others.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Stars, that would have no names,
But for the ills they threaten in conjunction.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: A race of hallow, and unskilfull Pilots;
Which doe miguide the Ship even in the calme,
And in great tormes erve but as weight to inke it.
More, prethee more.— (Alarum within.
'Tis muique to my melancholy.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: My Lord; a cloud of dut and men
The Sentinels from th' Eat gate dicover;
And as they guee, the torme bends this way.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Let it be.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: My Lord?—

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Let it be,
I will not fight to day:
Bid Stratheman draw to the trenches.
On, prethee on.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: The King imployes a company of formall beards,
Men, who have no other proofes of their
Long life, but that they are old.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Right, and if th' are wie,
'Tis for themelves, not others.— (Alarum.
As old men ever are.

sp.speaker: 2 Sold.
sp.l: Coronell, Coronell;
Th' enemies at hand, kils all the Centries:
Young Almerin leads them on agen.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Let him lead them off agen.

sp.speaker: 2 Sold.
sp.l: Coronell.—

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Be gone.
If th' art afraid, goe hide thy elfe.

sp.speaker: 2 Sold.
sp.l: What a Divell ayles he?— (Exit.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: This Almerin's the ague of the Camp:
He hakes it once a day.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Hee's the ill concience rather:
He never lets it ret; would I were at home agen.
'Sfoot we lie here i'th' trenches, as if it were
For a winde to carry us into th' other
World: every houre we expect—
I'le no more on't.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.l: Prethee—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Not I, by heaven.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.l: What man! the wort is but faire death.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And what will that amount to? A faire Epitaph
A fine account.—I'le home I weare.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Arme, arme my Lord,
And hew your elfe, all's lot ele.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Why o?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: The Rebels like an unruly floud,
Rowle o're the trenches, and throw downe
All before them.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: We cannot make a tand.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.l: He would out-rivall me in honour too,
As well as love; but that he mut not doe.
Help me Strathman.— (Puts on Armour.
The danger now growes worthy of our words;
And, oh Doran, I would to heaven there were
No other tormes then the wort tempet here. (Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Marinell, throwing downe one he carries.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: There;
The Sun's the nearet Surgeon I know,
And the honetet; if thou recoveret, why o:
If not, the cure's paid, they have mauld us.

div.stage: Enter Grainevert, with another upon his backe.

sp.speaker: Grain.
sp.l: A cure light on this powder;
It tayes valour, ere i • 's halfe way on it's journey:
What a diadvantage fight we upon in this age?
He that did well heretofore,
Had the broad faire day to hew it in:
Witnees enough; we mut beleeve one another—
'Tis night when we begin:
Eternall moake and ulpher.
Smalke; by this hand I can beare with thee
No longer; how now? dead as I live;
Stolne away jut as he us'd to wench.
Well, goe thy wayes, for a quiet drinker, and dier,
I hall never know thy fellow: earches his pockets.
Thee trifles too about thee?
There was never an honeter poore wretch
Borne I thinke—look i'th' tother pocket too—hum,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Who 's that?

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.l: 'Tis I; how goes matters?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Scurvily enough;
Yet ince our Colonell came, th' ave got no ground
Of us; A weake Sculler againt Winde and Tide,
Would have done as much, harke:
This way the torrent beares. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: The Villaines all have left us.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Would they had left their feares
Behind them. But come, ince we mut—

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Hoe! Stratheman;
Skirt on the left hand with the hore,
And get betwixt thee and that Body;
They'r new rallied up forrecue. Dor. Th 'are ours.
I doe not ee my game yet.— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: What hout is that?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: They have taken Almerin, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Almerin? the Divell thanke em for 't:
When I had hunted hard all day,
And now at length unhearded the proud Deere,
The Currs have natch't him up, ound a Retreat:
There's nothing now behinde. Who aw Doran?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Shall we bring Almerin in?

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.l: No; gazing is low Triumph:
Convey him fairely to the King,
He fought it fairely—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: What youth was that, whom you betrid my Lord,
And av'd from all our words to day?
Was he not of the Enemy?

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.l: It may be o—

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: The Governors Son, Freolin, his Mitris brother. (In Dorans e •• e.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: No matter who. 'Tis pitty, the rough hand
Of warre, hould early courages detroy,
Before they bud, and hew themelves i'th' heate
Of Action—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I threw (my Lord) a youth upon a banke;
Which eeking, after the retreate, I found
Dead, and a woman, the pretty daughter
Of the Forreter; Lucillia.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.l: See, ee Doran; A ad experiment:
Woman's the cowardly't and coldet thing
The world brings forth: Yet Love, as fire works water,
Makes it boyle o're, and doe things contrary
To'ts proper nature—I hould hed a teare,
Could I tell how—Ah poore Lucilia!
Thou didt for me what did as ill become thee.
Pray ee her gently bury'd—
Boy, end the Surgeon to the Tent; I bleed:
What lowie Cottages th' ave given our oules?
Each petty torme hakes them into diorder;
And 't cots more paines to patch them up agen,
Then they are worth by much. I'm weary of
The Tenement.— Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Villanor, Grainevert, Marinell, and Stratheman.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Villanor welcome, welcome, whence camet thou?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Looke, I weare the Kings high way till on my boots.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: A pretty riding phrae, and how? and how?
Ladies cheap?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Faith, reaonable:
Thoe toyes were never deare thou know't;
A little time and indutry they'l cot;
But in good faith not much: ome few there are
That et themelves at mighty rates—

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Which we o'th' wie pae by,
As things o're-valued in the market.
Is't not o?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Y'have aid Sir, Harke you, your friend the Rivals married.
Has obtain'd the long lov'd Lady, and is uch an ae after 't.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Hum.
'Tis ever o.
The motions of married people, are as of
Other naturals; violent Gentlemen to the place,
And calme in it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: We know this too; and yet we mut be fooling.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Faith, women are the baggage of life:
They are troubleome, and hinder us
In the great march, and yet we cannot
Be without 'em.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You peake very well,
And Souldier-like.

sp.speaker: Grain.
sp.l: What? thou art a wit too I warrant,
In our abence?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Hum—no, no, a poore pretender,
A Candidate or o, 'gaint the next Seions:
Wit enough to laugh at you here.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Like enough; valour's a crime:
The wie have till repro •• hed unto the valiant,
And the fool • s too.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: R • lleri • a part, Gr • invert;
What accommodations hall we finde here?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Cleane traw (weet-heart) and meat
When thou cant get it.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Hum? traw?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Yes.
That's all will be betwixt Incet:
You, and your mother earth mut lye together.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.l: Prethee let's be erious; will this lat?
How goes affaires?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.l: But well?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Faith, 'tis now upon the turning of the ballance:
A mot equall buinee, betwixt Rebellion
And Loyaltie.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.l: What doet meane?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Why; which hall be the vertue, and which the vice.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.l: How the Divell can that be?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Oh: uccee is a rare paint; hides all the uglines.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.l: Prethee, what's the quarrell?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Nay, for that excue us;
Aske the children of peace,
They have the leiure to tudy it,
We know nothing of it; Liberty they ay.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.l: 'Sfoot, let the King make an Act,
That any man may be unmarried agen;
There's liberty for them. A race
Of half-witted fellowes quarrell about freedome?
And all that while allow the bonds of Matrimony?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: You peake very well Sir.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Soft; the King and Councell—

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Looke, they follow after like tyred pannels:
Quet ometimes for company; that is, concurre:
And that's their buines.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: They are as weary of this port
As a young unthrift of's land:
Any bargaine to be rid on't.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.l: Can you blame them?—
Who 's that?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Brennoralt, our brave Coronell:
A dicontent, but, what of that? who is not?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.l: His face peaks him one.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Thou art i' th' right.
He looks till as if he were aying to
Fortune; Huwife, goe about your buines.
Come, let's retire to Barathens Tent.
Tate a bottle, and peake bold truths;
That's our way now. Ex. Manet King and Lords.

sp.speaker: Mie.
sp.l: —Thinke not of pardon Sir,
Rigor and mercy us'd in States uncertainly,
And in ill times, looke not like th' effects
Of vertue, but neceity: Nor will
They thanke your goodnes, but your feares.—

sp.speaker: Melid.
sp.l: My Lords;
Revenge in Princes hould be till imperfect:
It is then handom't, when the King comes to
Reduce, not Ruine—

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.l: Who puts but on the face of punihing,
And only gently cuts, but prunes rebellion:
He makes that flourih which he would detroy.
Who would not be a Rebell when the hopes
Are vate, the feares but mall?

sp.speaker: [Mel.]
sp.l: Why, I would not.
Nor you my Lord, nor you, nor any here.
Feare keeps low pirits only in, the brave
Doe get above it, when they doe reolve.
Such punihments in infancy of warre,
Make men more deperate, not the more yeelding.
The common people are a kind of flyes;
They 're caught with honey, not with wormewood, Sir.
Severity exap'rates the tirr'd humour;
And State ditempers turnes into dieaes.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.l: The gods forbid, great Polands State hould be
Such as it dares not take right Phyick. Quarter
To Rebels? Sir! when you give that to them,
Give that to me, which they deerve. I would
Not live to ee it—

sp.speaker: 3 Lord.
sp.l: Turne o're your owne, and other Chronicles,
And you hall finde (great Sir)
"That nothing makes a Civill warre long liv'd,
"But ranome and returning backe the brands
Which unextinct, kindled till fiercer fires.

sp.speaker: Mie.
sp.l: Mercy betow'd on thoe that doe dipute
With words, do's looe the Angels face it has,
And is not mercy Sir, but policie;
With a weake vizard on—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: —Y' have met my thoughts
My Lords; nor will it need larger debate.
To morrow, in the ight of the beiedg'd,
The Rebell dyes: Miela, 'tis your care.
The mercy of Heav'n may be offended o,
That it cannot forgive: Mortals much more,
Which is not infinite, my Lords. (Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: O Almarin; would we had never knowne
The ruffle of the world! but were againe
By Stolden banks, in happy olitude;
When thou and I, Shepheard and Shepheardee;
So oft by turnes, as often till have wiht,
That we as eas'ly could have chang'd our ex,
As clothes; but (alas!) all thoe innocent joyes,
Like glorious Mornings, are retir'd into
Darke ullen clouds, before we knew to value
What we had.

sp.speaker: [Alme.]
sp.l: Fame & victory are light (to himelf.
Huwifes, that throw themelves into the armes,
Not of the valiant, but the fortunate.
To be tane, thus!

sp.speaker: [Iph.]
sp.l: Almerin

sp.speaker: [Alm.]
sp.l: nipt 'ith' bud
Of honour!

sp.speaker: [Iph.]
sp.l: My Lord

sp.speaker: [Alm.]
sp.l: Foil'd! & by the man
That doe's pretend unto Francelia!

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: What is't you doe, my Almerin? it till?
And quarrell with the Winds, becaue there is
A hipwrack tow' • ds, and never thinke of aving
The barke?

sp.speaker: [Almer:]
sp.l: The Barke? What hould we doe with that
When the rich freight is lot: my name in armes?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: —Who knowes
What prizes are behind, if you attend
And waite a econd Voyage?

sp.speaker: [Almer:]
sp.l: Never, never:
There are no econd Voyages in this,
The wounds of honour doe admit no cure.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Thoe light ones which misfortune gives, mut needs.
Ele, why hould Mortals value it at all?
For who would toyle to treaure up a wealth;
Which weake incontancy did keep, or might
Dipoe of?— Enter Melidor.
Oh my Lord, what newes?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: As ill as your owne feares could give you;
The Councell has decreed him udden death,
And all the wayes to mercy are blockt up. (She weeps and ighs.

sp.speaker: Almer.
sp.l: My Iphigene—
This was a misbecomming peece of love:
Women would manage a diater better— (Iphig: weeps & ighs agen.
Againe? thou art unkinde—
Thy goodnes is o grea • , it makes thee faulty:
For while thou think' • t to take the trouble from me,
Thou givet me more, by giving me thine too.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Alas! I am indeed a uelee t • i • ie;
A dull, dull thing: For could I now doe any thing
But grieve and pitty, I might help: my thoughts
Labour to finde a way; but like to birds
In cages, though they never ret t • ey are
But where they did et out at firt—

sp.speaker: Jay.
sp.l: My Lords, your pardon:
The prioner mut retire;
I have receiv'd an order from the King,
Denies accee to any.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: —He cannot be
So great a Tyrant.

sp.speaker: [Almer.]
sp.l: I thanke him; nor can
He ue me ill enough: I onely grieve
That I mut dye in debt; a Bankrupt: Such
Thy love hath made me: My deare Iphigene
Farewell: It is no time for Ceremony.
Shew me the way I mut— (Exit.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Griefe trove with uch diorder to get out,
It topt the paage, and ent backe my words
That were already on the place—

sp.speaker: [Melid.]
sp.l: Is yet a way.

sp.speaker: [Iph.]
sp.l: O peake it

sp.speaker: [Mel.]
sp.l: But there is
Danger in't Iphigene, to thee high danger.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Fright children in the darke with that, and let
Me know it: There is no uch thing in nature
If Almerin be lot.

sp.speaker: [Melid.]
sp.l: Thus then; You mut
Be taken pris'ner too, and by exchange
Save Almerin.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: How can that be?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Why— (tudies.
Step in, and pray him et his hand, about (To the Jaylor.
This ditance; his eale too—

sp.speaker: Jay.
sp.l: My Lord, I know not what this is.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Setling of money-buines, foole, betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Jay.
sp.l: If't be no more— (Exit.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Tell him that Iphigene and I deire it:
I'le end by Strathocles his ervant,
A Letter to Morat thus ign'd and eal'd,
That hall informe the udden execution;
Command him as the only meanes
To ave his life, to allie out this night
Upon the quarters, and endeavour prioners.
Name you as mot ecure and lightet guarded,
Bet pledge of afety; but charge him,
That he kill not any, if it be avoydable;
Leat 't hould inrage the King yet more,
And make his death more certaine. (Enter Jaylor with the writing.

sp.speaker: Jay.
sp.l: He undertands you not
He ayes; but he has ent it.

sp.speaker: Melid.
sp.l: So—

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: But hould Morat mitrut now?
Or this micarry?

sp.speaker: Melid.
sp.l: —Come;
Leave it to me; I'le take the Pilots part;
And reach the Port, or perih in the Art. (Exeunt.

div.head: ACT II. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Almer.
sp.l: SLeep is as nice as woman;
The more I court it, the more it flies me;
Thy elder brother will be kinder yet,
Unent for death will come.—To morrow—
Well—What can to morrow doe?
'Twill cure the ene of honour lot—
I, and my dicontents hall ret together,
What hurt is there in this?
But death againt the will,
Is but a lovenly kinde of potion;
And though precrib'd by Heaven,
It goes againt mens tomacks:
So does it at fourecore too; when the oule's
Mew'd up in narrow darknes;
Neither ees nor heares,—pih, 'tis meer fondnes in our nature;
A certaine clownih cowardie, that till
Would tay at home, and dares not venture
Into forreigne Countries, though better then
It's owne,—ha, what Countries? for we receive
Decriptions of th'other world from our Divines,
As blinde men take relation of this from us:
My thoughts leade me into the darke,
And there they'l leave me, I'le no more on't,
Within. (Knocks)— Enter.
Some paper and a light, I'le write to th' King:
Defie him, and provoke a quicke dipatch.
I would not hold this ling'ring doubtfull State
So long againe, for all that hope can give.
sp.stage: Enter 3 of the Guard (with paper and Incke)
sp.l: That word does tempt me trangely— (writing.
Wer't in my hands, 'twere worth th' other two.
But then the Guard,—it leeps or drinks; may be
To contrive it o that if I hould not pae,—
Why if I fall in't,
'Tis better yet then Pageantry;
A caffold and pectators; more ouldier-like— One of the Guard peeps over his houlder.
Uncivill villaine, read my letter?— (Seizes his word.

sp.speaker: 1 Guar.
sp.l: Not I, not I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Deny it too?

sp.speaker: Guar.
sp.l: Murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Guar.
sp.l: Arme, arme— (The Guard runs out.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: I'le follow,
Give the alarum with them,
'Tis leat upitious— (Arme, arme, arme.
All—the enemy, the enemy— (Enter Soldiers running • ver t • e Stage, one throwing away his armes.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Let them come.
Let them come.
Let them come— (Enter Almerin.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: I heare freh noie,
The camp's in great diorder: where am I now?
'Tis trangely darke—Goddee without eyes
Be thou my guide, for—blindnes and ight
Are equall ene, of equall ue, this night.

div.stage: Enter Grainevert, Stratheman, Villanor, Mari •• ll.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Trouble not thy elfe, childe of dicontent:
'Twill take no hurt I warrant thee;
The State is but a little drunke,
And when 'tas pued up that that made it o,
'Twill be well agen, there's my opinion in hort.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Th' art i'th' right.
The State's a pretty forehanded State,
And will doe reaon herea •• er.
Let's drinke and talke no more on't.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: —A good motion, a good motion,
Let's drinke.

sp.speaker: Villa.
sp.l: I, I let's drinke agen.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Come, to a Mitris.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Agreed.
Name, name.

sp.speaker: Villa.
sp.l: Any body.—Vermilia.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Away with it.
Shee's pretty to walke with:
And witty to talke with:
And pleaant too to thinke on.
But the bet ue of all,
Is her health, is a tale
And helps us to make us drinke on

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Excellent.
Gentlemen, if you ay the word,
Wee'l vant credit, and affect high pleaure.
Shall we?

sp.speaker: Villa.
sp.l: I, I, let's do that.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: What thinke ye of the acrifice now?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Come wee'le ha't,—for trickling teares are vaine

sp.speaker: Villa.
sp.l: The acrifice? what's that?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Child of ignorance, 'tis a campe health.
An A—la—mode one. Grainevert begin it.

sp.speaker: Grain.
sp.l: Come give it me.
Let me ee— (Pins up a Roe.
Which of them this Roe will erve.
Hum, hum, hum.
Bright Star o'th' lower Orbe, twinckeling Inviter,
Which draw't (as well as eyes) but et't men righter:
For who at thee begins comes to the place,
Sooner then he that ets out at the face:
Eyes are educing lights, that the goodwomen know,
And hang out thee a nearer way to how.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Fine, and patheticall:
Come Villanor.

sp.speaker: Vill
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Come, your liquor, and your tanza's.
Lines, Lines.

sp.speaker: Villa.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why, of any thing your Mitris has given you.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Gentlemen, he never gave me any thing, but a boxe
Oth'eare, for offering to kie her once.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Of that boxe then

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I, I, that boxe, of that boxe.

sp.speaker: Villa.
sp.l: Since it mut be,
Give me the poyon then.— (Drinkes and pits.
That boxe faire Mitris, which thou gavet to me,
In humane guee, is like to cot me three:
Three cups of Wine, and veres ixe,
The Wine will downe, but vere for rime till ticks.
By which you all may eaily Gentiles know,
I am a better drinker then a Po.— Enter Doran.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Doran.
Doran.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: A hall, a hall
To welcome our friend
For ome liquor call,
A new or freh face,
Mut not alter our pace,
But make us till drinke the quicker:
Wine, Wine, oh'tis divine
Come fill it unto our brother:
What's at the tongues • nd,
It forth does end,
And will not a yllable mother Then,
It unlocks the bret
And throwes out the ret,
And learnes us to know each other.
Wine,—Wine.—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Mad lads have you been here ever ince?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Yes faith, thou eet the wort of us.
We—debauch—in dicipline:
Foure and twenty houres is the time:
Barruthen had the watch to night,
To morrow 'twill be at my Tent.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Good,
And d' you know what has falne out to night?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Yes:
Grainevert, and my Lievtenant Coronell:
But they are friends againe.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Pih, pih—the young Palatine of Plocence,
And his grave guardian urpris'd too night,
Carri'd by the enemy out of his quarters.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: As a chicken by a Kite out of a back ide,
Was't not o?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Is that all?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Yes.
My Coronell did not love him:
He eats weet meats upon a march too.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Well, harke ye;
Wore yet; Almerin's gone:
Forc'd the Court of Guard where he was prioner,
And has made an ecape.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: So pale and piritlee a wretch,
Drew Priams curtaine in the dead of night,
And told him halfe his Troy was burnt—
He was of my minde. I would have done o my elfe.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: Well.
There's high upitions abroad:
Ye hall ee trange dicoveries
I'th' Councell of Warre.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: What Councell?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: One call'd this morning.
Y' are all ent to.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: I will put on cleane linnen, and peake wiely.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.l: 'Sfoot wee'l have a Round firt.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: By all meanes Sir.
Sings:
Come let the State tay,
And drinke away
There is no buinee above it:
It warmes the cold braine,
Makes us peake in high traine,
Hee's a foole that doe's not approve it.
The Macedon youth
Left behind him this truth,
That nothing is done with much thinking;
He drunke, and he fought,
Till he had what he ought,
The world was his owne by good drinking.

div.stage: Enter Generall of the Rebels, Palatine of Trocke, Palatine of Menecke, Francelia, Almerin, Morat, Iphigene.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: As your friend, my Lord, he has the priviledge of ours,
And may enjoy a liberty we would deny
To enemies.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: I thanke your Excellence; oh Iphigene,
He does not know,
That thou the nobler part of friendhip hold't,
And doe't oblige, whilt I can but acknowledge.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Opportunity to State-men, is as the jut degree
Of heate to Chymits—it perfects all the worke,
And in this pri'ner 'tis offer'd.
We now are there, where men hould till begin;
To treate upon advantage.
The Palatine of Trocke, and Menecke,
With Almerin, hall to the King;
Petitions hall be drawne,
Humble in forme, but uch for matter
As the bold Macedonian youth would end
To men he did depie for luxury.
The firt begets opinion of the world,
Which looks not far, but on the outide dwels:
Th' other inforces courage in our owne,
For bold demands mut boldly be maintain'd.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Let all goe on till in the publique name,
But keep an eare open to particular offers;
Liberty and publique good are like great Oleos
Mut have the uper end till of our tables,
Though they are but for hew.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Would I had ne're een this hape, 't has poyon in't,
Yet where dwells good, if ill inhabits there?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: —Pree much religion,
For though we dree the cruples for the multitude,
And for our elves reerve th' advantages,
(It being much pretext) yet is it neceary;
For things of faith are o abtrue, and nice,
They will admit dipute eternally:
So how o e're other demands appeare,
Thee never can be prov'd unreaonable;
The ubject being of o fine a nature,
It not ubmits it elfe to ene, but capes
The trials which conclude all common doubts.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: My Lord, you ue me as ill Painters paint,
Who while they labour to make faces faire,
Neglect to make them like.

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: Madam, there is no hip wracke of your
Vertues neare, that you hould throw away
Any of all your excellencies
To ave the dearet, modety.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.l: If they proceed with us, we can retreat unto
Our expoitions, and the peoples votes.
If they refue us wholy then we plead,
The King's beiedged, blockt up o traightly
By ome few, reliefe can find no way
To enter to the King, or to get out to us,
Exclaime againt it loud,
Till the Polonians thinke it high injutice,
And wih us better yet.
Then eaily do we rie unto our ends.
And will become their envy through their pitty.
At wort you may confirme our party there:
Increae it too: there is one Brennoralt,
Men call him Gallant, but a dicontent:
My Coen the King hath u'd him ill.
Him a handome whiper will draw.
The afternoone hall perfect
What we have looely now reolv'd.—

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: If in dicoure of beauty,
(So large an Empire) I do wonder,
It will become your goodnee Madam,
To et me right.
And in a country where you your elfe is Queene,
Not uffer trangers looe themelves.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.l: What, making revenges Palatine?
And taking prioners faire Ladies hearts?

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: Yes my Lord.
And have no better fortune in this Warre,
Then in the other; for while I thinke to take,
I am urprized my elfe.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Diembler, would thou wert.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: You are a Courtier my Lord;
The Palatine of Plocence, (Almerin)
Will grace the Hymeneals;
And that they may be while his tay is here,
Take off for you the little trangenees
Virgins weare at firt,— (Iphe ounds.
Look to the Palatine.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: How is't my dearet Ipheg • ne?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Not well I would retire.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: A qualme.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: His colour tole away; anke downe,
As water in a weather-glae
Pret by a warme hand.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: A cordiall of kind lookes,— (En • er a Trumpet blinded.
From the King.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Let's withdraw,
And heare him.— Exit.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Yes to be married;
What are you mute now?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Thou cam't too hatily upon me, pu •••
So cloe the colours to mine eye, I could
Not ee. It is impoible.

sp.speaker: [Dor.]
sp.l: impoible?
If't were impoible, it hould be otherwie,
What can you imagine there of Contancy?
Where 'tis o much their nature to love change,
That when they ay but what they are,
They excue themelves for what they doe?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: She hardly knowes him yet, in uch an intant.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Oh you know not how fire flies,
When it does catch light matter, woman.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: No more of that; She is
Yet the mot precious thing in all my thoughts.
If it be o— (Studies.)
I am a lot thing in the world Doran.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Thou wilt in vaine perwade me to be other
Life which to others is a Good that they
Enjoy, to me will be an evill, I
Shall uffer in—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Looke on another face, that's preent remedy.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: How ill thou doet conclude?
'Caue there are petilent ayres, which kill men uddenly
In health, mut there be overaigne as uddenly,
To cure in icknes? 't never was in nature

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: I was a foole to thinke, Death only kept
The doores of ill-pay'd love, when or didaine,
Or pite could let me out as well—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Right; were I as you,
It hould no more trouble me
To free my elfe of love,
Then to pit out that which made me icke.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: I'le tell her o; that he may laugh at me,
<> at a prioner threatning his Guard,
He will breake looe, and o is made the fater.
She hath charmes.— (Studies)
Doran can fetch in a rebellious heart,
<> while it is conpiring liberty.
—Oh he hath all
The vertues of her exe, and not the vices,
Chate and unullied, as firt op'ning Lillies,
Or untouch'd buds—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Chate? why! do you honour me,
Becaue I throw my elfe not off a precipice?
'Tis her ruine to be otherwie;
Though we blame thoe that kill themelves (my Lord)
We praie not him that keeps himelfe alive,
And deerves nothing.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: And 'tis the leat.
She doe's triumph, when he doe's but appeare:
I have as many Rivals as beholders.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: All that encreaes but our jealouies;
If you have now uch qualmes for that you havenot,
What will you have for that you hall poee?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: —Dull haeritique;
Know I have thee, becaue I have not her:
When I have her, I hall have thee no more.
Her fancy now, her vertue then will governe:
And as I ue to watch with doubtfull eye,
The wavering needle in the bet Sun-dyall,
Till it has etled, then the trouble's o're,
Becaue I know when it is Fixt, it's True:
So here my doubts are all afore me. Sure,
Doran, crown'd Conquerours are but the types
Of Lovers, which enjoy, and really
Poee, what th'other have in dreames. I'le end
A challenge to him.—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Do, and be thought a mad-man.
To what purpoe?
If hee love him, hee will but hate you more.
Lovers in favour (Brenkoralt) are Gameters
In good fortune; the more you et them,
The more they get.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: I'le ee her then this night, by Heaven I will

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Where? in the Cittadell?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Know what and why.—

sp.speaker: Dor
sp.l: He raves, Brennoralt?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Let me alone.—
I conjure thee, by the dicretion
Left betwixt us, (that's thine,
For mine's devour'd by injuries of fortune,)
Leave me to my elfe.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I have done.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Is there uch a paage,
As thou hat told me of, into the Catle?

sp.speaker: Rag.
sp.l: There is my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: And dar't thou let me in?

sp.speaker: Rag.
sp.l: If you my Lord will venture.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: There are no Centry's neare it.

sp.speaker: Rag.
sp.l: None.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: How to the chamber afterward?

sp.speaker: Rag.
sp.l: Her woman.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: What's hee?

sp.speaker: Rag.
sp.l: A wicket to my Ladies ecrets,
One that tands up to marriage with me.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: There—upon thy life be ecret.— (flings a pure.

sp.speaker: Rag.
sp.l: Ele,—All punihment to ingratitude.—

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Enough,
I am a torme within till I am there,
Oh Doran!
That that, which is o pleaant to behold,
Should be uch paine within!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Poore Brennoralt!
Thou art the Martyr of a thouand tyrants:
Love, Honour, and Ambition raigne by turnes,
And hew their power upon thee.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Why, let them; I'm till Brennoralt: "Ev'n Kings
"Themelves, are by their ervants rul'd ometimes;
"Let their own laves govern them at odde houres:
"Yet not ubject their Perons or their Powers.

div.head: ACT III. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: WHat have I got by changing place?
But as a wretch which ventures to the Wars,
Seeking the miery with paine abroad,
He found, but wiely thought h'had left at home.
Fortune thou hat no tyranny beyond
This uage.— (Weepes
Would I had never hop't
Or had betimes dipair'd, let never in
The gentle theife, or kept him but a guet,
Not made him Lord of all.
Tempets of wind thus (as my tormes of griefe
Carry my teares, which hould relieve my heart)
Have hurried to the thankelee Ocean clouds
And howers, that needed not at all the curteie;
When the poore plaines have languih't for the want,
And almot burnt aunder.—
I'le have this Statues place, and undertake
At my own charge to keepe the water full.— (Lies down.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Thee fond impreions grow too trong upon me,
They were at firt without deigne or end;
Like the firt Elements, that know not what
And why they act, and yet produce trange things;
Poore innocent deires, journeying they know
Not whether: but now they promie to themelves
Strange things, grow inolent, threaten no ret
Till they be atisfied.
What difference was between thee Lords?
The one made love, as if he by aault
Would take my heart, o forc't it to defence;
While t'other blew it up with ecret mines,
And let no place for it, here he is.—
Teares teale too from his eyes,
As if not daring to be knowne
To pae that way: make it good, cunning griefe
Thou knowt thou couldt not dree thy elfe
In any other lookes, to make thee lovely. (pies Francelia)

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: Francelia
If through the ignorance of places,
I have intruded on your privacies,
Found out forbidden paths; 'tis fit you pardon, Madam:
For 'tis my melancholly, not I, offends.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: So great a melancholly would well become
Michances, uch as time could not repaire:
Thoe of the warre, are but the petty cures
Of every comming hower.—

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: Why hould I not tell her all? ince 'tis in her
To ave my life; who knowes but he may be
Gallant o far, as to undo her elfe
To make another happy?—Madam,
The accidents of war contribute leat
To my ad thoughts, (if any uch I have)
—Imprionment can never be—
Where the place holds what we mut love, and yet—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My Lord?

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: In this imprionment.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Proceed my Lord:

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: I dare not Madam.

sp.speaker: Fran.

l.U: ee I do diturbe you, and enter upon ecrets—

sp.l: Which when I know, I cannot erve you in them.

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: Oh mot of any
You are the caue of all.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I my Lord?

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: You Madam—you alone.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Alas! that 'tis too oone to undertand.

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: Mut not you marry Almerin?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: They tell me 'tis deign'd.

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: If he have you, I am for ever lot

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: —Lot?
The Heavens forbid they hould deigne o ill!
Or when they hall, that I hould be the caue.

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: Ha! her eyes are trangely kind,
Shee prompts me excellently,
Stars be propitious, and I am afe.
—A way I not expected.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: His paion labours for vent.

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: Is there a hope you will not give your elfe
To Almerin?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My Lord this ayre is common,
The walkes within are pleaanter.— (Exit.

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: —Invitation!
God of deires, be kind, and fill me now
With language; uch thou lend't thy Favourites,
When thou wouldt give them eaie victories:
And I forgive thee, all thy cruelties.— (Exit. after.

div.stage: Enter Pallatine of Trock Meneck, Almerin, Brennoralt, Lords.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: —Conider too, that thoe
Who are neceiated to ue violence,
Have firt been violent by neceity.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: —But till you judge not right
"Of the Prerogative; "For oft it tands
"With Pow'r and Law, as with our Faith and Reaon:
"It is not all againt, that is above. (my Lord.)

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.l: You Lithuanians had of all leat reaon;
For would the King be unjut to you he cannot:
Where there's o little to be had.—

sp.speaker: Almer.
sp.l: Where there is leat, there's liberty (my Lord.)
And 'tis more injurie to pull haires
From the bald, then from the buhy heads. (They go off talking Trock puls Brennoralt.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: of Tro. Brennoralt—a word
My Lord, the world hath cat its eye upon you,
And mark'd you out one of the formot men:
Y'have buied fame the eareliet of any,
And end her till on errands.
Much of the bravery of your nation,
Has taken up it's lodging in you.
And gallant men but coppy from you.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: 'Tis goodly language this, what would it meane?

sp.speaker: Pall. of Tro.
sp.l: The Lithuanians wih you well, and wonder
So much deert hould be o ill rewarded.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: While all the guifts the Crown is Mitris of,
Are plac'd upon the empty—

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Still I take yon not.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Then to be plaine; our Army would be proud of you:
Pay the neglected cores of merit double.
All that you hold here of command, and what
Your fortune in this Sigimund has uff er'd,
Repaire, and make it fairer then at firt.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: How?
Then nothing, Lord; trifle below ill language:
How came it in thy heart to tempt my honour?

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: My Lord?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Do't thinke 'caue I am angry
With the King and State ometimes
I am fallen out with vertue, and my elfe?
Draw, draw, or by goodnee—

sp.speaker: P
sp.l: What meanes your Lordhip?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Draw I ay.
—He that would thinke me a villaine, is one:
And I do weare this toy, to purge the world Ent. K of Pal. Lords, Melid. Miela.
Of uch. Th'have av'd thee, wert thou good natur'd
Thou wouldt love the King the better during life.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: If they be jut, they call for gracious anwers:
Speedy, (how e're) we promie. (They all kile the Kings hand.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Long live great Sigimond.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: —The Lithuanians Sir,
Are of the wilder ort of creatures, mut
Be rid with Cavilons, and with harh curbs.
And ince the war can only make them tride,
What can be ued but words? where men have fal'ne
From not repecting Royalty, unto
A liberty of offending it: what though
Their numbers (poibly) equall yours Sir?
And now forc't by neceity, like Catts
In narrow roomes, they fly up in your face?
Thinke you Rebellion and Loyalty
Are empty names? and that in Subjects hearts
They don't both give and take away the courage?
Shall we beleeve there is no difference
In good and bad? that there's no punihment,
Or no protection? forbid it Heaven!
If when great Polands honour, afety too,
Hangs in dipute, we hould not draw our Swords,
Why were we ever taught to weare 'em Sir?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: This late commotion in your Kingdom Sir,
Is like a growing Wen upon the face,
Which as we cannot looke one but with trouble,
So take't away we cannot but with danger.
War there hath foulet fac • , and I mot feare it
Where the pretence is fair't. Religion
Which like the Bils of ubtle Mountebankes,
Fill'd with great promies of curing all,
—Though by the wie,
Pa'd by unread as common coenage,
Yet, By th'unknowing multitude they're till
Admir'd, and flock't unto.—

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Is there no way
To diabue them?

sp.speaker: [Melid]
sp.l: All is now too late.
`The vulgar in Religion are like
"Unknown Lands; thoe that firt poee them, have them
Then, Sir, conider, jutnee of Caue is nothing:
When things are rien to the point they are;
'Tis either not examin'd or beleev'd
Among the Warlike.—
The better caue the Grecians had of Yore,
Yet were the Gods themelves divided in't;
And the foule raviher found as good protection
As the much injur'd husband.—
Nor are you Sir aur'd of all behinde you:
For though your Peron in your Subjects hearts
Stands highly honour'd, and belov'd, yet are
There certaine Acts of State, which men call grievances
Abroad; and though they bare them in the times
Of peace, yet will they now perchance, eeke to
Be free, and throw them off. "For know Dread Sir,
"The Common People are much like the Sea,
"That uffers things to fall and inke unto
"The bottome in a Calme, which in a Storme
"Stird and inraged, it lifts, and does keep up
Then; Time ditempers cures more afely Sir,
Then Phyick does, or intant letting-bloud:
Religion now is a young Mitris there,
For which each man will fight, and dye at leat;
Let it alone a while, and 'twill become
A kind of marry'd wife: people will be
Content to live with it in quietnee.
(If that at leat may be) my voyce is therefore Sir,
For Peace.—

sp.speaker: Mie.
sp.l: Were Sir the quetion imply War or Peace,
It were no more then hortly to be askt,
Whether we would be well or ill:
Since War the icknee of the Kingdome is,
And Peace the health: But here I do conceive
'Twill rather lye, whether we had not better,
Endure harpe icknee for a time, to enjoy
A perfect trength, then have it languih on us:
For Peace and War in an incetuous line,
Have till begot each other.—
Thoe men that highly now have broke all Lawes,
(The great one only 'tis 'twixt man and man)
What afety can they promie, though you give it?
Will they not till upect, (and jutly too)
That all thoe civill bonds (new made) hould be
Broken againe to them? o being till
In feares and jealouies themelves, they mut
Infect the People: "For in uch a cae
"The private afety is the publike trouble.
Nor will they ever want Praetext; "Since he
"That will maintaine it with his Sword hee's iniur'd,
"May ay't at any time—
Then Sir, as terrible as war appeares,
My vote is for't; nor hall I ever care
How ugly my Phyitians face hall be,
So he can doe the cure.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: In entring phiique,
I thinke, Sir, none o much coniders
The Doctors face, as his owne body.
To keep on foot the warre with all your wants,
Is to let bloud, and take trong potions,
In dangerous icknee.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I ee, and wonder not to finde, my Lords,
This difference in opinion; the ubject's large:
Nor can we there too much dipute, where when
We erre, 'tis at a Kingdomes charges; Peace
And warre are in themelves indifferent,
And time doth tamp them either good or bad:
But here the place is much coniderable;
"Warre in our owne is like to too much heate
"Within, it makes the body icke; when in
"Another Countrey, 'tis but exercie;
"Conveighs that heat abroad, and gives it health.
To that I bend my thoughts; but leave it to
Our greater Councell, which we now aemble:
Meane time exchange of pris'ners only we
Aent unto—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Nothing of Truce, Sir?

sp.speaker: [K.]
sp.l: No: wee'l not take up
Quiet at int'ret: Perfect Peace, or nothing.
"Ceations for hort times in warre, are like
"Small fits of health, in dep'rate maladies:
"Which while the intant paine eemes to abate,
"Flatters into debauch and wore etate.— Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Iphigene as leading to her chamber Francelia; Servants with lights; Morat, and another Souldier.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: I have not left my elfe a faire retreate,
And mut be now the blet object
Of your love, or ubject of your corne.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I feare ome treacherie;
And that mine eyes have given intelligence.
Unlee you knew there would be weak defence,
You durt not thinke of taking in a heart,
As oone as you et downe before it.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Condemne my Love not of uch fond ambition,
It aymes not at a conquet,
But exchange, Francelia— (whiper.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: They 're very great in this hort time.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: 'Tis ever o:
Young and handome
Have made acquaintances in nature:
So when they meet, they have the lee to doe.
It is for age or uglines to make approaches,
And keep a ditance.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: When I hall ee other perfection,
Which at the bet will be but other vanity,
Not more, I hall not love it—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Tis till one tep not to depaire, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Morat.
sp.l: Doet thinke he will fight?

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: Troth it may be not:
Nature, in thoe fine peeces, does as Painters;
Hangs out a pleaant Excellence
That takes the eye, which is indeed,
But a coure canvas in the naked truth,
Or ome light tuffe.

sp.speaker: Morat.
sp.l: I have a great minde to tate him.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: Fy! a Prioner?

sp.speaker: Morat.
sp.l: By this hand if I thought— Enter Iphig: waitingwoman comming after him.
He courted my Coronels Mrs in earnet.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord,
My Lady thinks the Geimine walks
Will be the finer, the frehnes
f th' morning takes of the trength
O' th' heate he ayes.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Mewe—doe it o? I upect vildly,
Wee'l follow him, and ee if he be
So farre quallified towards a ouldier,
As to drinke a crah in's chamber— (Raguelin puls the waiting woman backe.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.l: Where are thoe keyes?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Harke you, I dare not doe it.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: My Lady will finde—

sp.speaker: R.
sp.l: Scruples?
Are my hopes become your feares?
There was no other way I hould be any thing
In this lewd world,—and now—
'Sfoot, I know he longs to ee him too.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Does he?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.l: Doe you thinke he would deire it ele?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: I, but—

sp.speaker: R.
sp.l: Why, let me ecure it all.
I'le ay I found the Keyes, or tole them: Come—

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Well, if you ruine all now—
Here, thee enter the garden from the works,
That the privy walks and that the backe taires.
Then you know my chamber.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.l: Yes I know your chamber.— Exeunt

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: He comes not.
One wie thought more and I returne:
I cannot in this act eperate the foolih
From the bold o farre, but till it tats a' th, rah.
Why let it tate, it tats of love too;
And to all actions 't gives a pretty rellih, that.

sp.speaker: Rag.
sp.l: My Lord?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Oh—here.

sp.speaker: Rag.
sp.l: 'Sfoot y' are upon our Centries.
Move on this hand.— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Where are we now?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Entring part of the Fort,
Your Lordhip mut be wet a little.— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Why are there here no guards?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: There needs none:
You preently mut pae a place,
Where one's an Army in defence,
It is o teep and trait.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Thee are the teps of danger;
Looke to your way my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: I doe not find uch difficulty.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Waite me here abouts— (he drawes the curtaines.
So Miers looke upon their gold,
Which while they joy to ee, they feare to looe:
The pleaure of the ight care equalling,
The jealouie of being dipoet by others;
Her face is like the milky way i'th' skie,
A meeting of gentle lights without name.
Heavens! hall this freh ornament
Of the world; this precious lovelines
Pae with other common things
Amongt the wats of time, what pity 't were. (She wakes.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Blee me!
Is it a Viion, or Brennoralt?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Brennoralt, Lady.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Brennoralt? innocence guard me;
What is 't you have done my Lord?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Alas I were in too good etate,
If I knew what I did.
But why aske you Madam?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: It much amazes me to thinke
How you came hither.
And what could bring you to indanger thus
My honour, and your owne life?
Nothing but aving of my brother
Could make me now preerve you.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Reproach me not the follies, you your elfe
Make me commit—
I am reduc'd to uch extremity,
That love himelfe (high tyrant as he is)
If he could ee would pity me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I undertand you not.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Would heaven you did, for 't is a paine to tell you:
I come t'accue you of injutice (Madam)
You firt begot my paion, and was
Content (at leat you eem'd o) it hould live;
Yet ince would ne're contribute unto it,
Not looke upon 't, as if you had deired,
Its being for no other end; but for
The pleaure of its ruine—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Why doe you labour thus to make me guilty of
An injury to you, which when it is one,
All mankinde is alike ingag'd, and mut
Have quarrell to me?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: I have done ill; you chide me jutly (Madam)
I'le lay 't not on you, but on my wretched elfe.
For I am taught that heavenly bodies
Are not malicious in their influence,
But by the dipoition of the ubject.
They tell me you mut marry Almerin:
Sure uch excellence ought to be
The recompence of vertue;
Not the acrifice of Parents wiedome,
Should it not Madam?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Twould injure me, were it thought otherwie.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: And hall he have you then that knew you yeterday?
Is there in martyrdome no juter way?
But he that holds a finger in the fire
A little time, hould have the Crowne from them
That have indur'd the flame with contancy?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: If the dicovery will eae your thoughts
My Lord; know Almerin is as the man
I never aw.

sp.speaker: [Bren.]
sp.l: You doe not marry then?
Condemned men thus heare, and thus receive
Repreeves. One quetion more, and I am gone.
Is there to latitude of eternity
A hope for Brennoralt?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My Lord?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Have I a place at all,
When you doe thinke of men?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My Lord, a high one,
I mut be ingular did I not value you:
The world does et great rates upon you,
And you have firt deerv'd them.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Is this all?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: All.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Oh be lee kinde, or kinder:
Give me more pity, or more cruelty, Francelia.
I cannot live with this, nor die—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I feare my Lord,
You mut not hope beyond it.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Not hope? This, ure, is not the body to (views himelfe.
This oule; it was mitaken, hufled in
Through hate: Why (ele) hould that have o much love,
And this want lovelinee, to make that love
Receiv'd?—I will raie honour to a point,
It never was—do things (tudies.
Of uch a vertuous greatnee he hall love me.
She hall—I will deerve her, though
I have her not: There's omething yet in that.
Madam, wilt pleae you, pardon my offence?
—(Oh Fates!
That I mut call thus my affection!)

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I will doe any thing, o you will thinke
Of me, and of your elfe (my Lord) and how
Your tay indangers both—

sp.speaker: [Bren.]
sp.l: Alas!
Your pardon is more neceary to
My life, then life to me: but I am gone.
Bleings, uch as my wihes for you, in
Their extaies, could never reach, fall on you.
May ev'ry thing contribute to preerve
That exc'lence (my detruction) till't meet joyes
In love, great as the torments I have in't. Exit.

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: VVHy o, 'tis well, Fortune I thanke thee till,
I dare not call thee villaine neither.
'Twas plotted from the firt,
That's certaine,—it looks that way?
Hum—caught in a trap?
Here's omething yet to trut to— (To his word.
This was the entry, thee the taires:
But whether afterwards?
He that is ure to perih on the land,
May quit the nicetie of Card and Compae:
And afe, to his dicretion put to Sea:
He hall have my hand to't. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Looke:
By this light 'tis day.

sp.speaker: Oril.
sp.l: Not by this, by t' other 'tis indeed.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Thou art uch another peece of temptation.
My Lord raves by this time,
A hundred to one the Centinells
Will dicover us too,
Then I doe pay for night-watch.

sp.speaker: Oril.
sp.l: Fie upon thee,
Thou art as fearfull as a young colt;
Boglet at every thing, foole.
As if Lovers had conidered houres: I'le peep in— (he peeps

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I am as weary of this wench,
As if I were married to her:
She hangs upon me like an Ape upon a hore—
She's as common too, as a Barbers glae—
Concienc't too like a Dy-dapper.

sp.speaker: Orilla.
sp.l: —there's no body within:
My Lady leeps this houre at leat.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Good, the Divel's even with me—
Not be an honet man neither— Enter Bren. & a guard.
What coure now?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Nay Sir, we hall order you now.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Dogges.— Enter Freolin.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: What tumult's this—ha! Brennoralt! 'tis he
In pite of his diguie: what makes he here?
Hee's lot for ever if he be dicover'd;
How now companions, why doe you ue my friend thus?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Your friend my Lord? if he be your friend
H'as us'd us as ill:
H' has plaid the Divell amongt us.
Six of our men are Surgeons worke this moneth;
We found him climbing the walls.

sp.speaker: 2 S.
sp.l: He had no word neither,
Nor any language but a blow.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: You will be doing thee wilde things (my Lord)
Good faith y' are too blame, if y' had deir'd
To view the walls, or Trenches, 't was but
Speaking; we are not nice:
I would my elfe have waited on you:
Th' are the new out-workes you would ee perchance.
Boy, bring me blacke Tempet round about,
And the gray Barbary; a Trumpet come along too;
My Lord, wee'l take the neerer way,
And privater, here through the Sally-Port.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.l: What a Divell is this? ure I dreame— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Now, you are o officious. (Manet Sold.

sp.speaker: 2 S.
sp.l: Death! could I guee he was a friend?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: 'Twas ever to be thought,
How hould he come there ele?

sp.speaker: 2 S.
sp.l: Friend or no friend, he might have left us
Something to pay the Surgeon with:
Grant me that, or Ile beat you to't.— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Brennoralt—tart not:
I pay thee backe a life I owe thee;
And blee my Starres, they gave me power to do't;
The debt lay heavy on me.
A hore waits you there—a Trumpet too,
(Which you may keep, leat he hould prate)
No Ceremony, 'tis dangerous.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Thou hat atonih't me:
Thy youth hath triumph'd in one ingle act,
O're all the age can boat; and I will tay
To tell thee o, were they now firing all
Their Cannons on me; farewell gallant Freolin:
And may reward, great as thy vertue, crowne thee.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: A peace will come,
And then you mut be gone;
And whither when you once are got upon the wing,
You will not toop to what hall rie,
Before ye flye to ome lure
With more temptation garniht, is a ad quetion.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Can you have doubts, and I not my feares?
By this—the readiet and the weetet oath, I weare
I cannot o ecure my elfe of you,
But in my abence I hall be in paine.
I have cat up what it will be to tand
The Governors anger; and which is more hard,
The love of Almerin.
I hold thee now but by thy owne free grant,
A light ecuritie, alas it may fall out,
Giving thy elfe, not knowing thine owne worth,
Or want of mine, thou mayt, like Kings deceiv'd,
Reume the gift on better knowledge backe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: If I o eas'ly change, I was not worth your love,
And by the loe you 'l gaine.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: But when y'are irrecoverably gone
'Twill be light comfort to perwade my elfe
You had a fault, when all that fault mut be
But want of love to me; and that agen
Finde in my much defect, o much excue,
That it will have no wore name
Then dicretion if inconcern'd doe
Cat it up—I mut have more aurance.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: You have too much already:
And ure my Lord you wonder, while I bluh,
At uch a growth in young affections.

sp.speaker: Iphi
sp.l: Why hould I wonder (Madam.)
Love that from two breats ucks,
Mut of a child quickly become a Giant.
Dunces in love tay at the Alphabet,
Th' inpir'd know all before;— Enter waiting woman.
And doe begin till higher.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.l: Madam;
Almerin, returned, has ent to kie
Your hands. I told him you were buie.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Mut I my Lord be buy?
I may be civill though not kind.
Tell him I wait him in the Gallery.

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: May I not kie your hand this night? (Whiper)

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: The world is full of jealous eyes my Lord:
And were they all lockt up; you are a pye
Once entred in my chamber at trange houres.

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: The vertue of Francelia is too afe,
To need thoe little arts of preervation.
Thus to divide our elves, is to ditrut our elves.
A Cherubin dipatches not on earth
Th' affaires of heaven with greater innocence,
Then I will viit; 'tis but to take a leave,
I begg.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: When you are going my Lord— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Almer.
sp.l: Pih. Thou liet, thou liet.
I know he playes with woman kind, not loves it.
Thou art impertinent—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: 'Tis the campe talke my Lord though.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: The camp's an ae, let me hear no more on't

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.l: And hall we have peace?
I am no ooner ober, but the State is o too:
If't be thy will, a truce for a month only.
I long to refreh my eyes; by this hand
They have been o tyr'd with looking upon faces
Of this country.

sp.speaker: Villa.
sp.l: And hall the Donazella
To whom we wih o well-a
Look Babies agen in our eyes-a?

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.l: Ah—a prightly girle above fifteen
That melts when a man but takes her by the hand!
Eyes full, and quick; with breath
Sweet as double violets,
And wholeome as dying leaves of Strawberries.
Thick ilken eye-browes, high upon the fore-head;
And cheeks mingled with pale treaks of red,
Such as the bluhing morning never wore.—

sp.speaker: Villa.
sp.l: Oh my chops; my chops;

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.l: With narrow mouth, mall teeth,
And lips welling, as if he pouted—

sp.speaker: Villa.
sp.l: Hold, hold, hold;

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.l: Haire curling, and cover'd, like buds of Marioram,
Part tyed in negligence
Part looely flowing—

sp.speaker: Marin.
sp.l: Tyrant! tyrant! tyrant!

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.l: In pinck colour taffata petticoate.
Lac't mock-leeves dangling;
This viion tolne from her own bed
And rutling in ones chamber—

sp.speaker: Villa.
sp.l: Oh good Granivert, good Granivert.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.l: With a waxe candle in her hand,
Looking as if he had lot her way;
At twelve at night.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.l: Oh any hower, any hower.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.l: Now I thinke on't, by this hand
Ile marry, and be long liv'd.

sp.speaker: Villa,
sp.l: Long liv'd? how?

sp.speaker: Grain.
sp.l: Oh, he that has a Wife, eats with an appetit • ,
'Has a very good tomacke to't firt:
This living at large is very detructive,
Variety is like rare awces; provokes too far,
And draws on urfets, more then th'other.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: So; is this a time to foole in?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Draw out your choie men, and away to
Your Coronell immediately. There's worke
Towards my boyes, there's worke.

sp.speaker: Grain,
sp.l: Art in earnet?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: By this light.

sp.speaker: Grain.
sp.l: There's omething in that yet.
This moiety Warre
Twilight,
Neither night nor day,
Pox upon it:
A torme is worth a thouand
Of your calme;
There's more variety in it. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Almerin, Francelia, as talking earnetly.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Madam, that hewes the greatnes of my paion.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: The imperfection rather: Jealouie's
No better igne of love (my Lord) then feavers are
Of Life; they hew there is a Being, though
Impair'd, and perihing: and that, affection
But icke and in diorder. I like 't not.
Your ervant.— Exit.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: So hort and owre? the change is viible.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Deare Almerin welcome, y' have been abent long.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Not very long.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: To me it hath appeared o;
What ayes our Camp? am I not blamed there?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: They wonder—

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: While we mile—
How have you found the King inclining?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Well.
The Treaty is not broken, nor holds it.
Things are where they were;
'T has a kind of face of peace,
You my Lord may when you pleae returne.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: I Almerin?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Yes my Lord, I'le give you an ecape.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: 'Tis leat in my deires.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Hum!

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Such prions are beyond all liberty.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Is't poible?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Seemes it trange to you?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: No, not at all.
What? you finde the Ladies kinde?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Civill— (miles.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: You make love well too they ay (my Lord.)

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Pae my time.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Addree unto Francelia?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Viit her.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: D' you know he is my Mitres, Pallatine?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: D' you know he is my Mitree?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: I have been told o.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: And doe you court her then?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Why?— (miles.
If I aw the enemy firt,
Would you not charge?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: He doe's allow it too by Heaven:
Laughs at me too; thou filcher of a heart,
Fale as thy title to Francelia.
Or as thy friendhip: which with this I doe— (drawes.
Throw by—draw.

sp.speaker: Iph
sp.l: What doe you meane?

sp.speaker: Alm.

l.U: ee the cunning now of all thy love,

sp.l: And why thou camet o tamely kinde,
Suffering urprie Draw.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: I will not draw, kill me;
And I hall have no trouble in my death,
Knowing 'tis your pleaure:
As I hall ha ve no pleaure in my life
Knowing it is your trouble.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Oh poor—I lookt for this.
I knew th' wouldt find 'twas eaier to doe a wrong
Then jutifie it—but—

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: I will not fight—heare me:
If I love you not more, then I love her;
If I doe love her more then for your ake;
Heaven trangely punih me.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Take heed how thou dot play with heaven.

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: By all that's jut, and faire, and good,
By all that you hold deare, and men hold great;
I never had lacivious thought, or ere
Did action that might call in doubt my love
To Almerin.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: That tongue can charme me into any thing;
I doe beleev't, prethee be wier then.
Give me no further caue of jealouie,
Hurt not mine honour more, and I am well.

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: But well—Of all
Our paions, I wonder nature made
The wort, foule jealouie, her favorite.
And if it be not o, why took he care
That every thing hould give the monter Nourihment,
And left us nothing to detroy it with?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Prethee no more, thou plead't o cunningly
I feare I hall be made the guilty
And need thy pardon.

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: If you could read my heart you would.
I will be gone to morrow if that will atisfie. Indeed

l.U: hall not ret untill my innocence

sp.l: Be made as plain as objects to the ence.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: —Come;
You hall not goe, Ile think upon't no more.
"Ditruts ruine not friendhip,
"But build it fairer then it was before—

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: No more but ten from every company;
For many hands are theeves, and rob the glory,
While they take their hare how goes the night?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Halfe pent my Lord.
We hall have traight,
The Moones weaker light.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: 'Tis time then, call in the officers.
Friends, if you were men that mut be talkt
Into a courage, I had not choen you;
Danger with its vizard, oft before this time
Y'have look'd upon and out-fac'd it too;
We are to doe the trick agen, that's all.
Here—(drawes his word)
And yet we will not weare:
For he that hrinks in uch an action
Is damn'd without the help of perjury.
Doran; if from the virgin tow'r thou piet
A flame, uch as the Eat ends forth about
The time the day hould break, goe tell the King
I hold the Catle for him; bid him come on
With all his force, and he hall find a victory
So cheap 'twill looe the value. If I fall,
The world has lot a thing it us'd not well;
And I, a thing I car'd not for; that world.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Lead us on Coronell;
If we doe not fight like—

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: No like.
Wee'l be our elves imilitude
And time hall ay, when it would tell
