That men did well, they fought like us.

div.head: ACT. V. SCEN. I.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: WHat made the top?
One in's falling icknee had a fit
Which choak'd the paage; but all is well:
Softly, we are neere the place. Exeunt.

div.stage: Alarum within, and fight, then enter Almerin (in his night-gowne.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: What noie is here to night?
Something on fire—what hoe,
Send to the Virgin-tower, there is diorder—
Thereabouts. (Ent. Sould.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.l: All's lot, all's lot:
The enemie's upon the place of armes:
And is by this time Mater of that,
And of the Tower.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Thou liet.— (trikes him.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Save your elfe my Lord, and hat unto the camp;
Ruine gets in on every ide.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: There's omething in it when this fellow flies.
Villaines my armes, I'le ee what Divell raignes.

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: Looke, the day breakes.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You thinke I'le be o kinde, as weare
It does not now. Indeed I will not—

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Will you not end me neither,
Your picture when y' are gone?
That when my eye is famiht for a looke,
It may have where to feed,
And to the painted Feat invite my heart.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Here, take this virgin-bracelet of my haire,
And if like other men thou halt hereafter
Throw it with negligence,
'Mongt the Records of thy weake female conquets,
Laugh at the kinde words, and myticall contrivement.
If uch a time hall come,
Know I am ighing then thy abence Iphigene,
And weeping o're the fale but pleaing Image.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Francelia, Francelia,
Rie, rie, and ave thy elfe the enemy
That does not know thy worth, may ele detroy it.
Ha! mine eyes grow ick.
A plague has, through them, tolne into my heart;
And I grow dizzie: feet, lead me off agen,
Without the knowledge of my body.
I hall act I know not what ele— Exit.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: How came he in?
Deare Iphigene we are betrayd;
Lets raie the Catle let he hould return.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: That were to make all publique.
Feare not Ile atisfie his anger:
I can doe it.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Yes, with ome quarrell;
And bring my honour, and my love in danger— Enter Almerin
Look he returns, and wrecks of fury,
Like hurried clouds over the face of heaven,
Before a tempet, in his looks appeares.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: If they would quetion what our Rage doth act
And make it in, they would not thus provoke men.
—I am too tame.
For if they live I hall be pointed at,
Here I denounce a warre to all the world,
And thus begin it—(runs at Iphigene)

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: What hat thou done—(falls)

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Ah me, help, help.— (wounds Francelia)

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: Hold.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: 'Tis too late.

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: Rather then he hall uffer,
My fond deceits involve the innocent;
I will dicover all.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Ha!—what will he dicover?

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: That which hall make thee cure
The blindnee of thy rage.— I am a woman.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, brave and bold!
Becaue thy perjury deceived me once,
And aved thy life, thou thinket to ecape agen.
Impotor, thus thou halt.— (runs at him.

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: Oh hold—I have enough.
Had I hope of life, thou houldt not have this ecret.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: What will it be now?

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: —My father having long deir'd
A onne to heire his great poeions.
And in ix births ucceively deceiv'd,
Made a rah vow; oh how rah vowes are punihed!
That if the burthen then my mother went with
Prov'd not a male, he ne're would know her more.
Then was unhappy Iphigene brought forth,
And by the womens kindnee nam'd a boy;
And ince o bred: (a cruell pity as
It hath faln out.) If now thou findt that, which
Thou thoughtt a friendhip in me, Love; forget it.
It was my joy,—and—death.— (faints.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: —For curioity
Ile ave thee, if I can, and know the end
If't be but loe of Blood,—Breats!
By all that's good a woman!—Iphigene.

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: I thank thee, for I was falne aleep, before
I had dipatcht. Sweetet of all thy exe,
Francelia, forgive me now; my love
Vnto this man, and feare to looe him, taught me,
A fatall cunning, made me court you,—and
My owne Detruction.

sp.speaker: [Franc.]
sp.l: I am amaz'd.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: And can it be? Oh mockery of heaven!
To let me ee what my oule often wiht
And mak't my punihment, a punihment,
That were I old in innes, were yet too great.

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: Would you have lov'd me then? Pray ay you would:
For I like tetie ickmen at their death,
Would know no newes but health from the Phyitian.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Cant thou doubt that?
That hat o often een me exta • 'd,
When thou wert dret like woman
Vnwilling ever to beleeve thee man?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: I have enough.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Heavens!
What thing hall I appeare unto the world!
Here might my ignorance find ome excue.
—But, there,
I was ditracted. None but one enrag'd
With anger to a avadgenee, would ere
Have drawne a word upon uch gentle weetnee.
Be kind, and kill me; kill me one of you:
Kill me if 't be but to preerve my wits.
Deare Iphigene, take thy revenge, it will
Not misbecome thy exe at all; for 'tis
An act of pity not of cruelty:
Thus to dipatch a mierable man.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: And thou wouldt be more mierable yet,
While like a Bird made prioner by it elfe,
Thou bat't and beat't thy elf 'gaint every thing,
And dot pae by, that which hould let thee out.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: —Is it my fault?
Or heav'ns? Fortune, when he would play upon me,
Like ill Muitians, wound me up o high,
That I mut crack ooner then move in tune.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Still you rave,
While we for want of preent help may perih.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Right.
A Surgeon, Ile goe find one intantly.
The enemy too—I had forgot—
Oh what fatality govern'd this night.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: How like an unthrifts cae will mine be now?
For all the wealth he looes hifts but 's place;
And till the world enjoyes it: o will't you,
Sweet Iphigene, though I poee you not.

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: What excellence of Nature's this! have you
So perfectly forgiv'n already, as to
Conider me a loe? I doubt which Sexe
I hall be happier in. Climates of Friendhip
Are not lee pleaant, 'caue they are lee cortching,
Then thoe of Love; and under them wee'l live:
Such pretious links of that wee'l tye our ouls
Together with, that the chaines of the other.
Shall be groe fetters to it.

sp.speaker: [Franc.]
sp.l: But I feare
I cannot tay the making. Oh would you
Had never un-deceiv'd me, for I'had dy'd with
Pleaure, beleeving I had been your Martyr.
Now—

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: Shee looks pale. Francelia—

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: —I cannot tay;
A haty ummons hurries me away:
And—gives—no— (dies)

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: —Shee's gone:
Shee's gone. Life like a Dials hand hath tolne A • oye within. Enter ouldiers. Shee thinke • them Almer.
From the faire figure e're it was perceiv'd.
What will become of me?—Too late, too late
Y' are come: you may perwade wild birds, that wing
The aire, into a Cage, as oon as call
Her wandring pirits back.—ha!
Thoe are trange faces; there's a horrour in them:
And if I tay, I hall be taken for
The murtherer. O in what treights they move
That wander 'twixt death, feares and hopes of love.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Forbeare, upon your lives, the place:
There dwels divinity within it All ele
The Catle holds, is lawfull prize;
Your valours wages. This I claime as mine,
Guard you the door—

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.l: Coronell hall you ue all the women your elfe?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Away—'tis uneaonable— (drawes the curtain)
Awake fair Saint and blee thy poore Idolator
Ha!—pale?—and cold?—dead.
The weetet guet fled, murdered by heaven;
The purple treams not drye yet.
Some villaine has broke in before me,
Rob'd all my hopes; but I will find him out,
And kick his oule to hell—Ile doe 't— dragging out Iphigene.
Speak.

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: What hould I ay?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Speak or by all—

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Alas, I doe confee my elfe the unfortunate caue.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Oh d' you o?
Hadt thou been caue of all the plagues
That vexe mankinde, th' adt been an Innocent
To what thou art; thou halt not think repentance. (kils her.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Oh, thou wert too uddaine.
And— (dies.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Was I o?
The lutfull youth would ure have poil'd her honour;
Which finding highly garded, rage, and feare
To be reveal'd, counell'd this villany.
Is there no more of them? Exit.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Not enter?
Yes dogge, through thee—ha! a coure laid out
In tead of Iphigene: Francelia dead too?— (Enter Bren.
Where hall I begin to cure?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Here—If he were thy friend.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Brennoralt;
A gallant word could ne're have come
In better time.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: I have a good one for thee,
If that will erve the turne.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: I long to trie it,
That ight doth make me deperate;
Sicke of my elfe and the world.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Didt value him?
A greater villaine did I never kill.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Kill?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Art ure of it?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: May be I doe not wake.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Th' at taken then a guilt off from me,
Would have waigh'd downe my word,
Weakned me to low reitance.

l.U: hould have made no ports, hadt thou conceal'd it.

sp.l: Know Brennoralt thy word is tain'd in excellence,
Great as the world could boat.—

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Ha—ha—how thou art abus'd?
Looke there, there lies the excellence
Thou peak't of murdred; by him too;
He did confee he was the caue.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Oh Innocence, ill undertood, and much wore us'd!
She was alas by accident, but I,
I was the caue indeed

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.l: I will beleeve thee too, and kill thee—
Detroy all caues till I make a top
In nature; for to what purpoe hould he
Worke agen?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Bravely then,
The title of a Kingdome is a trifle
To our quarrell Sir; know by ad mitake
I kill'd thy Mitres Brennoralt,
And thou kild't mine.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Thine?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Yes, that Iphigene
Though howne as man unto the world,
Was woman, excellent woman—

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: I undertand no riddles guard thee.— Fight and paue.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: O could they now looke downe,
And ee how wee two trive
Which firt hould give revenge,
They would forgive us omething of the crime.
Hold prethee give me leave
To atisfie a curioity—
I never kied my Iphigene as woman.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Thou motion't well, nor have I taken leave (Riing.
It keeps a weetnee yet—
As tills from Roes, when the flowers are gone.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Even o have two faint Pilgrims corch't with heat
Vnto ome neighbour fountaine tept aide
Kneel'd firt, then laid their warm lips to the Nymph
And from her coldnee took freh life againe
As we doe now—

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Lets on our journy if thou art refreht.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Come and if there be a place reerved
For heightned pirits better then other,
May that which wearies firt of ours have it. Fight agood while Alm. fals.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: If I grow weary, laugh at me, that's all

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: —Brave oules above which will
Be (ure) inquiitive for newes from earth
Shall get no other but that thou art Brave.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: To preerve ome Ladies as we guet.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Still gallant, Brennoralt, thy word not heath'd yet?
Buie till?—

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Revenging Sir
The fowlet murder ever blated eares
Committed here by Almerin and Iphigene.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Fale, fale; The firt created purity
Was not more innocent then Iphigene.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Lives he agen?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Stay thou much wearied guet
Till I have thrown a truth amongt them—
We hall look back ele to poterity.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What ayes he?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Some thing concerning this he labours to
Dicover.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Know it was I that kild Francelia?
I alone—

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: O barbarous return of my civilities
Was it thy hand?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Heare and forgive me Mine
Entring this morning hatily
With reolution to preerve
The faire Francelia. I found a theefe
Stealing the treaure (as I thought)
Belongd to me. Wild in my mind
As ruin'd in my honour, in much mitaken rage
I wounded both: then (oh) too late I found
My errour. Found Iphigene a woman
Acting tolne love, to make her own love afe
And all my jealouies impoible
Whilt I ran out to bring them cure;
Francelia dies; and Iphigene found here
I can no more— (dies)

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Mot trange and intricate.
Iphigene a woman?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: With this tory I am guiltily acquainted
The firt concealments, ince her love
And all the wayes to it I have bin truted with:
But Sir my greife joyn'd with the intant buines
Begges a deferrement.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I am amaz'd till I doe heare it out.
—But ith' mean time,
Leat in thee mits merit hould looe it elfe,
—Thoe forfeitures
Of Trock and Meneck and Brennoralt are thine.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: A Princely guilt! But Sir it comes too late.
Like Sun-beames on the blated bloomes, doe
Your favours fall: you hould have giv'n me this
When't might have rais'd me in mens thoughts, and made
Me equall to Francelia's love: I have
No end, ince hee is not—
Back, to my private life I will returne.
"Cattell, though weary, can trudge homewards, after.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: This melancholy, time mut cure: Come take
The bodies up, and lead the prioners on,
Triumph and funerals mut walke together,
Cipree and Laurell twin'd make up one chaplet.
—For we have got
The day; but bought it at o deare a rate,
That victory it elfe's unfortunate.
